CIVIL AVIATION

Mr WEBB- I address a question to the Minister for Civil Aviation. Is there a curfew on the movement of jet aircraft at Sydney and Melbourne airports because of the noise? Is it difficult to introduce a curfew at Perth airport because international flights through Perth arrive and depart in the early morning? As Perth can expect more jet services in the future, and possibly bigger and noisier jet aircraft, what consideration is being given to reducing the noise nuisance at that airport? Will consideration be given to building a new airport away from built-up areas?

Mr SWARTZ-The answer to the latter part of the question is that no consideration will be given to the construction of another airport away from the built-up areas of Perth or of other centres at the moment unless sheer pressure on the facilities causes such a situation to arise. The noise question causes much concern to my Department as well as to people living in the vicinity of airports and action is taken by various means, including the determination of approach paths, to try to avoid it as much as possible. Restrictions are placed on the movement of aircraft at all major airports in Australia at night. This, of course, applies to Perth as well as to other airports.

There are circumstances where, in an emergency, it may be necessary for this regulation to be varied, but under normal circumstances traffic is permitted within certain specified times during the hours of darkness. I will look at the situation as it applies to Perth in relation to the international services that are being provided to see whether anything further can be done to avoid this problem, which I know is difficult particularly with the increased number of jet services that are being provided.
WATER RESOURCES

Mr MUNRO- My question is directed to the Minister for National Development. In view of recent Press statements about remarks he made in connection with the development of our northern river systems, can the Minister inform the House what work is currently being done in the investigation of our northern river systems, by or on behalf of the Australian Water Resources Council, and to what general extent this work has advanced our knowledge of the developmental potential of these water resources beyond what was reported in the 'Review of Australia's Water Resources - 1963* published by hia Department in 1965 for the Australian Water Resources Council?

Mr FAIRBAIRN- One of the first actions taken by the Australian Water Resources Council was to set up an accelerated ten-year programme in order to increase very considerably the number of gauging stations for measuring surface flow and also to increase the search for underground water in Australia. The honourable member will recall that for the last three years the Commonwealth Government contributed to the States for this accelerated programme $2.75m, and we will very shortly bc increasing this contribution for the next three year programme to $4.5m. This assistance has enabled the States to proceed very much faster than they were able to progress previously in assessing their resources of water throughout Australia, and I understand that in the north something like a 40% increase in gauging stations has been achieved. Naturally, however, as the honourable member would realise, it does take quite a considerable time after a gauging station is set in operation before final figures or adequate figures are available from it, so up to now we have not seen any reason to revise the review of Australian water resources by the Water Resources Council in 1963.
EDUCATION

Mr NICHOLLS- My question is directed to the Prime Minister. In view of the different forms of Government assistance now being given or offered to nongovernment schools in the various States and which has ted the New South Wales Methodist Conference to call upon its State Government to set up a committee of inquiry, will the Prime Minister give earnest consideration to the establishment of a national inquiry into ali aspects of education including both State and non-government schools?

Mr HAROLDHOLT - I would like to treat the honourable gentleman's question as being on notice. It clearly will require some consultation with my colleague, the Minister for Education and Science. When I have been able to give proper consideration to it I will reply to the honourable member.
Mr Whitiam- Before the House rises? Mr HAROLD HOLT - I hope so.
EXPO 67

Mr BUCHANAN- My question ls directed to the Prime Minister. In view of the huge sum expended on the Australian pavilion at Expo 67, apparently with no supervision from this Parliament through the Public Works Committee or any other source, and in view of the fact that the cost escalated from the original estimate of $2m to $3. 14m, will the Prime Minister consider sending a delegation of members to examine the fair, assess its value to Australia and report back to this Parliament?

Mr HAROLDHOLT- The provision for Expo 67 was undertaken by the Commonwealth Government after a good deal of consideration and after taking into account the very strongly expressed recommendation by our fellow Commonwealth country of Canada that we should participate. It marks, of course, a very notable occasion in the history of that country. I am glad to be able to tell the House that not only is the Australian pavilion attracting considerable interest and attention - the number of visitors over the first days of the exhibition has been more than double the estimated number - but I have heard very good accounts regarding it and the exhibits. It would, of course, be too late in the day for such a body as the Public Works Committee to report to the Parliament on the structure itself. What opportunities will exist for members of Parliament who may be overseas on other official duties to include a visit in their itinerary is not entirely clear to me, and I think that is an aspect which could be examined; but having regard to the provision we are making for delegations from the Parliament to go abroad for other purposes, I would not at this stage see a convincing case for adding to their numbers.
SUGAR

Dr PATTERSON- I wish to direct a question without notice to the Minister for Primary Industry. As the domestic sugar agreement expires in August this year, will legislation for a renewal of the agreement be introduced during this current sitting of the Parliament or will it be introduced after the Budget has been presented? To what level of Australian sugar production is the current Commonwealth responsibility restricted under the agreement? Because of the steep rise in costs of production in the sugar industry, is it a fact that the Government is giving very serious consideration to a rise in the domestic price of sugar of about 2c per lb?

Mr ADERMANN-The Acting Minister for Trade and Industry and I held a conference about a week ago with representatives of the industry at which all aspects of this agreement were discussed. Rather than adopt the approach suggested by the honourable member - that the Commonwealth Government take action with regard to prices or any other aspect - we always take the attitude that these matters should come from the industry first. The industry is now considering its final approach to the Government, and we expect to hear from it in the next few days.
EUROPEAN ECONOMIC COMMUNITY

Mr NIXON-I refer the Prime Minister to Britain's announced Intention to seek entry to the European Economic Community. Can the right honourable gentleman give the House details of any undertakings by the British Government to protect the interests of Australian industries? Further, can he assure the House that the Australian Government will place forcefully before the British Government the problems of Australian industries that have been developed to meet British requirements?

Mr HAROLDHOLT - This is a most important decision announced by the United Kingdom Government. Only this morning I received the full text of Mr Harold Wilson's statement, in the concluding sentence of which he said: for all of us realise that this is a historic decision which could well determine the future of Britain, of Europe and, indeed, of the world for decades to come.

From this it is clear that the matter should receive the close and urgent consideration of the Commonwealth Government, which it is now receiving. Ever since this proposal was first mooted we have given a great deal of attention to the implications of the entry of the United Kingdom to the European Economic Community. I do not propose to make a detailed statement at this stage, because the relevant departments have been applying their attention to the matter; however, I hope to be able to make a statement to the House after question time tomorrow.
SCREENING OF FILM

Mr JAMES- My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Customs and Excise. Is it a fact that a film, The War Game'; has been imported by the Australian Broadcasting Commission but has not been shown? Is it also a fact that this film is considered to be one of the most important films ever made but is unlikely ever to be shown in Australia because of official unwillingness to risk embarrassing the Government? Will the Minister make arrangements for the film to be shown at Parliament House by the ABC?
Mr HOWSON- I shall convey this question to the responsible Minister in another place and obtain a reply for the honourable gentleman.
DROUGHT IN TASMANIA

Mr PEARSALL-Is the Minister for Primary industry aware that Tasmania is experiencing the worst drought conditions in the State's recorded history? Has he been informed that lambs are being killed at birth to save the ewes? Has an approach yet been made by Tasmanian departmental officers seeking Commonwealth aid in the purchase of emergency stock feed on a dollar for dollar basis? Should such an approach be made will the Minister bear in mind the desperate nature of the situation and discuss it with the Treasurer and Cabinet as a matter of urgency?

Mr ADERMANN- I have been made aware of the drought conditions in Tasmania by the honourable member for Franklin who, I think, has done creditable work in investigating through the Australian Wheat Board the position in regard to wheat supplies and other matters that might be of assistance to the Tasmanian producers. I commend him for his energy. I am not aware of any approach having been made to the Government for finance in addition to that already given by the Commonwealth and the Tasmanian Governments for bushfire relief. I do not know to what degree that might involve the area mentioned. I have already mentioned this matter to the Treasurer. But I would indicate to the honourable member that if extra requests are involved, then in the first instance it is the function of the State Government to make an investigation and to give a report thereon.
POSTAL SERVICES

Mr CURTIN-Is the Postmaster-General aware that the vast majority of Australians now work a five-day week? Is he also aware that power, light, police, railway and transport facilities etc., and other services provided by the Postmaster-General's Department, are staffed for seven days a week by employees who are engaged on a five-day week roster basis? If so, will he give favourable consideration to operating post offices upon a similar five-day week roster basis, particularly as they are open for only six days a week?

Mr HULME-The question as to whether or not post offices should open for five days a week or five and a half days a week has received the consideration of the Government on a number of occasions. Generally there is a reduction of staff on Saturday mornings, but staff numbers are maintained at a level sufficient to meet the requirements of the public. In order to meet public requirements we are unable to have a very substantial reduction in staff on Saturday mornings. The Government's decision is that post offices should remain open for five and a half days a week. This is a public utility, and this service is required by the public.
BUTTER MARKET

Mr WENTWORTH-I address a question to the Acting Minister for Trade and. Industry about the entry of Australian butter into the United Kingdom. Is it true that our present arrangements, negotiated under the 1956 trade agreement, are terminable by the United Kingdom on six months notice? Would the terms of the Treaty of Rome involve the termination of these arrangements should Britain enter the

European Common Market without special reservations? Has New Zealand some special arrangement for the entry of butter into the United Kingdom market up till September 1972? Has the Minister any information as to how the United Kingdom proposes to reconcile her arrangements for New Zealand butter with the terms of the Treaty of Rome in the event of Britain's entry into the Common Market?

Mr SINCLAIR- Australia's butter exports to the United Kingdom, as the honourable member explained, were initially specified under the Ottawa Agreement, which provided for unlimited entry of Australian and New Zealand butter into the United Kingdom market. In 1961 the treaty was varied to the extent that quotas were introduced. In 1963 the surcharge of 15s sterling per cent was removed. This was a preference given to Australian and New Zealand butter. In 1966 the United Kingdom-New Zealand Trade Agreement came into operation. At this point of time, specified rights of access were granted up till 1972. The 15s preference was renewed,but it was waived on the condition that New Zealand continued to retain free access for certain quotas. Australia also retains quotas, which are determined on an annual basis and are subject to review, I understand, about 1st April each year. As the honourable member has explained, the quotas introduced in 1962 have operated subject to cancellation by either party on six months notice. To date Britain has not chosen to exercise this prerogative, either during the earlier application to join the European Economic Community in 1962 or during the Kennedy Round of negotiations which have continued since 1963. At this stage I see no reasonable likelihood of Britain choosing to exercise this option. However, as to the possible effect of Britain's entry into the European Economic Community and the comparable position of New Zealand, at this stage it is too early to ascertain the situation. I can assure the honourable member and other honourable members that the position at this stage at least is that there is no likelihood of Britain exercising that option.
DEFENCE EXPENDITURE

Mr BARNARD-I ask the Treasurer a question. Does he know what annual payments Australia is likely to incur in each of the next five years for defence purchases already arranged overseas? In view of the critical importance which overseas defence spending now has for our balance of payments position, will the Treasurer give details of all credit arrangements so far made, particularly those relating to the DDG destroyers and the Fill aircraft?

Mr McMAHON- I cannot give the figures for a succession of years, but this year we will be paying about $103m for defence purchases in the United States of America. At the beginning of the year and in the Budget Papers I gave the figure of $1 14m but that figure has been reduced by Slim. As to the other information sought by the honourable member, I can give him the details but I would rather check my memory as to figures and particulars of payments than attempt an answer now. If the honourable member does not mind, I will check the figures and, according to his wish, announce, them in the House or provide him with the information by letter.'
IMMIGRATION

Mr WHITTORN-I ask the Minister for Immigration a question. Has he any information to confirm that racial discrimination is building up in Great Britain? If this is the case, has the strain been brought about because lower standards are accepted by some migrants to the United Kingdom or are more important forces at work there? Is there a lesson for Australia to learn from the problems confronting the United Kingdom?

Mr SNEDDEN- I have read of difficulties in the United Kingdom of the nature referred to by the honourable member. I am aware that it was necessary for the Government of the United Kingdom to pass special legislation in connection with this matter. Every country must have the right to make a determination as to which people may come to that country and make their homes there. Each country makes its own decision and must accept the consequences that flow from that decision. We in Australia are very fortunate in that no other country is more free of intolerance and discrimination than is Australia.
Mr Bryant- What about politicial intolerance?

Mr SNEDDEN-I am speaking of racial discrimination. My view, which I am sure is shared by all honourable members, is that we want to retain in Australia our present freedom from intolerance and discrimination. I am sure that we want to build a prosperous and large society which retains our characteristic Australian identity and which will be free of intolerance and discrimination. This is not to say, of course, that people of diverse origins will not be welcomed in Australia as residents in reasonable numbers, having regard to their capacity to integrate into the type of community and society which I have described as our aspiration.
Fill AIRCRAFT

Mr COPE- Has the Minister for Air seen statements in this mornings' newspapers by Mr Kuss, the United States Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defence? Has he noted Mr Kuss's estimate that the cost of the Fill bombers being purchased by Australia will exceed $200m, even without armament? What was the last cost estimate announced by the Minister? If Mr Kuss's increased estimate is correct, why has the Minister not announced to the House the increase in costs?

Mr HOWSON- The cost that I have announced to the House is $US216m. As I have stated on more than one occasion, a provisioning team is in the United States at the moment investigating the requirements and costs of spares and associated ground equipment. When that team returns I shall announce its findings to the House. At the moment we have no information other than what I have already given to the House. I promise the House that when I do have further information I shall lose no opportunity of informing the House. No further information has yet been given to us by Mr Kuss and his mission. The teams were discussing this subject this morning, but, I repeat, no further information has become available. If it had I would certainly have informed the House.
TOBACCO

Mr HOLTEN-Is the Minister for Primary Industry aware that tobacco growers at Mareeba are dissatisfied with the prices paid for their leaf at the series of sales recently concluded? Is it a fact that lack of competition among buyers has been responsible for the low prices? Is it a fact also that a great deal of the tobacco was sold at minimum reserve prices after examination by the arbitrator? Finally, is the Minister aware that growers believe there is a plan to eliminate north Queensland tobacco growers from the tobacco industry?

Mr ADERMANN- I have received some representations from those who attended the tobacco sales. I do not think the representations are yet complete, because the sales, with which I have been keeping in touch, are continuing day by day. This is, in effect, the second series of the present sales being held in Mareeba. There is some dissatisfaction, which I think stems mainly from the lack of competition or of buying in the line, as it is called, at auction. The figures available to me so far show that overall - that is, over the two series of sales - the proportion purchased in the line would represent about 69.5%. This does not mean that every day 69.5% is purchased in the line. On some days the proportion has dropped to just over 50%, and this has certainly loaded up the work of the arbitrator because of his having to assess large quantities. Therein lies the dissatisfaction.

Of course any grower who submits tobacco for sale will, within the quota, obtain the reserve price that is laid down for that tobacco. The Commonwealth has given a guarantee of this up to a total of 26m lb. No-one could expect the Commonwealth or anybody else to guarantee a price in excess of the grade of tobacco as determined by the arbitrator. Actually the growers are getting a slightly better price than the reserve; I think they are getting 3c to 4c more per lb, on an average, than the average reserve price for the sale. So the overall picture is not so bad, because only 2% has remained unsold so far, or up to yesterday's sales - that is, in the line, plus the sales as determined by the arbitrator. The overall picture is not unsatisfactory. The unsatisfactory aspect is the lack of purchasing of sufficient quantities in the line, which puts a heavy load on the arbitrator. I do not think there is anything in the honourable member's final question about an attempt to eliminate Queensland growers from the scheme, because this is a four-year scheme and there is a quota for Queensland. The quota is 14m lb for that State, and I am sure that Mareeba is still selling good quality tobacco.
Fill AIRCRAFT

Mr CHARLESJONES - I direct a question to the Minister for Defence. Why was it left to Mr Kuss, an important American official, to come to Australia and make public important details about Australia's financial commitments in respect of Fill aircraft? Was he invited by the Australian Government? If not, in what circumstances is the gentleman in Australia today?

Mr MCMAHON-The United States Government has been extremely generous to the Australian Government in the terms and conditions of repayment of loans for defence purposes. We should express our gratitude to it for what it has done. When the Americans made their agreement with us that part of the loan was to be financed at an interest rate of 4%, we felt that it was proper that a representative of their Government and not ours should make this statement.
Mr CharlesJones - Was the Government afraid to make this statement?

Mr McMAHON-Nonsense. If one is generously treated, does the honourable member not think that the generous giver should be the one to make the first statement? I say no more than this: the Americans had the right to make the first statement, and they have made it. I repeat that this was a generous offer made by the United States authorities, and the Australian Government is grateful that the offer and agreement were made.
MUSCULAR DYSTROPHY

Mr CLEAVER- My question is addressed to the Acting Minister for Health. Will the Minister say what information regarding recognition and intensive research is available in respect of muscular dystrophy, which has been referred to as the least known and perhaps the cruelest of all killer diseases? Will the Minister extend encouragement to an association recently formed in Perth to provide practical assistance to those children who are sufferers?

Mr SWARTZ-I assure the honourable member that the action of a group of citizens in Perth is much appreciated; it has formed an association to sponsor a public appeal to assist research into this serious disease of muscular dystrophy. It is pleasing to know that some members of the medical profession in Western Australia have taken the initiative in this regard, and I hope that the association that has been formed there will extend to other States of Australia. A grant has already been made by the National Health and Medical Research Council to the principal research officer of this association, and an application for a further grant is being considered by the Council.
Fill AIRCRAFT

Mr GRAY- I direct a question to the Minister for Air. Is the figure of $5.3 1 m given by the Minister as the cost of the FI 1 1 bomber merely a basic aircraft configuration? Will any change in the basic design or the provision of extra equipment substantially increase the basic cost? In other words, is the aircraft being provided, at a cost of $5. 31m, little more than a souped up Cessna?

Mr HOWSON-The figure I have given to the House is $US5.95m, together with the increased cost for extra wingtips and strengthened undercarriage, which I have already announced to the House. That is still the most likely figure at which the Americans will sell the aircraft to us; lt is also the figure at which the British Government has been buying equivalent aircraft.
Dr J.F. Cairns- What is that figure?

Mr HOWSON-It is $US5.95m. The other matters still to be negotiated, as I have explained to the House on more than one occasion, are the cost of the ground handling equipment and the spares for the aircraft, but until the provisioning team comes back from the United States of America with full details on these matters, I cannot give the House any further figures.
EXPORT INCENTIVES

Mr IRWIN- My question is directed to the Acting Minister for Trade and Industry. Is he aware the motor industry complains that little encouragement is given to secondary industry to seek export markets? Is this correct? What is the extent of government assistance in this regard?

Mr SINCLAIR-The honourable gentleman will recall that the Prime Minister, in his policy speech, referred to the fact that the export incentive scheme would be reconsidered during the life of this Parliament. This review is under way at the moment. The honourable member will also be aware that a great deal has been achieved in the operation of the pay-roll concession scheme which operates to encourage exporters. I am sure the honourable gentleman's reference to one particular industry can be viewed in the light of the stimulus that this export incentive scheme offers. In addition, the Export Payments Insurance Corporation provides further financial encouragement to exporters. The Government endeavours in every way to encourage exporters to expand their base of operation. As it does in all fields, the Government believes that exports are in the interests not only of the Government and the country, but also of the manufacturer himself. The purpose of encouraging exports is to broaden the manufacturer's base of operation, thereby giving him a greater financial opportunity to expand and help more people, and in this way to assist the development of this great country.
Fill AIRCRAFT

Mr HAYDEN-Has the Minister for Air seen the statement by the United States Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defence, Mr Henry Kuss, that the Fill bomber will require maintenance spending equal to onehalf of its original cost every five years? Are these figures correct? If so, does it mean that the total cost of the bombers will exceed $300m during the first five years of use? Have we any guarantee that an end of this staggering cost spiral is in sight?
Mr HOWSON- I have already answered two questions on the cost of this aircraft. I have nothing to add.
CIVIL AVIATION

Mr TURNBULL- My question is addressed to the Minister for Civil Aviation. I refer to a case in which a provincial city cannot secure a daily air service because it has no night landing facilities and lacks finance to install them. What are the conditions or circumstances under which the Government, through the Department of Civil Aviation, provides night landing facilities at aerodromes operated by municipalities under the local ownership plan?

Mr SWARTZ-Under the local ownership scheme the Commonwealth normally provides up to the full standard the facilities that are required for the services which are in operation at the time of handover to the local authority. The facilities are handed over entirely without cost to the local authority. From then on, the maintenance costs are shared equally by the Commonwealth and the local authority concerned. A problem sometimes arises after an airport is taken over under the local ownership plan if traffic increases and more capital is needed to provide additional facilities. Normally this cost must be borne by the local authority; but in special circumstances, such as an unusual development in the flow of traffic, the Commonwealth considers sharing that cost. I suggest that if the honourable member has a particular case in mind, he should let me have the details so that we can look at the case to see what can be done.

ROYAL AUSTRALIAN AIR FORCE

Dr GIBBS- I wish to direct my question to the Minister for Air. Did the Australian Labor Party make an election promise to order, if elected, the British TSR2 aircraft for Australian defence purposes? Did this aircraft get off the drawing board? Would our defences have suffered a serious hiatus if the TSR2 had been ordered? Has the British Labor Government itself scrapped Britain's own TSR2 in favour of the Fill aircraft?

Mr HOWSON-i think the honourable member for Bowman has provided the House with some valuable information and it should be kept in mind at this time. I should like to add only the remarks of the Minister for Defence in the House of Commons who yesterday described the Fill aircraft, which is being purchased also by the United Kingdom, as an aircraft that will be eminently satisfactory for the defence services of that country in all the respects for which it is being purchased. He also said that Britain can be extremely proud to have bought this aircraft. All I can say is that, from the Australian point of view, I agree entirely.

Mr BEATON- I ask the Minister for Air a question that involves a matter of simple arithmetic. Does 24 go into 216 nine times? ls h true that we have ordered twenty-four FI IIA aircraft? Is it also true that the Minister has said that the total cost of these aircraft will be $2 16m? If this is so will the aircraft cost $9m each, and why does he continue to say that they will cost a little more than $5m each?

Mr HOWSON- I will not again go into the detail of matters that 1 have already explained to the House on a number of occasions. The fly away cost of the aircraft is $5. 95m plus, as I have explained, the costs of the extra modifications that we have requested for our own purposes. These relate to the wing tips and heavier undercarriage. We have in addition the costs of the special reconnaissance version. Six aircraft are being specially modified to have both the strike capability and the reconnaissance capability. In addition there are the costs of the ground handling equipment that is needed to operate the aircraft, of testing equipment for all the electronic devices in the aircraft and of the spares needed for the aircraft within the first year of its operations. All these costs are included in the $21 6m. The $5.95m is the initial cost of the aircraft. The other costs in the $21 6m are all required to enable the aircraft to operate effectively in the role for which it will be needed in Australia. I have said that in arriving at the total cost we have had to make an estimate of the cost of the spares and the ground handling equipment. Until the mission returns from the United States with details of these costs the figures I have given to the House will still be the estimate. When I have more detailed figures I will give them to the House, as 1 explained earlier today to the honourable member for Watson.
MIGRANT HOSTELS

Mr BUCHANAN-My question is directed to the Minister for Labour and National Service. Now that the Government has accepted the concept of selfcontained flats as transitory accommodation for migrants, will the Minister confer with the Minister for Works and try to have the plans of the Randwick and Springvale hostels readjusted so that the family units there, which are to be provided with a toilet and washbasin only, may also be made self-contained by providing a shower in each unit instead of the communal bathing arrangements that are now contemplated?

Mr BURY- The proposals for these particular hostels have already been examined by the Public Works Committee which has submitted a report on them to this Parliament. Any further tinkering would undoubtedly delay their construction. It is the Government's desire to replace some of our existing hostels as soon as we can with rather more satisfactory accommodation. Should we build any further hostels the question raised by the honourable member will be included in the consideration of the subject. However, this in itself is not directly connected with the provision of self-contained flats: this will be done on an entirely different basis. There will be no question of catering or of providing food and other facilities that we provide in our hostels. The flats will be a rather more expensive alternative for such families who desire to go into them.
SELF-GOVERNMENT FOR THE AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY
Ministerial Statement

Mr ANTHONY(Richmond- Minister for the Interior) - by leaves - I should like to inform the Parliament about the progress of certain investigations which I have made into the government and administration of the Australian Capital Territory. In view of the current interest of the people of the Australian Capital Territory in the question of self-government, I considered it timely that I should give them some advice on the progress of the investigations. On the other hand, the ultimate responsibility for the seat of government and the national capital rests with this Parliament, and I consider it my duty to inform the House before releasing the information.

Honourable members will be aware <hat the Minister for the Interior is responsible for the administration of the Australian Capital Territory. This function is performed in the main through the Department of the Interior, with the Department of Health and the Attorney-General's Department also playing important parts. Many other Commonwealth departments and instrumentalities are also involved. From time to time the people of the Australian Capital Territory, or at least some of them, have pressed for changes in the present system, under which their only elected representatives are a member in this House and eight members on the Australian Capital Territory Advisory Council. I have given serious study to the present administrative arrangements, particularly in the light of the views expressed by the elected members on the Advisory Council that selfgovernment is an immediate need and that the present arrangements are unsatisfactory. On the other hand, many residents of the Territory have indicated that they would prefer the present system, with all its faults, to a system which they did not know.

Having referred to the Australian Capital Territory Advisory Council, I feel I should tell the House that the Council has a very real role in the current arrangements for the government and administration of the Territory. The elected members of the Council are there as the representatives of the people of this community, and both the members, and their electors, make full use of their rights to interest themselves in all matters which affect them. My Department and I spend a great deal of time in considering the proposals put forward by the Advisory Council, and in supplying answers to questions. Honourable members will get some indication of the activities of the Council when I tell them that the present Council, which took office just two and a half years ago, has submitted well over a hundred resolutions to me. This figure relates only to what I term principle issues, many of which have In fact resulted in Council resubmitting various aspects of an issue to me two or three times by way oi further resolutions.

In addition, the Council has asked some 1,200 parliamentary-type questions on notice. The four nominated representatives on the Council have also replied to a host of questions without notice. As well as those motions which are passed as resolutions, there are vast numbers of motions which are not seconded or which are defeated after consideration. Although these do not reach me in the form of motions, they appear on the Council's agenda and thus involve a vast amount of work by officers in my Department in study and consideration prior to Council meetings. During the life of the present Advisory Council some 650 such motions have so far been listed on the notice paper and have received the appropriate consideration due to those matters which are raised by the elected representatives of the people.

As residents in almost any other part of Australia could testify, the existence of a system of State or municipal government does not, of itself, solve any problems of government and administration; nor does it mean that all persons living under such a system find themselves without grievances or cause for complaint. This being the case, it is important for those who would press for changes in the present system in the Australian Capital Territory to ask themselves whether they are concerned about their lack of representative institutions per se, or whether they honestly believe that greater local control would result in a better system of administration, recognising that such a concept will mean different things to different people.

If the desire of the Australian Capital Territory residents is for a more democratic system, based on traditional electoral responsibility, then it must be remembered that there is a wider democracy and a wider electoral responsibility which must also be accommodated. While the Government recognises that the Australian Capital

Territory is the home of over 100,000 Australians, it is also an area of territory acquired by the Commonwealth in accordance with the Constitution in order to fulfil a purpose which was specified in that Constitution. Underlying Canberra's constitutional role as the seat of government: - a place where the central organs of the national government are located - is its less legalistic but nonetheless important role as the National Capital, a city whose design and construction must be carried out to such standards as will reflect credit on the nation. It is these two concepts of. the seat of government and the National Capital which have for so long delayed the transition to responsible self-government for the residents of this Territory and which must continue, for many years to come, to influence the decisions of the government and parliament of the day on this important question.

Having said this, however, I must also tell the House that, since becoming Minister for the Interior, I have been concerned about this matter and I resolved to contribute to a solution if I could. Given the tradition of self-government at the State and municipal level throughout the rest of Australia, it has not been easy for me to accept with equanimity the situation in which this rapidly growing community is denied all representation, except for its Federal member who, for the first time, has full voting rights in this House, and a Council which may only advise the Minister for the Interior. I therefore initiated a study of the issues underlying the question of self-government for the Australian Capital Territory. Because of constant inquiries about the Department's study, and because of the interest which it may arouse, I have decided to publish a brief outline of the preliminary findings. Copies will be distributed to all honourable senators and members.

This interim information has not yet been considered by the Government. Thus, 1 emphasise that it does not have the imprimatur of the Government, and in fact' it makes no recommendations which require approval at this stage. It reports progress of exploratory studies, and its main purpose is to highlight those issues which will need to be considered before any firm decisions are taken. It does point up some of the real complexities of the problem and that a solution can be provided neither by any simple scheme nor quickly. As will be seen, quite a deal of study has been already undertaken, and while various possibilities are lightly touched upon these will need to be developed substantially as a next exercise in order to select the scheme or schemes which should be analysed in more detail to -enable us to assess how they may look in practice. In addition, a vast amount of material in relation to the activities of the seventeen Commonwealth departments and authorities that specifically affect the people of the Territory will need to be collected, collated and assessed.

It would therefore be imprudent for me to suggest what will ultimately appear as the best action in this problem. I have always felt, myself, that the Commonwealth would probably retain control of the centra] part of Canberra to a greater or lesser degree, and would tend to retain, or hand over at a later stage some of the State-type functions. I also believe, however that some municipal functions might be performed by the people, in particular in the new cities of Woden and Belconnen, as they develop to maturity. I emphasise that these are but first thoughts, not necessarily based on any concrete evidence. Conversely, they are also not ruled out, as yet, by the present studies. In any event, as first thoughts they could well be modified by the information and views revealed in the continuing studies.

Even assuming that we might eventually be able to separate national and local interests and pass over to the people of the Australian Capital Territory appropriate political and administrative responsibility, the assigning of appropriate financial responsibility, without which any other responsibility would be meaningless, will pose special problems of its own. In short, we will have to see whether the community of the Australian Capital Territory can assume that financial responsibility without which political responsibility and selfgovernment would not be possible. I emphasise that I have not yet come to any firm conclusions about which of the many alternatives I should see as the most appropriate. Nevertheless, I am conscious of Canberra's principal roles as the national capital and the seat of government, and I should not recommend any proposals which might place these roles in any jeopardy or derogate from the standards that we have managed to achieve. It is my hope that this progress report will stimulate further interest in the question of self-government for the people of Canberra and the Australian Capital Territory and that public discussion of the substance of the report will contribute towards finding the best solution to a most complex problem.

Mr S.R. FRASER (Australian Capital Territory) [3.38] - I commend the Minister for having brought this report, which is perhaps more correctly described as a study, before this Parliament, which at the present time must stand for the people of the Australian Capital Territory not only as the National Parliament but also in the role of a State government and a local council. This Parliament is the government of the Australian Capital Territory, whose laws it makes. Largely, of course, those laws are made by a process of passive acquiescence or by default, as the ordinances and regulations of the Territory are tabled in both Houses of this Parliament and become law unless a member of either House successfully moves for their complete or partial disallowance.

The Minister has put before us a very valuable study of the problems of govenment in the Australian Capital Territory which, I think, suggests lines of thought or research that might well lead to a decision and action by the Government to grant a form of self-government in the Territory.. During the sixteen years I have been in this place I have contended for the establishment of a form of self-government in the Australian Capital Territory. The people of the Territory should no longer be denied the right to govern themselves and should no longer be allowed to escape the responsibility of governing themselves. I have said that before, as the Minister for the Interior well knows.

But there are people in this community - I suggest they are mostly those who have lived here for many years - who find that things as they are are 'Pretty nice, thank you'. Those people have no desire to see a change in the machinery of government within the Territory. I believe that with the import of people from other States, notably from Victoria and the city of Melbourne, there is a growing feeling within the community that we should have a form of self-government and should no longer shirk that responsibility.

The present population of the Territory, as the Minister pointed out, is about 100,000. It is confidently expected that within thirteen years that figure will rise to 250,000. A population of that size, which largely will be encompassed within the city itself - our population outside the city area is about 2,500 - should not be without a form of self-government. The problem, as the Minister said, is how to divide the fields of responsibility. Canberra has been created. This is not a city which has grown in the ordinary sense of a city growing outwards from a main street. This city was created as the seat of national government. It was created as the National Capital of Australia. Because Canberra is the National Capital it is the responsibility of the people of Australia as a whole. Quite properly the people of Australia, through the National Government, must be prepared to accept expenditures on this place.

The Minister was not quite definite in bis statement about whether Canberra is now paying its way. If we take into account the sum for which land originally was purchased in the Territory, and the figure at which land is at present being disposed of by way of lease, and if we have regard to the charges and fees paid by residents, I would be inclined to agree with the opinion of Professor Arndt that Canberra is paying its way. If a statement of accounts showing the actual expenditure on the city and the receipts from people in this city were presented to this House, and if we took into account by contrast the amounts that are released by the National Government to State governments by way of tax reimbursements and subventions for the provision of roads and facilities within the States, as well as grants to the States for the creation of advantageous conditions in certain fields of primary industry, then I suggest to the Minister that he and the Parliament would find that Canberra is not a debt hanging around the necks of the people of Australia but that it is paying its way.

The people of Canberra pay income tax at the same rate as do people throughout the length and breadth of the Commonwealth. But because of the secure nature of the bulk of employment here, the absence of any heavy degree of unemployment, and the overall youthfulness of the population, the return per head from taxation in Canberra is greater than in any other part of the Commonwealth. So we are paying our way and are no longer a financial burden on the people of Australia.

Before determining, whether we should have self government, we must deal with the problem of establishing two fields of responsibility. Canberra is the National Capital. As such it is the responsibility of the National Government and of the people of Australia. But it is also the home town of 100,000 people. Shortly it will be the home town of at least twice as many people. These two aspects of the matter must be considered separately. While this city continues to develop as the National Capital and while it is maintained as such there will be aspects of expenditure which will remain the responsibility of the National Government and of the people. Canberra is a planned city. Many of the services that are provided here are much more costly than those for a more compact city of comparable population. Canberra is a city which sprawls along a valley from north to south for about eight or nine miles. Now it is spreading to the west. But it has been decided that Canberra is to be the seat of government. It has been decided that the government triangle will be in a certain place and that suburban areas will be in certain places. It has been decided that certain aspects of government will be located in certain areas of the city. Because of all these things the provision of water and sewerage services, telephones, electricity, roads, kerbing, guttering and footpaths - all the services that a modern city must have - is much more costly than for a city of comparable population which has grown compactly out of a main street and which does not have the large dead centre which Canberra has. Therefore a proportion of the maintenance of those services is properly a charge against the National Government and the people of Australia. This is the National Capital; it was so planned and it has so developed.

There seems to me to be no reason why the people of Canberra should not be required and should not be eager to accept the responsibility of governing themselves in their day by day affairs. I suppose that in some respects Canberra is the most un-Australian city in the continent. Here we do not have a form of government which follows the general pattern throughout the length and breadth of Australia. The people of Canberra, which as I have said is the very seat of national government and is the centre from which we govern the whole of Australia, are not entrusted with the responsibility of governing themselves. Figures were quoted yesterday which showed that of Canberra's population of about 100,000 approximately 23,000 are employed by the Government. Many are employed in the very business of government. In the higher echelons of the Public Service they advise governments; in fact they formulate policy for the government of Australia. But these talented and experienced people are not entrusted with the task of governing themselves. It is obvious that they are fully capable of doing so.

The Minister has said that it is not easy to find an early answer to these questions. As he would know, many inquiries have been conducted. He referred to them in the publication he has put before us. The first of the recent inquiries was conducted in 1949 - eighteen years ago. Successive Ministers for the Interior have chosen not to give importance to this matter, which has been raised frequently by some of the people of Canberra. 1 give full credit to the present Minister for the Interior. He has set in motion initial studies which are designed to get at the facts and to place before the Ministry and the Parliament the problems that must be faced in order to come to a solution and to grant selfgovernment. I do not doubt that the booklet which the Minister has placed before the Parliament will be most valuable to those in the community who have taken an interest in this step and who see that the time is coming when some form of self government should be established here.

With the establishment of some form of self-government here - it might be selfgovernment at the municipal level, which has often been described as the best form of democracy - it may well be that the people of Canberra will have to impose upon themselves rates somewhat higher than they pay now. I cannot see any argument against this because we have in this city a level of municipal services vastly superior to that provided in most provincial cities and even in some State capitals. There is no real reason why the people of this city should have those services at bargain prices. I do not suggest, and it would be fatal, perhaps, to suggest, that the people of Canberra should be called upon to pay increased rates but there is no really valid argument to maintain that in this city we should have a really excellent standard of municipal services at rates much lower than are being paid in cities of comparable size or with comparable population, or even in small towns just across the border from the Capital Territory. In saying that I do not disregard the fact that those who pay rates in this city also pay land rent, and, as the Minister knows, this is a somewhat burning question at the moment.

So when we are considering the revenues that should be available to any form of self-government established here, it may well be that we should take into account some diversion or some division of the sums received from land rent. Admittedly, portion of the sums paid in land rent should continue to go to the national government for its national expenditure in this National Capital, but if we do entrust a local body with the task of governing this city we should see that it has adequate finances and that it receives an adequate portion of the moneys paid as land rent or as premiums on the sale of leases in this place. Such a body should receive registration and licence fees and similar payments. Of course, it would have to levy rates within the city area. But the Commonwealth, I suggest, would continue to subvent the cost of provision and maintenance of many of the city or municipal services.

The Commonwealth may indeed have to increase its subvention towards the cost of maintaining omnibus services, because these are costs inseparable from the planned nature of this city and it would be wrong to call on this or any other generation of ratepayers to pay for all the cost of providing services which are costly only because this is the National Capital. I think the Minister would have in mind that if we were to establish here a form of local selfgovernment at the municipal or city level we would have congregated within our city area the greatest number of Commonwealth buildings which in other areas would be free of the payment of rates. Many municipal services are provided free to these Commonwealth establishments and to the various Service establishments of the Navy, the Army and the Air Force.

This is not a usual city. It is in many respects a most unusual city. But it is a growing city. It is a city which has developed vastly in the last twenty years or so. It is a city which in those years has shown, despite the opinions of eminent people from overseas, that it does have a soul and a community spirit which once it lacked. I believe that community spirit is sufficient to cause the people of this city to accept a form of self-government. I believe the people of this city should be given a say in what form of self-government they should have - whether it should be by legislative council, which to my way of thinking is not the ideal answer. I feel that what we need here is government of ourselves at the day by day level. My thoughts run towards a territory council which would handle all the aspects of government normally covered by the activities of a city or municipal council.

So I am indeed pleased that this step has been taken; that the Minister has been able to bring before the Parliament not a document which puts forward any hard and fast ideas, not a document which says this or that should be done, but a document which honestly surveys the problems and honestly poses the questions which have yet to be answered. I do not think these questions are unanswerable. I would have thought - 1 say this with the greatest respect to the Minister's predecessors that some action such as the Minister has now taken could well have been taken in past years by any one of several of his predecessors. It is to the present Minister's credit that he has acted in this field just as he acted to ensure that the people of the Capital Territory were represented in the Parliament by a member with full voting rights, however much he might dislike the fact that I retained my position in those circumstances. I give the Minister credit for his action.

I hope that the means will be found. I think it could be reasonably said that although there are problems - there must be division of financial responsibility and division of legislative responsibility - there must be retained to the National Parliament its right to the absolute say in the development of the National Capital; but there must equally be reserved to the people the right to say how they shall be governed in their home town. These are the two aspects which are perhaps hard to divide, but I do not think the task should have taken the time that it has taken. I believe that a government which had the will to grant self-government would find the means to grant it. I hope that the Minister will persuade this Government during its lifetime, which is ticking away far too slowly, to act in this field and to see that the people of the Capital Territory are given selfgovernment.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

Mr FOX(Henty) [3.50]- The Bill which we are debating today is the result of a survey - not a superficial survey but, in the words of the Chairman of the Australian National Travel Association, probably the most detailed of its kind to be carried out in any country. The survey took members of the survey team over 25,000 unduplicated miles in all States of the Commonwealth and in the mainland Territories. They interviewed probably every person of authority who had any first hand knowledge of tourism in Australia and of its problems. Again in the words of the Chairman of the Australian National Travel Association, the people interviewed included Premiers and ministers of tourism and also many Commonwealth, State and local government officials. The members of the survey team saw transport and accommodation executives. They interviewed restauranteurs, travel agents and tour operators both in Austrafia and overseas. They interviewed regional tourist promotors, statisticians, bankers, sharebrokers, directors of museums and of Aboriginal studies and a host of other persons in various fields of activity bearing on the terms of reference with which the

Committee was constituted. So we have no reason to believe that' this was not a comprehensive survey. From the survey came a report which has been called the HFK report, and from the report came the Bill that we are new debating.

At the present time tourism is ninth on the list of our foreign exchange earners. Last year tourism earned this country $59m. I believe that within the not very distant future it could well be second only to wool as an earner of foreign exchange. According to the International Union of Official Travel Organisations, which has a membership of 93 nations, international tourism is the largest single item in world trade. In 1964, 66.7 million tourists spent $US10.23 billion. The advent of jet aircraft, of course, has given a terrific impetus to travel. The HKF report envisages an increase in Australia's earnings from tourism of 142% over the next six years and 360% over the next eleven years. But this will not just happen. As with everything else which is worthwhile, we have to put in the work if we expect to collect the dividends. We - and I mean the Government and private enterprise - must create the right climate, and I do not mean weatherwise

Under the terms of this Bill the Government will be contributing a greatly increased amount to assist with promotion. Private enterprise must make its contribution. It must work to provide tourists with the kind of services and facilities they expect and which in fact they can receive today in many countries. We in Australia must set out not only to equal but actually to surpass the efforts of those other countries. First we must attract more tourists. We must advertise and we must sell Australia to potential tourists - and we have plenty to sell. Having attracted the tourists we must deliver the goods, because the best advertisement one can have for any product is a satisfied customer, and the reward for delivering the goods will be a very rich one.

You may well ask what I mean by delivering the goods. Nature will not let us down. We are blessed with natural attractions which are not found in other parts of the world. We are blessed with a good climate. I believe that Australians generally are blessed with good health and, again generally speaking, with happy dispositions. All these things are helpful when we are trying to attract tourists. We must provide the facilities. The accommodation we offer to tourists must be at least equal to the best available in other countries. Our restaurants, our theatres, our travel facilities, whether rail, road or air, our stores - we must strive to bring all of these to a standard at least as high as that prevailing in other countries.

A table which is included in the HKF report shows visitor arrivals for selected Pacific area countries during the period from 1958 to 1964. That table tells us that the number of overseas visitors to Australia increased in the period by 147%. This is a better percentage increase than that achieved by Japan or New Zealand, but it is inferior to those of Fiji and Hawaii, and a long way below that shown by Hong Kong. The last is understandable, because for one thing Hong Kong is a duty free port, and this undoubtedly is a very big attraction to the big spenders among the tourists. But with all due respect to Hawaii, what has that place got that Australia cannot match? Certainly not climate and certainly not surf beaches. Practically everything which attracts the overseas visitor to Hawaii is available in Australia in greater quantity and for less money. Our cost of living is lower than that of Hawaii. We know it, but international travellers do not, and it is time we set about telling them.
During 1964 more than two million Americans travelled overseas. Hawaii received 405,000 of those tourists and Australia received 20,000. Why? According to the team responsible for the HKF report:

The American and Canadian public do not yet know of the travel attractions and opportunities in Australia, and most wholesale and retail travel agents are not sufficiently interested in Australia at this time.

It is only a few years ago that 1 happened to meet in Melbourne an American school teacher. I think she had probably just retired, which would mean that she was most likely in her sixties. She had just arrived in Melbourne from Canberra and she asked me the population of Melbourne. When I told her that it was more than two million she was astounded, because she had been led to believe that apart from Sydney the centres of population in Australia consisted of a number of bush towns, and she had quite confidently expected to see kangaroos, emus, koalas and Aborigines wandering the streets of all the cities other than Sydney. As I have said, she was a school teacher, a person quite well educated. The HKF report also stated:

Travel. Tourism suffers in Australia from insufficient understanding of its importance to the economy and the wellbeing of the country and from failure to accord it the status of a major national industry.

I believe we ought to value tourism at least as highly as we value our export industries. While we frequently have to sell our exports on credit, with the possible risk of incurring some bad debts - and I am quite sure we do incur some despite the Export Payments Insurance Corporation - visitors pay cash for the goods and services they receive and in most cases they pay for what they see and leave behind in Australia, whereas when we export minerals, for instance, we are exporting something which cannot be replaced. But we are novices in the field of promotion. We must do more, a great deal more, and what we do should not be spasmodic but continuous. After all, we are playing for big stakes. The report suggests that we should adopt an aggressive marketing policy. This in my judgment means that we should not sell ourselves short.

The tourist offices of Mexico, Bermuda, Great Britain, Spain, the Netherlands, Italy, France, India and Jamaica spend from twice as much to eight times as much on advertising in the United Kingdom as Australia spends. If we do not spend we cannot expect to gain the profits. In the words of the men who used to haunt the local shows, if you do not speculate you cannot accumulate. It is not enough simply to spend money, we must spend it wisely; we must spend it in the right places and in the right ways. Our national expenditure on publicity and tourism is very low by comparison with that of many other countries. The investigating team suggested that we should be spending on promotion an amount equal to at least 2% of our earnings from tourism, and we do not spend this amount. For the year ended 30th June 1966 we actually spent $1.136m. I believe that Government expenditure on promotion can be likened to casting bread on the waters - it will come back many times over, not only in material terms in the form of taxation but also in goodwill and development.

Tourism creates employment, for the visitors have to be fed, housed and transported. As a result, the worker benefits from increased employment opportunities; private enterprise also benefits from increased business and profits; finally, the Government benefits from increased taxation income - from income tax, sales tax, petrol tax and payroll tax. The man in the street benefits from increased turnover, which lowers operating costs and in turn lowers prices.
Mr Cope- And the overseas balances.

Mr FOX- Yes, I am coming to that. That is the chief benefit, for any money coming to the country in this way assists in our balance of payments problem. While speaking of payroll tax I might mention that the Government already provides incentives to exporters by setting them an export target, based on a base year, and allowing a rebate on the amount of payroll tax they pay, in direct proportion to the amount by which their exports exceed the exports settled upon for the base year. Therefore, the more they increase their exports, the greater the rebates they obtain. It might be worth offering this concession of payroll tax rebates to the wholesale tourist business. If a target is set for this industry, any new business brought into Australia - not created within Australia - could be taken into account, and the proportion by which the increase exceeded the figures for the base year would lead to a reduction in the amount of payroll tax. This scheme should be worthy of investigation.

Apart from the obvious advantages relating to foreign exchange that can be earned by tourism, this type of activity stimulates potential investment in Australian industry, which in turn stimulates employment. Further, the goods that are produced then assist in the balance of payments problem, by replacing imports or by adding to exports. I am thinking of the motor vehicle industry, which came to Australia from overseas. In less tangible terms, tourism stimulates our immigration programme. The people who visit here might like what they see and will either come back here themselves or influence their friends and relatives to migrate to Australia. Tourism helps to spread goodwill for Australia throughout the world, and unrestricted travel, such as is available within Australia, could be the biggest factor in international understanding and world peace.

I should like to make what I believe are one or two constructive suggestions. People visit Australia for many reasons, one of which is to see our Aboriginals. This could be turned to the advantage of the Aboriginals. I do not believe that visitors should be ted to think that they are simply going to see Aboriginals as they would go to view animals in a zoo. Our Aboriginals should be accorded the dignity that is their right, and this cannot be done without their complete co-operation; indeed, it could be a challenge to them. We should make it clear to the Aboriginals that we do not wish to exploit them but, in a highly developed tourist programme, we see opportunities for them to advance themselves and their cause.

A few years ago I visited the Toronto Exposition, at which the Department of Trade and Industry had a stand containing a number of exhibits from Australia. There were manufactured goods, such as carpets and lawnmowers, from manufacturers in this country. Canned fruits also were exhibited together with a wide variety of other Australian goods. However, honourable members might be surprised to hear that the section of the stand that created by far the greatest interest from visitors was the exhibition of opals. The promotion of our opals could be another means of increasing our foreign exchange payments, both from the export of these gems and from attracting people here to see them mined. I believe that at Lightning Ridge they have begun to develop a tourist potential. Accommodation is available, although it is not so good as it is likely to be in the future. The more people go there the more can be spent on development of facilities and accommodation. I pass that on as a helpful suggestion.

My final suggestion refers to the treatment I received as a visitor in San Francisco, Los Angeles and Germany. In the two American cities I was contacted by local citizens who, working through their local government department, welcomed me to the city and asked me what they could do to make my stay there a pleasant one. They ascertained my interests and set out to see that I had the opportunity to indulge them. I came away with a very favourable impression of the friendliness and warmth of the people in both cities. I had the same experience in the cities I visited in Germany, through the Inter-nations Department. I do not suggest that this sort of thing can be done with every visitor to Australia, but I regard myself as an ordinary type of individual, who was visiting these cities not as the Prime Minister of Australia or even as a Cabinet Minister. However, these people still welcomed me in this way. I am unaware of any organisation of private citizens in any city in Australia which goes out of its way to ascertain from hotels, motels and guest houses whether overseas visitors staying there would appreciate a visit from Australians. From my own personal experience I believe that such an idea could catch on and would do much to attract goodwill for Australia. I hope that some of the local bodies will read these remarks in 'Hansard' and will consider them worthy of consideration. I believe this is a good Bill, and I congratulate the Minister and the Government upon introducing it. I have much pleasure in giving it my unqualified support.

Mr WEBB(Stirling) [4.8]- I am pleased to support this measure which aims at encouraging tourists to come to Australia. The more tourists we can attract the more we shall help our local industries, including airlines, road transport, rail transport, taxis and hotels. I am thinking, also, of the dining places where people can get casual meals, enjoying not only the food provided but also such things as the wine that comes from our Australian vineyards. In this way our wine industry will derive some benefit. It is obvious that the more tourists we have in this country the more employment will be provided for our people. That is why I am pleased to see that this measure has been brought forward to promote the tourist industry in Australia. The aim will be to promote tourism overseas and then, when the tourists arrive here, to show them our tourist attractions, expecting them to return to their homelands and to talk about Australia and to interest others in coming here.

It is not much good encouraging people to come here unless we have the facilities to satisfy them. I pose this question: is suitable accommodation available for the people we propose to attract? Our hotel accommodation is recognised as being very poor. I suppose one should refer to his own State in this regard. Only last week in Western Australia it was decided to adopt international standards and gradings in hotels, and the licensing court there has published a schedule of grading requirements, containing five categories in accordance with international standards, which range from five star to one star. Each of the 461 hotels in Western Australia will be graded by licensing inspectors. Unfortunately at the moment not one hotel in the State would qualify for the five star grading, although one is now being built and should be completed by 1969. This is not very good from the viewpoint of attracting tourists. There are a few metropolitan hotels that would get a four-star grading, but not many. Some country hotels would be lucky to get a star of any sort. I am not suggesting that all hotels should have a high rating. We must cater for all pockets, not only those of well to do people but also those of tourists who have saved for perhaps the only tour they will have in their lifetime and who for many years have to watch every cent of expenditure. Hotel standards must be raised, and to do this finance is necessary.

The honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Luchetti) yesterday suggested long term loans for hotel improvements. This is worthy of consideration. I noticed in this morning's Press that the Australian Hotels Association intends to make a new approach to the Commonwealth Government this year for preferential interest loans to renovate and build hotels. This was decided at the Association's national conference in Perth yesterday. I have given an idea of some of the difficulties that are facing us. I think the suggestion of providing finance, perhaps by long term loans, for hotel improvements is well worth consideration.

The Minister in Charge of Tourist Activities (Mr Chipp) said that in 1965-66 earnings from oversea visitors to Australia totalled at least $65m, and he pointed out that tourism was Australia's ninth most important earner of foreign exchange in that year. A firm of consultants has estimated that expenditure by visitors will be $120m by 1970, and $208m by 1975. This was subject to certain conditions which the firm outlined and which were mentioned in the Minister's second reading speech. They are as follows: Firstly, Australia's travel plant will be further developed and substantially improved; secondly, transportation costs to Australia will be reduced; thirdly, coordination of Australia's 'travel industry will be accomplished with the Commonwealth and State governments, as well as the travel industry, assuming their proper roles; and fourthly, an intensive and aggressive promotion programme will be carried on in conjunction with carriers and other interests to penetrate the major market areas. Those conditions are very important, but it is just as important to make certain that we are ready to receive the influx of visitors expected in 1970, and the greater influx expected in 1975. The Government must dp more internally to prepare the way for this expected stream of visitors; otherwise we could easily fail in the job we are setting out to do.

This Government has failed in many respects in regard to tourism. For years I have been pushing In this Parliament for the sealing of the Eyre Highway, but the Government has given little consideration to this important matter. The Governments of South Australia and Western Australia have prepared a joint case for Commonwealth support to complete the sealing of this highway. The South Australian Government has asked the Commonwealth to finance the sealing of the 266-mile stretch between Penong in South Australia and the Western Australian border. Very little development has taken place on this section of the road. The South Australian Government is prepared to do the work provided finance is made available. If this Government agrees to provide the finance, this trans-continental highway could be completed by the early 1970s. This is of the utmost importance to tourists. If this part of the road remains unsealed, many potential tourists who do not wish to go overland by rail will be deterred from travelling in this area. Some of these people will be overseas tourists who do not want to travel by plane or train. There is no doubt that some people prefer to travel by road, driving themselves wherever they want to go. Consequently, important benefits to our economy will be lost if this work is not completed by the time the expected influx of tourists comes to this country.

The programme of the Western Australian Government provides for construction and sealing of about sixty miles of the Eyre Highway each year. Since 1961 258 miles of the highway east of Northam have been sealed at a cost of $5,176,000. If this rate of progress can be continued, it is estimated that the 1 80-mile stretch to the South Australian border will be completed by December 1969 - that is, by the time this great influx of overseas tourists arrives. The Western Australian plan involves the sealing of 452 miles of road at an estimated cost of $9,734,000. The South Australian Government expects to have the highway sealed to Ceduna on its side of the border by 1968 at a cost of $5,260,000. I understand the South Australian Government is prepared to continue the bitumen to Penong provided the Commonwealth provides financial assistance to seal the section between Penong and the Western Australian border, the estimated cost of which is $6,300,000.

I point out again that the sealing of the Eyre Highway will be of tremendous benefit to tourists in this country. The work, when completed, will form a vital part of a national roads system that is urgently needed for the development of Australia and the expansion of the national economy. The tourist industry will receive a great stimulus when tourists are able to use a sealed road in this region. A sealed highway will give an impetus to the motel and service station trade along that highway. This Government will also benefit by increased collections of fuel tax when many more motor vehicles use the highway. This work, when done, could encourage more Australians to travel extensively in Australia instead of going overseas. This would strengthen our balance of payments. I have pointed out to the House that other countries have found that a trans-continental highway reduces the demand for foreign exchange from their own people and attracts foreign exchange from overseas tourists. In effect, it encourages people to see their own land first, provided they can get there fairly easily. Completion of the Eyre Highway will be of great assistance in this regard.

The honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren) said yesterday that in 1965, $58m came into this country in the form of earnings from overseas visitors and that Australians travelling overseas took over $122m with them. In other words, we were S64m out of pocket. The balance is against us at the present time. There is no doubt that this is a good Bill. We must make our scenic spots attractive to tourists if they are to come here and are to urge other people to come here later. I urge the Government to give a high priority to the sealing of the Eyre Highway from Penong to the Western Australian border by the early 1970s to coincide with the completion of the Western Australian section and the South Australian section. The work, when done, will greatly assist the tourist industry.

I should like to mention a matter that I referred to the Minister for Shipping and Transport (Mr Freeth) recently - namely, the proposal to terminate the standard gauge railway at Midland Junction in Western Australia. I did not get a satisfactory reply from the Minister. The present proposal, if implemented, could adversely affect tourist traffic. The original proposal was for a standard gauge line across the continent from Brisbane to Perth, a distance of about 3,000 miles. But this Government - not the Government of Western Australia - is now quibbling about the last ten miles of this great project. Instead of having the line terminate at the new interstate passenger terminal in Perth, the Commonwealth wants to terminate it at Midland Junction.
