If this proposal is proceeded with, the break of gauge problem will be transferred from Kalgoorlie to Midland. The absurdity of this should be apparent. A final decision has not yet been made, but when it is, let us hope that it comes down on the side of common sense. It is about time that this matter was settled. The Commonwealth should not be arguing about financing it. If additional funds are required, they should be made available, not only in the interests of tourism but in the interests of common sense.

We must remember that the terminal is not being built merely for Midland, which is in my electorate, but for Perth, Fremantle and indeed Australia. It will have international as well as national significance. To my mind, it is ridiculous to consider placing a passenger terminal of such national importance twenty-two miles inland from the shipping terminal at Fremantle, which is the western gateway to Australia. An item in the 'West Australian* of 30th March of this year stated:
No decision yet on railway terminal.
No decision had been made on whether to build the standard railway passenger terminal at East Perth or Midland, Premier Brand said yesterday.
However, it was a fact that the proposal to build the terminal at East Perth was in jeopardy because of the cost.
The Commonwealth Government's advisers on the project had reported that it would be cheaper to build the terminal at Midland than at East Perth.
Mr Brandsaid he would prefer to have the terminal at East Perth.
This seemed to him to be as far from the centre of Perth as it could conveniently be placed.

Surely that is a reasonable statement for the Premier of Western Australia to make. I urge the Minister for Shipping and Transport and the Government to ensure that the terminal is placed where it will be of advantage not only to Western Australia but to Australia as a whole. This will help our tourist traffic.

The Minister in Charge of Tourist Activities said that by 1970 we could have 320,000 visiters from overseas and that by 1975 the number could be 607,000. This is very good, but let us be sure that those who come here will be good ambassadors for Australia after they have left the country. Silly things like a break of gauge at Midland will not help. Imagine a tourist getting off a ship at Fremantle to travel overland by train. He would travel to Perth by train on a 3 feet 6 inch gauge, change trains at Perth, possibly, because the trains do not always go through to Midland, and then travel on another train using the 3 feet 6 inch gauge. Then at Midland he would commence his journey proper overland. No tourist would be impressed by this service. Nor again would a tourist be impressed if he decided to go overland by the Eyre Highway and found that he had to travel about 300 miles over an unsealed road from Eucla to Penong because the Commonwealth would not provide the funds for the sealing of the road.
Another field that calls for our attention in the development of the tourist industry is the use of supersonic aircraft. According to reports, they will be in the air by 1971.

But before then the Jumbo jets will be in use, and they will carry 490 passengers. Air travel will be revolutionised in the next ten to twenty years. Four nations - Britain, France, Russia and the United States - are now in the supersonic race. The first aircraft off the drawing board is expected to be the Concorde, which is a joint venture of the British and French Governments. These will be bigger and faster than any aircraft in use today. They are expected to fly at 1,450 miles an hour. Already world airlines are jumping on to the supersonic band wagon, fifty-two advance orders having been placed already for the Concorde. These new aircraft, because of the payload they carry, are expected to reduce fares. Although they wm be more expensive to operate, their larger payloads will mean that passengers will be able to fly at cheaper rates. Of course, this will mean more people travelling round the world and more people coming to Australia. The Jumbo jets will take three times the payload of the aircraft operating today. Instead of five seats across the economy section there will be nine, and the aircraft will be capable of carrying 490 passengers.

A major task will be redesigning air terminals to meet the challenge of the new aircraft. Where are the airports that they will use? What planning are we doing for the supersonic aircraft that will follow the Jumbo jets? Today's giant aircraft carry more than 100 passengers. The giant aircraft of tomorrow wm carry four or five times that number. When we talk about tourism we must think about the aircraft that will be used in future years. New methods must be devised to get passengers to and from the airports more speedily. The airline passenger today carries his luggage to a counter, has it weighed and checked in, pays an excess rate if his luggage is overweight and then walks to a holding room. After about half an hour he is shepherded on to the tarmac and aboard the aircraft. At the end of the trip he waits for about fifteen minutes for his luggage and catches a bus or a car for a drive of thirty or forty minutes into the city office. He often spends as much time - or even more time - travelling to and from the airport as he does in the air. This is bad enough with the aircraft being used today, with, say, a Viscount carrying fifty passengers. But imagine what the position will be when we have the Boeing 747 Jumbo jets carrying 490 passengers, and after them the supersonic aircraft. Travelling procedures must be simplified. This is being looked at now in European countries. Authorities in these countries are considering how to speed up the methods of getting passengers to and from the airports, how to speed up the handling of luggage and how to reduce the waiting time. If we intend to enter the tourist trade extensively we must look at these problems seriously.

As an honourable member said earlier in the debate, we must simplify our customs procedures. I agree with the honourable member for Wills (Mr Bryant) that we are out of step with the rest of the world. He pointed out that in 1963 Canada abolished the entry visa for nationals of certain countries. We should consider doing this if we intend seriously to encourage the tourist trade. One good feature about the procedures for entry into Australia is that, as far as I am aware, we do not have an airport tax. Honourable members who have travelled overseas know that most countries charge an airport tax. I think it is about 15s. The arrangement in Australia is good and I hope it is never altered.

I raised the matter of the bush fly menace with the previous Prime Minister. This problem was mentioned in the House yesterday. The previous Prime Minister advised me that the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation had been trying to find a solution to the problem. This pest will do much to stop people from returning here and from encouraging others to come here, and we must do something about it. People who come here for the first time may not know about our bush fly menace, but it does not take them long to learn about it. We see visitors who have just landed here being interviewed for television programmes, and they seem to be brushing flies away. I will never forget a review I saw of the Empire Games, which were held in Perth. People were waving their hands across their faces, brushing the flies away. The gesture was known in Perth at the time as 'giving the sign'. I hope the CSIRO will continue with its efforts to conquer this pest.

Australia has some wonderful tourist attractions and we can be justly proud of them. The honourable member for Henty (Mr Fox) mentioned quite a few of them only a short time ago. The Aboriginals are one such attraction. I would suggest that many features in the western part of the continent would assist the tourist industry. The Kimberleys and the north west were mentioned in the report. This area is novel for tourists. It is the most interesting part of this great country of ours, in my view. Australia has some of the best beaches in the world, and Western Australia has some of the best in Australia. Our beaches combined with our wonderful climate should be one of the best attractions to tourists. I have pleasure in supporting the Bill.

Mr IRWIN(Mitchell) [4.30]- The Government's intention to establish the Australian Tourist Commission is to be commended and the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade and Industry (Mr McEwen) also is to be commended for the part he has played in bringing about this Bill. The earnings from the spending of visitors to Australia will be considerable. It was estimated that in 1965-66 the amount exceeded $60m and that the sum earned by Qantas Empire Airways Ltd in that year was $6m. Tourist traffic does improve our overseas balance of payments. With increased co-ordination of advertising by the States the figures I have given will increase considerably. Tourism will provide more foreign exchange and will supersede most other earners of foreign exchange other than the wool and wheat industries. It will assist our employment situation and will foster employment in many fields. Over and above the material gains by way of overseas exchange and monetary benefits we must not overlook the goodwill and friendship that the tourist trade will engender between people from other nations and ourselves. As Australians we may lack veneer but we have national characteristics that endear themselves to most people - our friendliness and our down-to-earth attitude to most things. These characteristics will appeal to visitors from overseas.

This year the Government has assisted the Australian National Travel Association financially to the extent of $862,000. This authority, which was established in 1927, deserves our gratitude for the wonderful work it has done over the years, especially in the early stages of its existence when, because of the slowness of travel, it was difficult to attract tourists to Australia. They had to be people of leisure with not very light or strict schedules as to movement if they were to be enticed to Australia. The Association did a wonderful job in that respect. It recognised and comprehended the vastness of our tourist potential and initiated the move to appoint the Commission. It is difficult for people who have had an association with and been in control of a function to relegate themselves out of office. That members of the Association have done so proves their sincerity and genuineness.

Australia, and the Government, must become vitally and actively associated with all phases of tourism. Another gratifying aspect is that State governments, which have for some years had tourist bureaux overseas advertising the attractions of their own States, are desirous of co-operating with the Commonwealth Government in an endeavour to attract more tourists to Australia. The honourable member for Stirling (Mr Webb) spoke about bush flies. Of course, they are a definite hazard, but I see that through this Bill there is the possibility that more consideration will be given to eliminating this menace than has been given in the past. I am informed that this menace costs the wool industry at least $20m a year. It also raises the old and burning question that has never been fully answered: where do flies go in the winter time? We may be able to direct our tourists to places where flies are not present in great numbers.

I stress that first impressions are often the best and the most lasting. We must do something about our customs procedures. I have been at the wharves when people have arrived from overseas, and conditions of entry to Australia could not be described other than as chaotic. With better organisation and administration present difficulties in getting customs clearances could be obviated. I stress this point. It does not matter much what we do about advertising overseas: first impressions are important and our present customs defects are noted. Of course, we who live in Sydney have the Sydney Harbour and so have the edge on people who live in other States.
Mr Curtin- What about the Yarra?

Mr IRWIN- I did not want to mention that. I am sure that the improvement of customs clearances to enable people to get away from our wharves as quickly as possible is not an insuperable problem and it should engage the Commission's attention at the outset Furthermore, it is desirable that the facilities at Mascot and Tullamarine airports be completed in order to give people who fly into Australia a better first impression than they get at present. I hope that what I have said about customs procedures will be noted by the Minister because I believe it is one of the most important factors affecting tourists to Australia.

Mr COLLARD(Kalgoorlie) [4.40]- Mr Deputy Speaker, the Bill now before the House proposes to introduce for the first time an Act to establish an Australian Tourist Commission, the purpose and objects of which are to encourage more people to come to Australia and travel in Australia. The Minister in Charge of Tourist Activities (Mr Chipp) has informed us that the task of the Commission is 10 attract the tourists and that the States and Australian industry together must share the task and also the cost, apparently, of looking after them and providing facilities and amenities. Therefore, the success or otherwise of the Commission's efforts will depend very largely on what the States and private industry are prepared to do or can see their way dear to do in the way of developing these facilities and amenities which must go together with the tourist attractions.

So it would seem that the Government is of the opinion that once having brought people to Australia it has done all it can be expected to do. Of course, this is a completely wrong attitude to adopt, because it is not sufficient to leave the rest to State governments and private industry. There must be a co-ordinated effort between the 'Commonwealth, the States and industry; they must all work together under a proper plan so as to ensure that all those things necessary to achieve the final purpose of the Commission are properly carried out, not only overseas in the way of publicity but also in Australia itself. The extent to which that co-ordination exists will mean the difference between an easy task for the Commission and a very difficult one.

The Commonwealth must increase its financial assistance rather substantially if we are to enjoy any great increase in the tourist trade over a long period of time, and it is the long term which is most important. Late in 1965 the Managing Director of the Australian National Travel Association said that he agreed with the Director-General of the Irish Tourist Board that Australia was grossly underspending on the promotion of tourism. He went on to say that Australia was outlaying less than 2% of the return we received from overseas tourism alone. This niggardly attitude must not be allowed to continue. However, the Minister in this debate has not given us any encouragement at all with reference to finance for this Commission. In fact, he was almost noncommittal. The Commission's main and practically only job is one of publicising our tourist attractions, and in that regard it is not likely to run out of material, because Australia has plenty to offer, particularly in the way of natural attractions; but there is a great deal more to be done both at home and overseas if we hope to reap the full benefit from what nature has been good enough to provide us with, and certainly publicity by way of pamphlets and magazines will not be sum.cent if other things such as accommodation and general conditions are to be neglected.

Now there are several good reasons - and one in particular, of course - why we should be doing a great deal more to capture additional overseas tourist trade, and certainly we have a very wide area in which to cast our net. However, we should not overlook the fact that there are also very good reasons why we should be doing much more to encourage or persuade our own people to travel more widely and to see more of Australia. Unfortunately, it does not appear as though the Commission is expected to go very far into that area, and if that is so it is a great pity. In a country such as this, which has so much to offer in the way of tourist attractions and holiday resorts in so many different ways sufficient to satisfy all tastes, it should not be difficult to capture a great deal more of the local tourist trade. There are a number of avenues and methods which could be followed or employed towards encouraging people to see Australia first, and we should be pursuing the local trade with the same vigour and at the same time as we are pursuing the overseas trade.

It may be suggested that international trade is more important or has more value than domestic trade, but in my book we require both; but even if we are looking at tourism only from the angle of international trade, there is still considerable value in encouraging our own people to see Australia first.

The value I refer to in that respect would come from the personal observations and the knowledge of the Australian attractions which people would have when they went overseas and which they would quite naturally, even if unknowingly, put to good purpose in the way of advertising Australia amongst those people they met and mixed with overseas. However, the purpose of this Bill is to encourage people from overseas not only to visit Australia but also to travel in Australia, the idea being, of course, that they should be encouraged to visit our many tourist attractions. While the purpose of the Bill will meet with general approval, the Bill cannot properly achieve its purpose merely as a result of implementing the provisions which the proposed Act will contain, because they will fall far short of what is required in the overall situation if we hope to attract large numbers of tourists over the long term. If we are really going to set out in earnest to attract and encourage people to travel in and around Australia, I would have thought it would be necessary to commence proceedings in Australia itself by ensuring that what we have to offer is readily available and properly presented, and that inspection and consumption are guaranteed to take place in some degree of comfort. But in this case it appears that we are to adopt just the opposite tactics and that the Commission is to pursue a course of building up the number of visitors without first making certain of the other points. If this is allowed to happen there Ls a strong possibility, as I see it, that it could have a detrimental effect upon our efforts in the long run.

I say this because the reports of returning tourists regarding conditions and so on will carry much more weight than all the pamphlets and magazines we care to publish and distribute. We must not forget that this publicity campaign will have the backing of the Commonwealth of Australia and will not simply be a case of private industry looking for an easy dollar. Therefore, it becomes even more important that we ensure that good accommodation and conditions are part of the programme. Apparently it is not even certain that the Commission will undertake any investigation of tourist attractions in Australia before it goes overseas or before it commences its publicity campaign. I was surprised to hear the Minister suggest that this could happen when he said:
In the process it may be that the Commission will also study the Australian facilities and amenities which exist; it will need to do this to inform its own mind on what it is setting out to promote.

It was pleasing to hear that the Minister himself was of the opinion that the Commission should do this, but it seems strange that he should consider it necessary in raising the subject to use the words 'it may be', for surely this must also mean 'it may not be'. It would indeed be ridiculous for the Commission members to go overseas or draw up and publish advertising material without having first visited the several places of tourist attractions in each State to make themselves aware of what is actually offering, or perhaps more importantly to find out what is lacking, for it could be on the latter point where the efforts of the Commission could succeed or fail, depending on what is done or is not done to correct any lack of proper facilities.

Because of this, 1 would not have expected to hear any doubt expressed, particularly by the Minister, on whether the Commission would carry out an inspection of our tourist attractions as one of its first moves towards encouraging people to come to this country. The Minister has informed us that the Government's decision to establish an Australian Tourist Commission resulted from a proposal put forward by the Australian National Travel Association, and in turn, of course* that proposal was put forward as the result of a report brought down by Harris, Kerr, Forster and Co., one of the two firms commissioned by the Australian National Travel Association to make a study of the tourist situation and of Australia's potential to attract a greater number of tourists in the future, and not just in the near future, either. The report followed the biggest and most comprehensive survey and study that has ever been carried out on Australia's tourist possibilities, and I understand that it cost about $40,000. Therefore, it should be worthy of some respect and consideration. One of the recommendations out of several it made was that the Commonwealth should set up an authority or commission under the jurisdiction of the Commonwealth.

While this Bill will be the means whereby a Commission will be established, it does very little else. It hardly touches the important recommendations made by the Harris, Kerr, Forster report, except with regard to the adoption of a promotion programme; and that particular recommendation of the report is placed towards the bottom of its list of main points, so apparently it was considered to be of much less importance and perhaps meant that it should not be undertaken until several of the other recommendations were put into force. I would be inclined to agree with that view when we look at the report on a long term basis. While the report places promotion programmes and advertising as the eleventh of what it calls the twelve more important needs to encourage tourists, by this Bill the Government places it second among the powers of the Commission. I suggest that this gives a fairly clear indication of how unimportant the powers of the Commission will be when measured against the several recommendations of the report upon which this Bill is supposed to be designed. It also suggests that the Government is not treating this matter over-seriously
One of the powers of the Commission - apparently the main power - is:

To engage in, or arrange for, publicity campaigns or other publicity, by any appropriate means of communication, in relation to Australia, with particular reference to its tourist attractions and facilities;

Yet, despite the fact that the Commission is expected, with regard to publicity, to apply particular reference to tourist attractions and facilities in Australia, the Minister is not certain that it will actually make a study of these things, even though one provision gives the Minister the right to issue directions as to the actions of the Commission. The Minister's uncertainty is particularly surprising, as the Government apparently places more importance upon publicity than upon some other aspects of tourism. This legislation will give the Commission power to do very little more than draw up, publish and distribute magazines, pamphlets and other advertising material and to pass on information to travel agencies and transport operators overseas. This is only a very minor part of what is required if Australia's tourist potential is to be properly exploited.

It appears that the powers of the Commission could be wide enough to cover many of the requirements, because clause 16(1) provides that the Commission will have the power to do all things conducive to or necessary for the carrying out of the purposes for which the Commission is established. One visualises the Commission doing a number of things that should be done if it is to be successful in its efforts to encourage people from other countries to come to and travel in Australia. But the Minister has made it clear that the Commission is not expected to exercise its powers to the extent this clause suggests, for in his second reading speech he said:
The range of activities which will make up the Commission's main undertaking can be seen from the paragraphs of clause 16 sub-clause (2.) of the Bill.

He then went on to refer to publicity and advertising campaigns etc., which are all that those paragraphs give the Commission power to engage in. Apparently the Commission is not expected to interest itself very much beyond carrying out publicity, and this is where we may suffer in the future if our early publicity does not coincide with, or is not subsequent to, any necessary improvements in conditions.

After completing their field research members of the HKF Committee used the word 'poor' to describe some of the available accommodation, and they were also critical of facilities, or the lack of facilities. They then recommended that, where private industry could not or would not supply the necessary requirements, the Government should provide them and have them managed or leased by some qualified organisation. This is one of the avenues in which the Commission should be used in the first place. It should travel throughout Australia and note what may be lacking in accommodation etc. Where it found that lack of facilities was such as to offset to some degree the value of the attractions, it should have power to recommend to the Government what should be done and to indicate what is required to bring these places to a proper standard. Apart from this, it should also be safe in the knowledge that any reasonable recommendation it .made would be carried out. Further, it should be empowered to inquire into transport and accommodation charges and be able to report on whether in the different circumstances they are fair and reasonable.

The Commission should look at many other things and be satisfied upon them before making any move to go overseas, but this can happen only through a coordinated effort between the parties to which I have referred previously. Apparently the Government has done very little in this regard. The HKF report warns against the inclination to rush in and promote a rapid growth of tourism before we have established a planned and co-ordinated development programme on a long term basis. The report suggests that there is a danger in trying to cash in too quickly on the immediate situation rather than pursuing the certain success of a long term plan. I think this is clear from the following paragraphs of the report:

Australia stands on the threshold of great opportunity in the field of international tourism. Concurrently, it faces challenges in providing for an expanding travel movement of Australians at home and for the travel needs of a greatly increased flow of overseas visitors. It is now at a critical point where, to meet these challenges, it should make decisions, establish policies, and plan for the development of its travel industry, destination areas and travel facilities.

Australia at this time should review the progress it has made, give consideration to ils present position and adopt plans for the future. In a comparatively few years Australia has become one of the world's great emergent countries with an almost unlimited future. Travel and tourism are a fundamental part of this future and can contribute significantly to the realisation of ft.

It is the opinion of the Survey Team that it would be unsound to allow growth in tourism to take place as a result of pressures of Immediate needs without co-ordinating the efforts of government and industry or without harnessing effectively the existing enthusiasm and desire to take advantage of Australia's opportunities in international travel.

Australia should now adopt and implement a planned, co-ordinated and strong -tourist development programme. This should be based on a longrange plan despite any fluctuating balance of payments considerations and without interruption due to uncertain conditions and tensions which have developed, or may develop, in some parts of the world. Travel movements are a great natural force and, under the impetus of extraordinary improvements in transportation, continuously advance despite all but very major dislocations in world economic conditions.

So. as the report points out, there will be an automatic or natural increase in our tourist trade even without our publicity campaign being stepped up. What we have to guard against is any possibility of dissatisfaction with, or criticism of, our accommodation, travel and other facilities, charges etc. by those tourists when they return. If we leave ourselves open to those criticisms, they will definitely tell against us in the long term. Therefore, as the report rightly points out, we should ensure that we have a development plan and proper progress throughout Australia before we settle down to any high pressure publicity.

While quite naturally tourists will be interested in visiting and exploring our capital cities, it must be remembered that the great majority will be much more interested in visiting the outback and far flung areas of this country to see what they have to offer. I am referring to most of the country away from the capital cities. I am sure that they will be .more interested in looking at our flora and fauna and colourful views than in visiting night clubs. They should be encouraged to go to the outback - not to travel through it in a hurry but to remain for a while in attractive spots to gain the full value from what nature has been good enough to provide. To encourage them to do this it will be necessary to ensure that good comfortable accommodation and amenities are readily available. Unfortunately these things are not now available in some places, and the people on the spot are not able financially to improve conditions to the desired standard.

I notice that the Tourist Ministers Council has expressed concern about the standard of accommodation and is now pursuing a plan of uniformity to offset complaints regarding the misuse of the word motel' for- what has been found to be rather inferior accommodation, but I fail to see how it will get very far unless finance is made available. This possible misuse of terms relating to conditions and accommodation is one of the dangers the Commission will need to guard against when it is arranging publicity and drawing up pamphlets. It will have to be sure that what is advertised is correct and cannot be misunderstood. This again points to the necessity for the Commission to visit outback areas as one of its first duties.

The HKF report, in dealing with accommodation, estimates that 46,600 more rooms will be required within the next ten years - that was from the date the report was presented - to satisfy the tourist demands. Many of these will be required at the actual site of tourist attractions, or at least very close to them. It is in those places, in the country areas rather than the capital cities, where the main difficulties in relation to finance will arise. Where these difficulties do arise the Government will have to do something about them; otherwise we will find gaps in our overall tourist schemes which will considerably reduce their full value. Big improvements in accommodation have been made in a number of places. This is encouraging. The people who have been making these improvements are to be complimented. Even so there may still be quite a big difference between what may be termed a motel in the outback and something of that nature in overseas countries. This matter must be considered in our advertising.

Another thing we must guard against is the possibility of allowing our natural attractions to be swamped or ruined by man made attractions. This danger will always exist; it is one we will have to guard against. Undoubtedly there is a great future for Australia in the tourist trade. The greatest attractions we have are those which have been provided by nature. It would take several hours to refer to all of them - even briefly to describe their more interesting features. We have them, in every State, and in each State they are different. I could talk about the many attractions in my own State of Western Australia, particularly those in my own electorate. Western Australia is noted for its tourist attractions. They are located in every part of the State, and there is no need for me to dwell upon them to any extent. Nature has been very generous to Australia and has provided us with magnificent views equal to those anywhere else in the world. In most cases they are quite different to what one would see elsewhere. Nature has provided us with many varieties of fauna and flora - again different to what one would see in other countries. It is those things which, if properly preserved and not allowed to be excluded for man made glitter and glamour, will prove to be our greatest asset in the tourist trade.

If we can provide good accommodation and comfortable means of travel, both at reasonable cost, we are not likely to experience any difficulty in encouraging people to our outback areas - providing, of course, we do not allow that which has been given to us by nature to be destroyed by man made efforts carried out on the basis of a quick quid and to hell with the future. Some tourists will want to rough it to some degree in the wide open spaces. They can be accommodated without trouble at all. But others will want to see our natural attractions, such as birds, animals and flowers, in more comfortable conditions. To meet their demands it will be necessary to set up additional and extensive national parks where the animals, etc., can be preserved and encouraged to multiply. Reasonably good accommodation and other facilities will have to be provided to encourage tourists to stop over for at least a short time to enjoy those attractions fully.

Here again we find a need for finance. Here again is the need to spend if we expect to gather. The only source of finance for such projects will be the Government. Although the HKF report drew attention to the need for these types of attractions, if we want to succeed to any extend in tourism then the Government must move in those directions. But there is no suggestion that the Government intends to do so. There is also the need for new roads and improved roads to permit better travel conditions. It is of little use to advertise tourist attractions if it is not possible to reach them or if the condition of the roads is such as to discourage people from using them. Here again we should be able to expect some Federal responsibility.

As I said earlier, there is one particularly good reason why we should encourage many, more people to come to Australia. It is not the one referred to by the Minister - that is, our reputation for friendliness and easy going hospitality. The main reason is the one which causes other countries to try to increase the number of visitors they have - that is, the additional amount of money which can be gathered from tourist spend ing. But we should not be satisfied simply with what an increase in tourists will mean to tourist spending when considered against our existing facilities; we must concern ourselves with providing better conditions and better opportunities and, more particularly, with extending the fields in which tourists can be encouraged to spend. Whilst I support the proposal to give more publicity to what we have to offer, I believe that before pushing it too hard it would be better to spend a little time and quite some money in providing better facilities at those places where tourist attractions now exist and also in establishing additional attractions such as large animal, bird and flower reserves, and things of that nature, in the outback. I am sure that such reserves, where tourists could observe our animals and birds in their natural surroundings and where the animals and birds would be tame enough to come reasonably close to be photographed, would prove to be a tremendous attraction. The cost of establishing them would soon be recovered.

It must be remembered that increased tourist spending would benefit not only those who were directly involved. There would be many indirect benefits. The Taxation Branch would benefit largely, both from direct and indirect taxation. It would be a short-sighted policy to refuse financial assistance to improve features within Australia which would attract and hold tourists and, in turn, increase our returns. Yet we have heard nothing from the Government of any intention to make grants or loans to the States for the specific purpose of improving our tourist attractions. It is quite obvious that, if the Australian Tourist Commission is to achieve its purpose to any worthwhile extent, it will be necessary for the States to carry out a number of improvements to roads, water supply, accommodation, fares and other matters. To do these things State governments are certain to require financial assistance, but apparently they will have to beg for it from this Government Although I support the Bill because of the additional publicity that it is supposed will come from it, I think it would have been better to develop and improve many things in Australia before pursuing the publicity angle.

Mr WENTWORTH(Mackellar) [5.71- Like other honourable members, I support this Bill and I commend the Government for introducing it. It has been heartening to see the amount of interest shown in it. Because of that it seems to me that the Parliament should have two non-voting and unpaid members on the proposed Australian Tourist Commission - perhaps one from this House and one from the Senate. At the Committee stage I propose to move an amendment on those lines. I hope it will commend itself to the Government and the House.

Honourable members from both sides of the House have put forward a number of constructive ideas. I think honourable members can take some pride in this debate. As the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Collard) said during his speech, there are two angles to tourism, or two duties before the Commission. One is publicity and the other is the improvement of facilities in Australia. I do not want to under-estimate the importance of improving our publicity both at home and abroad, but I do not wish to speak about it today. I would prefer to concentrate on the improvement of facilities in Australia.

It has been said by other honourable members that tourism is big business. It enters into our balance of payments - our crucial fight for overseas funds - in two ways. In the first place, tourists coming here from abroad bring money. They are, as it were, an export; the money they bring to Australia is similar to the money that is brought into Australia by the sale of wool, metals or anything else that we send overseas. In the second place, we send abroad a large number of tourists from Australia. We have what is known as an unfavourable balance in regard to tourism. So if we can improve our facilities in Australia we can get more Australians to take advantage of them. This would be equivalent to import replacement, because it. would mean that funds would not go overseas. Even more than this, if we are to have m Australia a healthy tourist industry which will attract people from overseas, it must be built on the foundations of a healthy local tourist industry. So it would seem to me very definitely that we should be improving our local tourism as a means of import replacement and as a means of attracting overseas money.

I do not want to speak at the moment of the Australian tourist angle; I want to speak specifically of the overseas angle. We have to look at this matter practically, as a businessman would, and ask: what do overseas tourists want in Australia? Firstly, there is the prestige of going somewhere that is distant. This is a real thing which, certainly in the wealthier society of America, carries a great deal of weight. There is the prestige of getting away from things. Being far from other countries makes us, funnily enough, a tourist attraction. Secondly, there is the matter of novelty. When tourists come here they want to see something different from what is available to them in their own country. They do nol come to Australia just to have a repetition of London, Birmingham, New York or Chicago. They come here for novelty. Thirdly, tourists need comfort. They will not come here if we cannot offer to them the amenities to which they are accustomed. Now, there is some conflict between the novelty angle and 'the comfort angle. This is a conflict which we must face and resolve.

There is one other factor. We are south of the Equator and therefore our seasons are the opposite of those in the countries from which the bulk of our tourist trade can come. In particular, we have summer while the northern hemisphere has winter. This is one of the things which may be very important to us. After all, where in the southern hemisphere can one go? One could go to Africa, but many people would find Africa today uncongenial. One could go to South America. There is definitely a tourist potential in South America, but there is also a tourist potential in Australia and the islands of the Pacific.

It is up to us to exploit these angles - the prestige of distance, the novelty, the giving of comfort and amenities, and the fact that our seasons are the opposite of those of Europe and America. The angle of opposite seasons enables us to exploit Australian sunshine, Australian surfing and Australian fishing. Perhaps I may be pardoned for a moment if I say that my electorate, which contains the northern beaches of Sydney from Manly to Palm Beach, helps very much the Australian image. The fact that world surfboard champions come from my electorate is not to be entirely ignored. Indeed, the fact that Australian sportsmen have given such a good account of themselves in so many fields overseas is something which helps to attract tourists to this country.

I want now to talk about the novelty angle. It is of no use our trying to be a poor copy of what is in Europe and America. We have in Australia things which are unique. I think particularly of the Great Barrier Reef, the greatest coral structure in the world. Are we exploiting this? I know that we have some outposts on the Barrier Reef but are they sufficiently accessible and sufficiently commodious and do they have the necessary facilities? Let me emphasise that what we need in many of these cases is novelty value. It may be that the bulk of tourists - the people who will spend the most money in total - are not able to appreciate or even to afford these novelty items, but the fact that there is a small glamour fringe of tourists which individually spend a tremendous amount but in total, because their numbers are few, may not spend as much as the bulk of tourists, brings in the other tourists. I should like to see, for example, in association with our Barrier Reef such things as hovercraft, because this tropical wonderland, which is unique in the world, has a great potential for that kind of thing. Perhaps the small submarines which are used for tourists in the Mediterranean - there are such things - should be available here. We have in this House perhaps the most famous skin diver in Australia, so perhaps we should have facilities on a greater scale for skin diving. This kind of thing, which may not appeal to the bulk of people practically, will appeal nevertheless to their imaginations and bring in the bulk of the tourists who would like to see these things even if they will not use them or cannot afford them.

What are we doing to exploit our unique fauna and flora? I deplore the slaughter of the kangaroo which has been going on over too much of Australia. It is time we had a more reasoned look at the way in which some of our great native assets, which are worth money in tourist terms, are being despoiled and destroyed. What are we doing to exploit the attraction of our open spaces? It may be said that we are doing something in this regard, but where are our dude ranches, so-called? We do not want improved hotels in country towns. No tourist is interested in this kind of thing. What we want rather are proper facilities to enable tourists to go on to a station or cattle property, to see sheep and cattle being worked, to go to the Northern Territory and see the buffaloes, to see the wild birds in the Northern Territory, perhaps to visit the pelican rookeries and things of that kind.

These are the things we should be offering tourists, but we are not. Can a tourist hire in the outback a caravan and four wheel drive vehicle? One will find it hard to do so. What about our aerial taxis? We have a very good aerial taxi service in Australia, but is it sufficiently known? Do we publicise its work? I would say that we do not. We have potentially some of the greatest mines in the world. People would be interested in seeing these in the outback. Incidentally, one of our wrecked industries is the pearling industry. More than half the luggers in Australia are laid up with no work to do. Perhaps tourists blessed with a little imagination might find interest in this kind of thing.

The question of comfort comes in. First, I believe that in our big cities we should have first class hotels of international standard. We are getting some now. We have not, perhaps, got enough of them, but certainly the improvement that has taken place in the last six or seven years has been phenomenal.
Mr Arthur- We have them in Sydney.
Mr WENTWORTH-Yes, we have them in Sydney, and I think we have them in Melbourne too. Let us be generous to Melbourne in this respect.
Mr DonaldCameron - They should be everywhere.

Mr WENTWORTH- My friend from Brisbane says that they should be everywhere. I have already suggested that we should have them in all capitals. Although we do not want to spend large amounts of money on hotels in all our country towns there are certainly some country towns in which we should have good motel accommodation, and this is another field in which a tremendous amount of improvement has been shown over the last six or seven years.

We should also, as other honourable members have suggested, act as hosts to international conventions. We should perhaps have convention centres in various places. We should certainly have them in Sydney and Melbourne, and perhaps my friend from Brisbane might like to see such a centre in his city also. But most of all we have to sell our image, and our image is one of sunshine and space. I believe we have to sell Sydney as the capital of the South Pacific. We do not want to exclude the possibility of having Sydney thought of as the main centre for the Pacific Islands. It was once, you know, but it is not to the same extent today as it was in earlier times. But with our modern aircraft and ships we can perhaps revive this idea of Sydney as the main city of the South Pacific.

In this connection I would not rule out the possibility of a further liaison with New Zealand. New Zealand is different from Australia. It has different kinds of scenery and different attractions. The two countries might well complement one another, so that people coming here might automatically think of going on to New Zealand, and people who go to New Zealand might naturally think of proceeding to Australia. In this way the two countries might help one another, or lean on one another. Of course there is also New Guinea, which is perhaps one of the most spectacular places in the world. May I also add a suggestion that may seem a little outlandish. It is not meant for the general tourist but for the small fringe of luxury tourists whose activities will help to build up the picture of Australia, although these tourists are few in number and the total of their expenditure is small. I am one of the few members of this Parliament who have had the good fortune to visit the Antarctic continent. It is a difficult place to get to at present, because there are no normal travel facilities, but it would be quite easy to provide facilities to enable people to get there. As a spectacle the Antarctic continent is, I believe, without rival in the world. A visit to Antarctica is something which the average run of tourists would not be at all interested in, because it would be fabulously expensive, but I believe there is an opening for the development here of a little bit of tourist glamour, and I put this forward as something which is meant, perhaps, rather for advertising effect than to have any solid substance.

These are just desultory ideas that I have tried to throw into the ring. In doing so I want to build up the interest of this House, which has already been shown so markedly, and I want to ask the House to support the amendment which I shall move, that we should have on the Commission one member of the House of Representatives and one member of the Senate, non-voting and unpaid, merely to maintain contact between the very valuable work of the Tourist Commission and this Parliament which, after all, is more than the Government of Australia, and to which the Government of Australia is ultimately responsible. It is consonant with the dignity of this House that its members individually should have some part in the administration of government. I do not for one moment suggest that they should go into politically sensitive areas1- we all know that policy cannot be entirely bi-partisan - but I think the debate on this Bill has shown that on the question of the promotion of Australian tourism there is no difference between the two sides. It does not seem to me, therefore, that there would be any political difficulty in having a member of this House and a member of the Senate on the proposed Commission. I do not think they should have voting powers. I do not think they would have the competence to exercise an independent vote on technical matters, but they would have the competence to present the views of this House to the Commission, and the views of the Commission to this House. To give an analogy, we have members of this Parliament on the Library Committee, and this is right and proper. I see no reason, therefore, why members of the Parliament should not be members of the proposed Commission, and I shall move an amendment in the Committee stage with a view to having two members of the Parliament on the Australian Tourist Commission.

Finally let me express a view at variance with views expressed by certain other honourable members. It has been said in this debate that our Aborigines represent one of our great tourist attractions. With this I agree, but I believe our Aborigines are too important to be considered as a tourist attraction. I do not say that they should be barred from tourists, but I do say that their privacy should be respected and that any initiative with regard to their contact with tourists should come from them. Let them decide for themselves the extent of contact that they want with tourists. Let us not exploit these people as we are entitled to exploit our natural scenery, our flowers, our animals and our climate. I make this plea both for the Aboriginal people of Australia and for the people of New Guinea. Whatever tourist potential they have - and it is a great potential indeed - we should refrain from exploiting that tourist potential and from exploiting them. We should consider first their rights as people.

Mr PETERS(Scullin) [5.28].- It would be tedious repetition, Mr Acting Speaker, for me to take part in this discussion if I were in favour of exactly the same kind of tourism as those who have already spoken or if I were in favour of tourism for exactly the same reasons as those who have already spoken. With the probable exception of the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Wentworth), honourable members who have spoken have made it clear that what they want to make of Australia is a kind of playground for playboy millionaires. They want to establish in this country a number of Las Vegases, Monacos or Miamis, to be visited by the very wealthy. They consider that a commission for tourism should be an organisation to provide all the exotic requirements of that kind of person coming to this country. They believe that these people should come here so that we Australians may be able to exploit them and so alleviate our balance of payments difficulties.

I do not believe in that approach. My views on the subject are more along the lines expressed late in his speech by the honourable member for Mackellar, that is to say, the people we should attract to this country as tourists are the more or less ordinary types of travellers - people who cannot afford to live in luxury hotels but are coming here maybe to visit relatives who have migrated from England or some other country. The people I am thinking about could have a cousin, a husband or a son who has migrated here from

Italy, Germany or some other country. I am thinking, also, of the small shopkeeper or the professional man - even the working man - who had saved up some money in the south of Asia and was able to come on a trip to Australia. These are the people that the Commission should cater for, by devising methods whereby they can travel cheaply in this country and really get to know Australia. The Commission should ensure that these people do not travel throughout Australia, packed like sardines in tourist coaches which move from one hotel lobby to the other, with the passengers mingling only with the people in their own particular tour group.

This idea is not novel, but has been expressed by experts who have made statements on the subject in other parts of the world. Indeed, I have here a document entitled 'Luxury Forced on the Tourist' which states:
Millions of us,' said the American visitor to New Zealand, 'have never lived in homes that are luxurious and de luxe, so why do we have to travel that Way?

These people do not like living in luxury hotels and going on conducted tours that are reserved exclusively for people travelling on the same ship or from the same country - going from place to place and seeing the same prescribed features. This article describes how six experts entered into a discussion in New Zealand, and states:

How can we get these American tourists out of the hotels? The question was the start of a long discussion of the tourist industry in New Zealand and Australia by three American couples, all of them travelling in a somewhat unusual style, and all six indignant about touring 'Down Under'. . . .

All six have travelled extensively in the United States and are critical of the high cost of touring for the average family there. All agree that the unfortunate American tourist, obliged to buy a managed tour and live in hotels abroad, when not cramped for time, should be rescued from that insulated existence and placed in the main stream of people-to-people foreign travel. . . .
But you must hand it to these Kiwi and Aussie families who know how to beat high touring costs,' Mrs Quibell said.
Mrs Quibellwas one of the six people who took part in this discussion. She continued by saying:

They throw blankets, linen, an electric fry pan, a teapot, cutlery and dishes into their cars along with the kids and take off on a holiday they can afford. It would be wonderful if people without a trailer could do the same in our country.'

They suggest that tourism should be promoted along those lines so that they can travel cheaply to the places they want to see and not be forced to live in luxury hotels and motels with the other members of a group from their own country. They go on to point out in this article:

And our American tourists sit cheek by jowl all day on bus or plane or train. They eat together in the same hotels, trudge obediently side by side after tourist couriers to see the same tourist sights, and then at night loll in the lobbies with the very same people.'

Of course, they object to that - and I also would object to it along with, I believe, the majority of tourists. The discussion of this measure leads one to believe that honourable members seek to establish a Commission that will take the tourists and prescribe for them exactly what they are going to do, in surroundings of the greatest luxury; indeed, Surfers Paradise will be a relatively cheap place compared with the exotic surroundings that will be created for the tourist trade. If that is done, the Commission will be providing for only the comparative few. The article I have been referring to continued in this way:

Maybe we sound like malcontents. Maybe we're even subversive,' said Dr Quibell. 'But I'm serious about the Down Under Government agencies ignoring the millions of us in the United States who would come down here if they could be assured of reasonable touring costs.'
Dr Inglesadded: 'Not to forget our own millions who are not wealthy and who would appreciate such facilities along the tourist trails back home.'

These people would appreciate those facilities in Australia, and I believe that this is what the Tourist Commission should aim at, rather than starting out with the wrong concept of providing the most exotic facilities for the more or less millionaire tourists from other countries, exploiting them, and merely using them as a weapon to reduce our overseas obligations.
Mr Lynch- That is not the Government's intention.

Mr PETERS- The way Government members have spoken during this debate has conveyed the impression that we have to reduce or retrieve the deficit of $634m that has come about in tourist trade balances in the past fifteen years. I admit that it would be a good thing if we could break even, but tourists should not be exploited. A better purpose for the promotion of tourism in a country like this would be, instead of getting a few dollars out of the people who come here, to promote a real understanding between our people and the peoples of other countries. If the relatives of migrants to this country see exactly what Australia is like they will become ambassadors for us when they go back home, either inducing others to migrate here or becoming migrants themselves.

I admit that we have beautiful beaches and mountain resorts, and I realise that most electorates have their tourist attractions. Australia has sporting events that would appeal to people from all over the world. The potential football premiers, the Carlton team in my electorate, provide such attractive entertainment that tens of thousands of people flock every week to see them play. I am sure that people visiting this country from overseas enjoy this team's play. Other honourable members naturally have different ideas on where our visitors should go. I heard someone say that they should stand in awe, admiration and bewilderment before an opera house somewhere in Sydney. I believe that in future they will stand in bewilderment and amazement before the Sydney Opera House, feeling somewhat like the traveller who gazes upon the sphinx. Looking at the vast pyramids, he might ask how anybody could have built such gigantic edifices for the purpose for which they were used in days gone by when there was so much greater need for other edifices and buildings.
Mr Turnbull- What about the Leaning Tower of Pisa?

Mr PETERS-The Leaning Tower is leaning only by accident, but the building in New South Wales to which I have referred is being deliberately put up at the expense not of one hospital but of dozens of hospitals. High schools, a university, hospitals and homes for aged persons could have been built with the resources that are going into the building of one place that so far has been called an opera house, though I believe some people suggest that ultimately it will not be an opera house. However, that is enough of that matter. It might be an attraction for people, and probably it will be; but there are other attractions. One of them is Ayers Rock in the centre of Australia. Vast areas in the north west and the north of Australia will appeal to people of adventurous spirit who come to this country to see part of the world in which they live.
Mr Nixon- There is Gippsland.

Mr PETERS- Of course. Gippsland is magnificent, with huge gums covering vast areas down near the place where the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr Nixon) has a magnificent farm that takes up too much of the land in that region. I stress the absolute necessity of improving our tourist facilities. I intend to make the Minister a present of the document I have in my hand which describes luxury tours to New Zealand and other places. Why do tourists have to travel that way? Why do they have to go to hotels like the Wentworth Hotel, which I have heard lauded in this House? I would rather have hotels of reasonable standard stretched throughout the length and breadth of the country than one gigantic edifice rivalling the great hotels of the centres of civilisation in other parts of the world. I suggest through you, Mr Deputy Speaker, to the Minister in charge of this Bill, of whose energy I have not the slightest doubt and for whose capacity I have a little admiration, that he take into consideration the provision of amenities for tourists of the ordinary, average kind.

Mr TURNER(Bradfield) [5.44]- I agree in some respects with the contentions of the honourable member for Scullin (Mr Peters). I join with him in his tribute to the Minister in Charge of Tourist Activities (Mr Chipp) who, I believe, is capable of carrying this new project to fruition. The honourable member for Scullin spoke of tourists who preferred simpler and plainer fare. If we are to be businesslike we must take into account all tourists, all customers. This is a business matter, and all customers should be considered. I would not be as exclusive as the honourable member. Some tourists prefer luxury tours and others are satisfied with the kind of facilities to which the honourable member referred. Both groups are tourists, potential customers, and both have to be considered.

The Minister proposes, under this Bill, to set up a commission to replace, in effect, the Australian National Travel Association. Perhaps that is not an accurate way of putting it. The new Australian Tourist Commission is to be, as it were, the head and front; but the Association will still have an important part to play. The number of members of the Commission will be small, but all of them will be experts. Provision is made for the appointment of people with considerable knowledge and expertise in this field. The honourable member for McKellar (Mr Wentworth), with whose general contribution I agree, foreshadowed an amendment; but, although I agree with some of his reasons for it, I shall not support the amendment. It is important that the Commission should remain small and expert, and for this reason I do not think it desirable to increase its membership. No matter what the reasons are, it is of no use increasing membership of an expert committee by including parliamentarians.

The reason for setting up this Tourist Commission is that the Government at last means business in this field. It recognises that tourism is an important earner or saver of foreign exchange. The Minister has pointed out that last year the tourist industry brought in about $65m. This can be compared with $94m earned by the dairy industry. The big difference, however, is that the cost to the Government of the tourist industry was a mere $826,000 - less than half a million pounds - whereas the cost to the Government of the dairy industry, through direct subsidy, was $27m and the cost to the butter consumer $33m, or a total of $60m to produce that return of $94m. Looking at the tourist industry in this context, one can see its great importance. There is no doubt that more should be spent on it to derive more revenue from it.

The Minister referred to a number of highly desirable targets. The Harris, Kerr, Forster report anticipates that by 1970 there will be 320,000 visitors to Australia, and by 1975, five years later, 607,000 visitors. This will increase the income of all people associated with the tourist industry in Australia. Targets are splendid things. They are easy to put up, but we all know that they are much harder to hit. This arithmetical game is good fun, but we are concerned with hitting the target rather than playing with visionary figures and thinking how splendid it all is.

There are two or three relevant and sobering reflections. As a result of increased affluence, there have been more tourists not only in Australia but also in north America, Europe and other advanced areas of the world. This affluence means that more people can afford to travel than hitherto. We must remember that not only do more people travel to Australia, but also that more Australians now travel abroad. Therefore, we are concerned with more than a tremendous increase in earnings from oversea visitors to Australia. Looking at the matter in context, we must realise that we must try to reduce th: cost to the nation of Australian tourists going abroad. We want tourists here to pay at least part of the national expense of Australians going abroad. We should not regard local tourist returns as something already in the bag, and think of oversea tourists as an additional source of earnings. We are really saving imports, so to speak. We are really trying to redress the balance.

We must remember, too, that competition is very keen. As I say, these are some sobering reflections. We are not the only people who are seeking to attract more tourists. The whole world, including countries in our vicinity, is doing so. This is a highly competitive business and is not be engaged in lightly with the thought that the fish will just swim into the net. Let me give some examples of the competion that we face. In 1965, 185,000 Americans visited Japan. Japan has such tourist attractions as the Ginza, which is a great shopping area, and the ancient city of Kyoto. It has many other attractions. We should not think that we are the only people in the world with attractions. This large influx of Americans into Japan in 1965 was an increase of 15% over the number of Americans who visited Japan in 1964. In 1965 Taiwan, a very small country of ten million people, had 133,000 visitors. This was 40% more than in 1964 and 600% more than in 1960. In 1970 it plans to have 300,000 visitors. So Taiwan too is aiming at a quite considerable target, just as we are, and it is on our side of the Pacific.

Even India, despite its famine and all its troubles, in its five year plan for 1966-71 has allocated $A30m for tourism. This is to be spent mainly on improving facilities for tourists. In 1965 Mexico had 1,400,000 visitors, and this was an increase of 100% on 1964. It is, of course, near the United States and so has a great advantage. There is, however, the encouraging thought that, although Europe used to be the main tourist resort for Americans they are prepared to look away from Europe because, with the increasing affluence of the Western world, so many of them have already seen Europe and are turning somewhere else. That is, of course, encouraging to us. Even the United Arab Republic, which includes Egypt, is expecting that tourism will become its second most important industry. It has targets too, and expects that in three years the revenue from tourism will be greater than the revenue from the Suez Canal.

I said that these were some sobering thoughts, that tourism is not pure gain, that we are in a very competitive field and that we cannot win the tourists we hope to get without considerable effort. This means, firstly, greatly increased expenditure. The Minister for the Navy (Mr Chipp) has said nothing very much about this, except in the broad terms that he does expect that more will have to be spent. In 1966-67 Government expenditure for tourism was no more than $862,000, or under half a million pounds. This obviously must be stepped up considerably, and we must do more than engage in extended promotion. How this revenue will be raised or how the Government will provide the resources I do not know, and I am not dealing with this point in great detail now. But we may well have to consider, at either the Commonwealth or the State level, doing what is done in other countries. We may have to impose a surcharge on accommodation in certain types of hotels or an airport tax. Though this will not bring very much, it may be useful. If we are going to catch a mackerel the sprat must be a fairly sizeable one, in my judgment.

I have a second point to make, apart from the fact that this new departure means the expenditure of much more money if we want to enter this highly competitive field with success. My second point has been made with great force by the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Collard) and a moment ago by the honourable member for Mackellar. It is that we must match promotion with facilities. I am afraid of the boomerang effect if our promotion goes ahead of facilities and tourists come here in large numbers, are gravely disappointed with the facilities they find and when they go back are the very reverse of ambassadors selling Australia for the future. I would hope that these two requirements would march very much hand in hand. Like the honourable member for Mackellar and others who have spoken in this debate - it is not a novel thought; indeed it is perfectly obvious - I am concerned about the Australian image that we will present. Those who go to Europe look for history, ancient buildings and ancient monuments. Many of the visitors who go to England may go back to the village from which their people have sprung. If they go to Italy they go to see the great works of the Renaissance. If they go to Florence, they may go to see the Giotto Campanile, the Church of Santa Groce, the Medici Memorial, the Pitt Gallery and so forth. We do not have this history or this heritage of architecture and art.

What indeed is our image? What are the attractions that people would be likely to come to Australia to see. We have the advantage of the HKF report, which sets out the things in Australia in which the visitor is interested. I think in order I can state them as our outback, our Great Barrier Reef, our unique flora and fauna, the frontier aspect of our development and those peculiar creatures, the Australian people. So we do have some guidance from a proper assessment and survey, not from imagination, as to the things that ought to be promoted. But if they are promoted, will we have the matching facilities? This can be a difficult, expensive and intricate business. There is ample power under the Bill for them to be provided. It is the money with which to provide them that is likely to cause the trouble. May I say before I pass on that the report did not deal with other attractions in our area. We are concerned also with tourist attractions in New Guinea and the earning of money for New Guinea, whose development is so expensive to Australia. Tourism can bring revenue to Australia via the Pacific Islands if the facilities are provided by our shipping and so on.

When we look at this matter we must realise that we do not have all the advan tages in the world. I think we must be realistic about this. I have heard member after member speak about the great glories of his own electorate. But we do not have all the scenery in the world by any manner of means. We do not have anything like, say, the Grand Canyon. Mention has been made of our Blue Mountains. We do not have anything like the Rockies or the Alps. Let us realise that we do not have everything. It is rather pathetic very often to hear somebody who has never been outside his own parish say that his area has the most wonderful scenery in the world. In order to make comparisons we must know the two things that we are comparing. If he has never been outside his own parish how can he make this comparison? To say that people want to see scenery and we have the most magnificent scenery in the world is a pretty naive approach to the problem. Fortunately the Minister has had the report which sets out what people do want to see when they come to Australia. They do not want to see all the things about which honourable members have been dilating for the last day or two. So it is the distinctive character of Australia with which we are concerned, and we have some guidance as to what are the distinctive features in respect of which facilities should be provided. The facilities should match the promotion so that people who come here to see something will not be disappointed because they cannot see it. I ask for leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned. Sitting suspended from 6 to 8 p.m.
AUSTRALIAN TOURIST COMMISSION BILL 1967
Second Reading
Debate resumed.

Mr TURNER-Before the suspension of the sitting I was suggesting that if we are to promote tourism in Australia we must promote it in respect of those aspects of our country that interest people from overseas and not what we may happen to think are attractive features of our landscape. If we are to expect tourists here, they will expect to see things that are distinctive of Australia - the kind of things they are not likely to see elsewhere. We have the advantage of the report to which the
Minister referred and which points out, after a survey overseas, those things that attract tourists to Australia.

The first attraction, according to the report, is our outback. Promotion must keep in step with facilities and if we are to promote the outback and invite people to come to see it we must provide the facilities to enable them to see it. If, for example, they want to see a cattle station we must make sure they can see it. Similarly if they want to go to a sheep station and see shearing operations, sheep dogs in action and so forth, we must make sure they can see these things.

If we are to promote the second feature that the survey says is attractive to overseas visitors - the Barrier Reef - we must make sure -they can see it in the way they want to see it. At present there are four or five launches operating in the Barrier Reef area and they are too small. The divisions between the cabins are by no means soundproof and tourists are cooped up on these small boats. Arrangements are not such that they can go ashore to spend a night on islands in the area. Altogether the facilities are not of the type tourists would wish to have, having been induced by our advertisements overseas to come to see our Barrier Reef. If it is a question of seeing our flora and fauna then it is fine to pass along miles and miles of our bush, but it is much more interesting if the tourist knows something about the way our various native flora are also able to protect themselves against the heat of the sun, bush fires and so forth, so that he does not see merely a lot of leaves, flowers, blossoms and seeds without knowing why they are as they are. I do not want to engage in this extensively, because the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Collard) spoke about it at considerable length.

A little while ago I saw a television film of Montreal where the great Expo 67 is being held. It was a city of glass towers and vast buildings - a port on the St Lawrence River - just as Sydney is a port. It had industrial areas and so forth. Americans do not want to come to Sydney to see glass towers, vast buildings, a port or industrial areas. They have only to cross the border to Canada to see them. Indeed, their own cities are like that. There is nothing distinctive about it. On the other hand in

Sydney, (or example, we have very little civic pride. Possibly one of the great advantages of tourism is that we may really discover our own history and background. We have in Sydney the old barracks in Queens Square, full of historical associations. We have the miserable law courts with a lot of outhouses, as we might call them, surrounding them. Queens Square is just a miserable place.
Mr IanAllan - lt is being rebuilt.

Mr TURNER- As at this moment it may be. It has been like this for a long time. Here was the centre of Macquarie's Sydney. It has a colonial atmosphere with St James Church, the old barracks building and so on. I hope that if we seek a distinctive image this kind of thing will be preserved. We can have plenty of glass towers rising to twenty storeys or more, as in Montreal or any city of the United States of America, but this little part of old Sydney is unique and we do nothing about it. It may be that in inviting tourists to Australia we may discover our own past, which would be a very good thing.

Tourists - and 1 am indebted to my friend the honourable member for Scullin (Mr Peters) for this - like to have accommodation of an international standard. They like hotels of an international standard. My honourable friend from Scullin says that he does not want to encourage people like this to Australia, but tourism is a business proposition and if this is what they want it is no use saying that we have the best hotels in the world if the tourists, after they have been here and find they are the worst in the world, go back home and say to their friends: 'Do not go to Australia'. We have to meet the market, in other words. These are our customers and we must meet the market.

In Taiwan, for example - and I mentioned earlier the tremendous number of tourists it has been able to attract and the tremendous hopes it has for the future - hotels of international standard gain a tax holiday for five years. In Australia, according to the estimates of the experts, we will need about 4,000 rooms per annum additional to the rooms we now have. It may well be that the Government will have to do something about this and think of the possibility of providing a tax holiday for hotels of a certain standard that would have to be defined.

We must consider country accommodation. Country hotels, of course, have been quite appalling for a long time. We are said to have the best beaches in the world and the worst hotels. Indeed, some years ago I visited the Northern Territory, going up through New South Wales north of Bourke through Barringun, Cunnamulla, Charleville, Kynuna, Cloncurry and Camooweal, to Darwin and back by Tennant Creek and Alice Springs. I met with the most appalling hotels I think I have struck anywhere. It is no use saying that we have the best of this, that and the other in Australia when we have not. People from overseas are not going to accept it because it just is not true.
Mr Katter- At least the service is preferable to some service.

Mr TURNER-I should like to say something about service. Our attitudes in Australia have to be altered. I do not think the situation is as bad as it was but Australians in the past have regarded it as beneath their dignity to provide service in an hotel as service should be provided. 1 can remember some years ago being in Switzerland at a place called Lugarno and in the hotel where I was staying a skilled waiter attended to me.
