He was accompanied by an apprentice. The waiter took a pride in his skill and the apprentice was learning from him. If the Australian attitude is that it is beneath our dignity to exercise this kind of skill then we will not get tourists. Apart from this, there is no moral advantage in not taking pride in skill. If my honourable friend talks about service in these places, all I can say is that in the Northern Territory - and J was riding a motor bike at the time - I never before met so many hard faced men and women on the make. The service was bad and the attitude was appalling. These things have to be altered if we are going to be like, say, the Swiss - a nation of inn keepers, though not entirely, I hope. This was my own experience in travelling through these places. I repeat what I said: I never met so many hard faced men and women on the make, the accommodation was rotten and the charges were high. This situation has to be improved. I am not saying this for the sake of being unpleasant but for the sake of the truth and in the hope that these conditions may be improved.

I wish to refer briefly to other matters that are likely to be taken in hand by the Commission. The first impression that people have of a country is tremendously important. If a person goes to a country and has to wait for the customs people to attend to him, for the health authorities to attend to him and all the rest of it, his impressions are unfavourable from the very outset. I hope that the Commission will set up an interdepartmental committee comprising representatives of the Departments of Customs and Excise, Health and Tourist Activities, because each of these Departments at present is concerned only with its own particular interests. To see, for example, whether a person has smallpox is the interest of the Department of Health and to see that a person has paid customs duty is the interest of the Department of Customs and Excise. 1 should hope that the Tourist Commission insists on the appointment of an interdepartmental committee to ensure that tourists are not unnecessarily held up with these procedures.

Although I do not wish to spend much time on this topic, I hope that from the promotional point of view the Commission will do something about providing decent documentary films and seeing that the kind of propaganda that goes out in magazines likely to be read by possible tourists is better than in the past. In a recent issue of a leading monthly magazine of some repute a writer described the surf at one of the main Sydney beaches as being so rough that at the end of the day plates of false teeth found in the water would be placed on a shelf outside the club house to be claimed by their owners. It is time we got away from the Dad and Dave approach instanced in this case, and I hope the quality of this kind of article improves.

Coming back to my friend from the Northern Territory, I would hope that some kind of welcome stranger organisation might be set up whereby an Australian with a similar calling to a visitor would be prepared to invite the visitor to his home for an after dinner chat; in other words, to give a friendly reception to visitors. In the survey that the Minister quoted, he mentioned that one of the five main things that visitors from America, at least, expect and are interested to see here are the inhabitants - the Australians - these strange people who produce such remarkable sportsmen and who are so friendly. Well, I hope they will be more friendly than I found the people of the Northern Territory to be. I suggest that a welcome stranger kind of organisation might be set up. I suggest, too, that the Commission might consider group travel for, say, American senior school children to visit Australia and see something of the life of this country, and I would hope that possibly travel grants might be made to senior school children on the basis that when they got back they would go around to various secondary schools and say something about the country they had visited.

I point out that the Americans in particular think of buses as means of transport for the hoi polloi; they prefer to travel by train. Why should we not have some de luxe trains? People must move around on the ground if they are going to see the country, because they cannot see it from the air. Why should we not have some de luxe trains that could provide sleeping accommodation as well as a means of seeing the countryside? If they were not in use all the time, they could be used in local towns, for conferences and the like. This is an opportunity for the railways commissioners to take up. I would hope that there would be display centres in the cities where people could see the products of the country, and that we might be able to promote some of our own products such as our wines. Australians probably more than any other people enjoy very reasonably priced meals of Iamb and steak and so forth, and our restaurants are good. These are things that could be promoted and could assist in promoting our exports as well.

I could mention many other things if I had the time, but probably they have been mentioned by other speakers and advocated more ably than I could advocate them. I support the Bill, and I hope that we will really be launching a campaign to bring visitors to this country. I hope that the facilities here will keep pace with the promotion. I do not want people to be brought here to see something but fail to see it and that the boomerang will come back through people saying: 'Don't go to that country, the accommodation is atrocious; I wanted to see country life but I saw nothing of it; I wanted to see the Barrier Reef but the way I saw it I don't advise my friends to go and look at it.'
Mr ACTING SPEAKER (Mr Lucock)Order!The honourable member's time has expired.

Mr HANSEN(Wide Bay) [8.15]- The purpose of this Bill is to establish an Australian Tourist Commission of seven persons to be appointed by the GovernorGeneral. Two of the voting members are to be appointed by the Minister from a panel nominated by the Australian National Travel Association. Two non-voting members are to be persons nominated by the governments of the States. The honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Wentworth) has foreshadowed an amendment whereby he proposes that a representative of this chamber and another from the Senate should be appointed to the Commission. Whatever reasons the honourable member has for this I feel they are very hard to justify when we recall that on the Commission there will be only two persons representing all of the States, which have a very vital interest in this matter.

I think the reason the honourable member for Mackellar has moved this amendment is that he feels that the Parliament is responsible to see how the money is spent. This brings me to the point that I do not see anything in the Bill to indicate that the Commission is required to present a report to Parliament. The Australian National Travel Association has been supported by the Commonwealth Government over a number of years, and while it does a very worthwhile job it presents its report or balance sheet not to the Parliament but to the Minister for Trade and Industry (Mr McEwen). If any honourable member has endeavoured to obtain a copy of the report of the Association I hope he has had more success than T have had. Twelve months ago I tried to obtain a copy of the Association's annual report and after a time I obtained one which was three years old. However, I have now been able, after three weeks of trying, to obtain the 1965-66 report of the Association. The

Commonwealth has money invested in the work of the Association and invested, I believe, to bring about a good return. This is evident if one reads the report. But most honourable members have not had the opportunity to study the report of the Association and to appreciate just what has been done. The honourable member for Mackellar may have a very good point when he suggests that there be parliamentary representation on the Commission. However, it is to be a restricted Commission. Since the members will bc appointed not only because of their interest but also because of their ability and knowledge of tourism and what is required by tourists, and since membership is to be restricted even in the representation of the States, I believe that the proposed amendment should be rejected by the Parliament.

The report of the Australian National Travel Association for 1966 indicated that it was hoped that 3,000 New Zealanders would come to this country. I had thought that the trend was for Australians to go to New Zealand rather than for New Zealanders to come to Australia, but apparently quite a number of New Zealanders come here. In 1965, 27,675 people visited this country from the United States of America and Canada. From the United Kingdom and Europe there were 35,140 visitors of whom 22,800 came from the United Kingdom. Also, there were 4,000 visitors from Asia and 5,375 from Malaysia and Singapore. The 4,000 from Asia came mainly from Japan. The only place from which we have had a falling off in the tourist trade was Hong Kong. I do not know the reason for this. The Minister referred to the value of tourism to Australia. He pointed out that this industry was the ninth most important earner of foreign exchange in 1965-66, bringing in a total amount of $59m. He also said that by 1970 we hoped to attract 320,000 overseas visitors and, five years later. 607,000.

I join with the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Turner) and other members in saying that we must ensure that suitable accommodation is available for these people. I do not think the rescue of false teeth by members of surf clubs should be decried. I suppose people have to identify their teeth. I know of an unfortunate case in which a friend of mine was wandering on a lonely beach at low tide looking for his teeth. He met a beachcomber who said he might be able to fix him up, and produced a box of teeth. My friend went to this man's house, and the man found a set of teeth that fitted him. My friend asked: Are you a dentist?' The man replied: 'No, I am an undertaker'. At any rate, my friend was satisfied.
Mr Freeth- A service for tourists?

Mr HANSEN- That is a service for tourists. Fourth-class accommodation has been mentioned in this debate. The honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Turner) spoke about hard-faced men and women on the make. These people are probably typical of many who find they have to pinch pennies to make a success of hotelkeeping This applies particularly to hotels owned by breweries in many parts of Australia, the licencees of which find that as soon as their trade builds up their rents are increased. These people work long hours and would probably earn more per hour if they worked forty hours a week on the basic wage. Probably this is one of the reasons why Australians do not take easily to service in hotels. Also, most Australians are not servile: they do not like to think they are waiting on people and at their beck and call. I do not mean that other people are thought any less of because of this, but Australians resent this kind of work.

Most Australians do not like tipping, so they find, particularly if they are staying in first-class hotels overseas, where tipping provides the major part of the income of hotel employees, that they get black looks and poor service. Australians think every person is entitled to a decent wage, and for this reason they do not take readily to tipping, being tipped, or having to wait with hand out in order to get half of the wages to which they are justly entitled.

The Government made available to the Australian National Travel Association in the year covered by the report the sum of $462,000, plus a further grant of $1 for $1 which amounted to $272,923. It was estimated in that year the tourist trade was worth $7 1.4m to Australia, so it can easily be seen that the money spent was a good investment. The point arises whether we will be able to keep pace in hotel accommodation. When on holidays, many people do not want to get up at 5 o'clock in the morning to watch kangaroos feeding on the dewy grass or to see wombats before they go to sleep, or koalas in the trees. Most people want to relax. If they have the money to travel long distances - this applies particularly to overseas visitors - they want reasonable accommodation.

We should also cater for travellers on small budgets. Most overseas countries indicate the types of hotel available so that people will not find they have been booked into hotels where the tariff is above their means. In this vast country of ours there are many differences in country. All honourable members who have preceded me have dealt with various places in Australia - the Great Barrier Reef, Ayers Rock, Darwin, the north generally, the Blue Mountains. I believe Australians should be encouraged to get to know Australia before they go overseas.

Affluence has been mentioned in this debate. I believe that the conditions under which we now work, particularly the fact that people get long service leave and three weeks annual leave, have contributed much to travel by Australians in Australia. Teenagers, and young married couples with their families, come north during the summer months and stay in places in my electorate and nearby. People are able to come from Victoria to these places because they now have three weeks annual leave, good cars and good roads. In the winter months the type of tourists changes; then the middle aged executives and retired couples travel north to get away from the cold in the south. Because Australia is in the southern hemisphere - it is the largest continent in the southern hemisphere - I believe it has something to offer to Europeans. As travelling increases with the advent of Jumbo jets and cheaper fares, perhaps people not only from Europe but also from the United States will come to Australia to dodge the northern winter.

Mention has been made of gimmicks. What type of gimmick is necessary to attract people? My electorate has 120 miles of coastline, apart from 250 miles of shoreline of the largest sandy island in the world. I refer to Fraser Island, which is the largest island close to Australia. One of the best publicity gimmicks that I know was in relation to Burrum Heads. An anti-progress association was formed there which drew nationwide publicity, not because it tried to attract tourists but because it tried to keep them away. Signs were posted along the road leading to Burrum Heads warning tourists to keep out. The association advertised that it was setting up farms to breed sand flies and sharks. A previous speaker mentioned that bush flies were a problem, but I would rather put up with bush flies than with sand flies. With sand flies, at the end of a day I look like a case of measles. The association also urged the local regional board to ration power and turn it on intermittently for four-hour periods. As a result of these things, the local caravan park was booked out. I do not know whether this type of publicity would be successful on a national scale, but I mention it for what it is worth.

The Great Barrier Reef, which is one of the wonders of the world, has been mentioned. For many years people did not realise just what it was like. The honourable member for Dawson (Dr Patterson) paid a tribute to Senator Ian Wood for the work he had done in publicising this great natural feature. I know that what was said is true, because an uncle of mine was connected with Senator Ian Wood, not only around Mackay but also on Heron Island. I know the battle these people had and how many people went broke trying to encourage tourists to come to the Great Barrier Reef to see what it had to offer. I believe much can be done, but unless we ensure that accommodation is available to the people whom we encourage to visit these places, I believe our efforts may misfire. The Commonwealth has a responsibility in this regard. I promised the Minister that 1 would not speak for very long. Therefore, I conclude by saying that if honourable members have been vocal about this Bill, particularly in regard to their own electorates, undoubtedly they have been fired by the enthusiasm of the Minister, whose second reading speech exceeded twenty-four pages. I support the Bill.

Mr KATTER(Kennedy) [8.30]- While sitting here for the last week or so I have heard various references to the town of Cloncurry, in which I reside. Tonight I heard the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Turner) speak. When he spoke of riding his motor bike we could almost visualise him in his leather jacket. Perhaps I should refer to him as the Marlon Brando of Bradfield. His reference to Cloncurry gives me the opportunity to speak briefly about the accommodation that is now provided there and in other inland areas of this great nation.

A recent survey made in the United States revealed an interesting evaluation of tourist attractions in Australia. Clearly the average tourists from the United States want to see two things while in Australia. They want to see the Great Barrier Reef and the great inland regions of the Northern Territory arid the border areas of Queensland. I can quite understand why they would want to see those places. I should think that if they spent any time in Sydney and came in contact with the people there, who have clearly indicated their rudeness and lack of courtesy, they would go to these great inland areas even though the proprietors of the hotels in those areas may be a little hard faced. Do you know why they are hard faced, Mr Acting Speaker? They are hard faced because they are a little tired of city slickers passing through and taking most of the cutlery and any other portable utensils that may be readily available.

This prompts me to mention a rather interesting incident; it relates strictly to tourism. All honourable members will be interested in it. City slickers nearly pinched the tree at Barcaldine under which, it is said, the Australian Labour Party was formed. It is said that shearers used to be chained to that tree. When these city slickers went there the plaque disappeared. I do not know whether it was the Marlon Brando from Bradfield who pinched the plaque. On the following morning there was evidence that they had tried to pinch the tree as well. With all due respect to the honourable member for Bradfield, I think it would be quite some time since he rode a motor cycle and since he visited the inland. If what I say is untrue, perhaps we might have some kind of test tomorrow outside Parliament House with a motor cycle. May I mention that we have ceased using smoke signals out in my area.
Only a few months ago the honourable member for Griffith (Mr Donald Cameron) came up to the rugged frontier town of

Mt Isa on a fact finding mission and of course while there he visited the air-conditioned bar of the Barkly Hotel. I hope certain people who may use this information at some future date are not present in the House. However, the honourable member enjoyed meeting the rugged, so-called hard faced people that we have in these areas and as I said, it was very difficult to get him to return to his electorate of Griffith. He enjoyed some of this socalled lack of hospitality.

Quite seriously, we now find the most modern air-conditioned motels throughout inland Queensland and the Northern Territory. We also find caravan parks. They are all new, so they have the most modern equipment. The honourable member for Griffith saw much of these facilities. So I must refute decisively the implication in the speech of the honourable member for Bradfield that all we have in this area are old broken down pubs in which a person finds hard faced people who greet him and then touch him. I told you why they were hard faced, Mr Acting Speaker.

It is interesting to note, as I said earlier, that a survey in the United States of America revealed that the two most outstanding attractions for tourists in Australia are the Great Barrier Reef and what the inland has to offer. This can be verified quite easily. Only recently, about sixteen miles from Cloncurry - that beautiful rugged town which effuses hospitality and friendliness - there was discovered what is called a bourie camp. In other words, various rocks with hand paintings were found. The art of Aboriginal painting ceased about 600 years ago but the craft of etching ceased about 1,000 years ago. It is interesting to visualise an Aboriginal male saying to a female Aboriginal: 'Come and see my etchings'.

Tourists arriving at Cloncurry now may go on planned safaris. Honourable members know how rugged these are. We have big boxes in which the food is carried. Recently we asked a journalist who visited Cloncurry to come on one of these safaris. We said: 'We hope you like damper and corned meat'. He said he would come. When we arrived at our destination and opened the box he was quite shocked. We had a little refrigerated bar with lemonade and orange juice, tonic water and so on. In the lower hatch we had chicken and other delicacies. This was right out in the middle of nowhere. Honourable members will see that we now enjoy modern amenities. The point is that tourists can come across from New York to Sydney and see the same old thing all over again. Honourable members know that this is so, particularly if they saw the 'Four Corners' programme a few weeks ago. That programme indicated what was being offered in Sydney. Tourists from overseas can see the same old transportation facilities. But in the cities they do not see what they will find in the inland of Queensland, the Northern Territory. Western Australia and other interior parts of this great nation. There they will see something that is quite different. There they can get a beautiful piece of steak - not the sort of thing one gets here.
Mr J.R. Fraser- Flies?
Mr KATTER- Listen to the honourable member talking about flies. What about Canberra?
Mr ACTINGSPEAKER-Order! 1 suggest that the honourable member for Kennedy be permitted to make his own speech without assistance.

Mr KATTER- Thank you, Mr Acting Speaker. I appreciate that. What is handed up to you in Sydney as a steak, for the small cost of about $2.75, is not a steak at all. I think it is a piece of the saddle. I am not kidding about this. Honourable members should compare the steak they get in Sydney, for about $2.75, with the delicious steak one can get out in my part of the world, served with asparagus and celery by a charming person, for about $1.25. This is the sort of thing tourists would like. It would make them happy and they would go home delighted.

I conclude by saying to the honourable member for Bradfield and his very good friend the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Wentworth), who is now planning to visit the various areas, that when he comes back to my area he will observe what has happened since his last visit. If the honourable member for Mackellar proposes to make a trip to the north, perhaps he will confer with the honourable member for Bradfield, and perhaps the honourable member for Bradfield will forsake his motor bike and hop into a Boeing 727 which will take him to Mount Isa. He will be staggered at what has happened since 1954.

Mr CHIPP(Higinbotham- Minister for the Navy and Minister in Charge of Tourist Activities) [8.39] - in reply - As the Minister in charge of this Bill I must say that I have been very pleased with the quality of the debate and the amount of interest which the Bill has evoked from honourable members on both sides of the House. So many members have spoken, and have spoken so well and constructively, that I believe that the report of the debate will be useful and will be a challenge to the Australian Tourist Commission when it is formed, and to the Commissioners, whoever they might be. By reading this second reading debate they will know of the constructive interest that has been taken in this subject by honourable members of the Commonwealth Parliament. Some of the matters that have been raised have been provocative and interesting. The honourable member for Evans (Dr Mackay) and the honourable member for Kingston (Miss Brownbill) spoke of attracting conventions to Australia. Before I go any further T must join with other honourable members in complimenting the honourable member for Kingston on her maiden speech. This matter of conventions is one about which 1 am particularly keen. Let me describe two techniques for attracting tourists to the country as the rifle technique and the shotgun technique. Using the shotgun technique we can spend thousands of dollars by advertising in expensive magazines in the hope of attracting tourists of all classes from all over the world. But if we can attract to this country a convention, in one fell swoop, using the rifle technique, we can attract perhaps 1,000 delegates and 1,000 wives. And there are hundreds of conventions held throughout the world every year.

Many other suggestions were forthcoming during the debate. What excited me as much as anything was the way in which Australian members of Parliament, representing the Australian electorate, eulogised the tourist attractions of this country. For so long we have admitted to ourselves that

Australians are a race of knockers; that we knock our virtues and attractions. Anybody listening to the debate and hearing honourable members eulogise our great tourist attractions, ranging from the Great Barrier Reef to the centre of Australia, to our magnificent snow fields and to our beautiful coastlines which are the equal of anything in the world could be forgiven for coming to the conclusion that we have ceased to be a race of knockers. All of the suggestions that have been made in the course of the debate will be examined in detail by the Tourist Commission when it takes office.

In a very good speech the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren) referred to the Elizabeth Farm Cottage. I confess that I had known little of this matter before the honourable member raised it. As I understand the honourable member, this was the first farm built and operated in Australia. It is situated at Parramatta. The honourable member said that the building is now to be auctioned. If I could again express a personal view, which I think would be shared by most honourable members, let me say that we in Australia as citizens have not yet developed the consciousness to preserve our historic and traditional assets such as the classic one referred to by the honourable member for Reid. In fact, in the past we have bordered on the sacrilegious in the way in which we have allowed these assets to be destroyed, defaced and converted by private enterprise as a price for progress. I am happy to tell the honourable member that this matter has been referred to the Commonwealth Government and is currently under consideration.

Might I make a plea to the many benevolent, beneficent and wealthy people of the city of Sydney: if the Commonwealth Government cannot see its way clear to intrude into this field of purchasing or assisting some form of national trust to purchase Elizabeth Farm Cottage it would be a great tragedy for our traditional history if this monument to our development were purchased by private enterprise, demolished and lost to us forever. If I could I would use my office and the forms of the House, with the assistance of our friends of the Press, to make an appeal to public minded citizens of Sydney to see whether some thing could be done to preserve for posterity Elizabeth Farm Cottage.

Some of the proposals advanced in the course of the debate involve broader government action. The honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Turner) referred to the provision of finance to equip ourselves to meet satisfactorily the inrush of tourists which we hopefully expect will come within the next few years. The honourable member for Flinders (Mr Lynch) and other honourable members advocated an extension of income tax incentives for the overseas promotion of tourism. May I say a few words on each proposal. In leading for the Opposition the honourable member for Dawson (Dr Patterson) referred to internal facilities and said: lt does not appear to give consideration to aspects of tourism inside Australia . . . That is the main criticism we have of the Bill. 1 remind the honourable member for Dawson and other honourable members that we are a Federal Parliament. In Australia we have six State governments with sovereign rights. The internal facilities of this country are the responsibility of State governments, local government authorities and the private sectors of the tourist industry. Already there has been a tremendous improvement in this regard, although I confess that much remains to be done. I can say with some feeling, having played a part in the organisation of Melbourne for the 1956 Olympic Games, that one year before the Games one could have said that Australia had not grown up to meet the challenge of overseas tourists. I speak candidly of my own city of Melbourne and 1 suspect that the same observations would have applied in respect of Sydney and other capital cities. Steak and eggs was the staple fare in any restaurant that one cared to enter. Restaurants of world class were very scarce. Hotels at that time did a guest a favour or appeared to be doing him a favour if they accommodated him. A comfortable motel of first class standard in country areas was a phenomenon thai aroused surprise. But ten years later the response of the private sector and the public sector to this challenge has been phenomenal. They had responded to the demand. It would be our hope as a Federal

Government, with the co-ordination and cooperation of the Australian Tourist Commission, that private enterprise on the one hand and the government and public sector on the other will meet the demand which we hope we will provide.

As a Federal Government we expect the Australian Tourist Commission, in its early days at least, to perform one function and to perform it very well; that is, to treble the number of tourists who come to Australia in the next ten years. If we accept this as a minimum target and let the Commission know that it is our minimum target, I am sure that private enterprise, State governments and local government bodies will meet the demand. We as a Federal Government realise that by stimulating this demand we will encourage further approaches to us for additional finance. I sympathise with State governments for the position in which they may find themselves because I realise that an increase in tourists will mean an increase in demand tor roads, electricity and other facilities. I suggest that any need for finance which they may have in order to develop their tourist facilities must be reflected in their overall approach to the Commonwealth through the Premiers Conference and the Australian Loan Council rather than going through the back door for handouts or special grants for tourist purposes.

As to the matter of tax incentives raised by the honourable member for Flinders, I can assure him that it is at present under consideration by the Government. I give him a further undertaking that a decision on the extension of income tax incentives to people engaged in genuine tourist promotion will be made by the Government in the near future.

Some of the broader issues relating to State governments were raised by the honourable member for Evans and the honourable member for Riverina (Mr Armstrong). Both of them advocated the establishment of national trusts and national parks. I believe that there are very few members of this House who would not be in sympathy with the sentiments expressed by these two honourable members. I have often wondered about these terms 'national trust' and 'national park'. They are really misnomers because in fact such institutions are State trusts and State parks. But if we are to keep pace with other countries and preserve the heritage that our forefathers and nature have handed down to us, I believe we must attain a new level of thinking.

Let me now refer to some methods of increasing the tourist business in Australia. Many stimulating suggestions have been made by honourable members. The honourable member for Evans voiced the rather provocative thought that we might establish a duty free port at Alice Springs. I am still rather confounded as to how we could create a port at Alice Springs, but I agree that the honourable member's point is well made. The honourable member for Perth (Mr Chaney) made what I thought were a few quite stimulating remarks, on the face of them, about the irritation that would be felt by a visitor who comes to Australia by ship and calls first at the fine city of Perth. Throughout the voyage from the United Kingdom to Perth he has been able to purchase cigarettes and gifts and the ordinary necessities of life free of customs charges, but after leaving Perth he is informed that for some mystical reason he must now pay considerably more for these commodities during the voyage from Perth to Melbourne or to Sydney.

The honourable member for Wills (Mr Bryant) suggested reduced entry formalities. This is a matter which, of course, involves the Department of Immigration. I am happy to tell the house that my friend and colleague, the Minister for Immigration (Mr Snedden) has already written to me saying that all possible facilities will be made available by him and his Department to try to alleviate any real irritation that is being caused by present entry formalities. But the matters that have been raised by the honourable member for Perth and the honourable member for Wills are not without their problems. This is an area in which I would hope that the new Australian National Travel Association may prove of invaluable service to this Parliament and to the country. The matter of waiving duty on certain items, which was raised by the honourable member for Perth, involves certain problems, as I think the honourable member would be the first to acknowledge. It will not be the task of the Commission to go into this sort of thing, but we would envisage that a sub-committee consisting of a small group of experts from the ANTA might allocate itself the task of looking into this problem very carefully and making recommendations to the Government or to the appropriate Minister. We know that the present members of the Australian National Travel Association are very busy men, as will be those who will become members of the Association in the future. We would not expect them to form a sub-committee, write their own minutes and call their own meetings or - and this would be more important - to carry out their own research. We would plan for the provision of a service officer, a research officer, for the various and, I hope, many sub-committees of the ANTA which might be formed for the special investigation of specific problems such as the one I have mentioned.

Let me now refer briefly to a matter raised by the honourable member for Wills. He was rather critical of the existing visa requirements as they affect tourists coming into Australia. At present these requirements do enable the great majority of genuine tourists to obtain visas without annoying delays or formalities. Delays have occurred mainly when the officers who issue visas have had reason to question whether a visitor's real intention was a tourist visit or permanent settlement in Australia. We should retain our sense of perspective in this matter of relaxing visa requirements. More than tourists and tourism are involved in this situation, as I hope to show.

It will be realised that if Australia were to drop the visa requirements for all who claim to be visitors, as many European countries, I concede, have done, then very many people unable to obtain migrant visas would travel as tourists and having arrived here would refuse to leave. This is an unpleasant thought that I intrude into the debate, but I think honourable members are realistic enough to concede that this could happen. It did in fact happen in Canada, as is clear from a White Paper presented to the Canadian House of Commons a few months ago. The United States of America, like Australia, has been unwilling to allow this kind of uncontrolled entry. In other words, the countries most attractive to migrants - Australia, Canada, the United States of America, to mention a few - are in a very different position from that of the densely populated nations of the old world. Retention of the visa requirements also enables Australia to refrain from irritating controls on the visitor when he visits Australia. The tourist in Australia does not have to hand in his passport when he registers at a hotel, as the tourist in Europe does. Honourable members who have travelled in Europe will understand the frustration and irritation that I have experienced on finding that the first thing I must do when arriving at an hotel in some of the old world countries is to hand in my passport for police examination. This, of course, does ont happen here. We do not compel the Australian hotelkeeper to do this, and I hope that we never will.

In recent months the Department of Immigration has made a comprehensive review of all visa requirements for intending visitors. This has been done in specific recognition that the flow of tourists to Australia will increase and must be encouraged. Special attention has been paid to requirements which have caused complaints in the past. Considerable streamlining of certain requirements and of the form of applications is already seen to be possible, and the Minister for Immigration has recently authorised the issue of the necessary instructions. These will be issued in the immediate future.

I now turn to some particular aspects of the Bill and deal with them in more detail. The honourable member for Dawson was at pains to admonish the Government - and I thank him for this - to select the best men available in Australia as members of the Australian Tourist Commission. He said - and I think these were his words: Surely we should get the four best men available in addition to the member from the Department of Trade and Industry'. I give this House my personal assurance, as I did in my second reading speech, that the men appointed to this Commission will be, in our judgment, the best men available to perform this extraordinarily important task.

I pause here to say that I was disappointed by one remark made by the honourable member for Dawson. I have already paid him a tribute and thanked him for one point that he made. When one of my colleagues in this quarter of the House was making the point today that the best men should be appointed, the honourable member for Dawson interjected and said: As long as they do not come from Sydney or Melbourne, or as long as some of them come from Queensland'. I can give him a written guarantee now, if he wants it, that parochial considerations will not influence me or, I feel sure, the Minister in charge of this Bill, the Minister for Trade and Industry (Mr McEwen), or the Government in determining the men or women who will be appointed Commissioners. We are playing for very big stakes. We have adopted the principle of a small commission. Surely the point has been made and it does not matter whether the men or women come from Western Australia, Queensland, Tasmania or anywhere else, they must be the best available from the point of view of experience, dynamism and knowledge of the industry. One thing I can guarantee the House is that all States will not be represented on the Commission, for that is an arithmetical impossibility. The honourable member for Dawson (Dr Patterson) was genuinely concerned with the provisions ot clause 12 of the measure, which provide that a commissioner who has a vested interest must disclose that interest and refrain from voting. I do not blame the honourable member for slightly misunderstanding the complex wording of the Bill, but I assure him that the terms of sub-clause (4) of clause 12 are consistent with the wording in many other similar Bills that constitute commissions. Explaining this sub-clause as best I can in plain, non-legal language, if the Commission enters into a contract with a company and a voting member of the Commission is a member of the company, and the company has fewer than twenty-five shareholders, the member concerned must do two things. First, he must disclose his interest, and will not then be permitted to vote or take part in the deliberations. This is a natural and usual provision for the declaration of interest that is found in many places. However, I should hope - and I expect that it would be done through prudencethat any commissioner who is a member or a director of a public company would have a sense of propriety and would refrain from voting in respect of any contract the Commission might seek to enter into in respect of his company. I have confidence in the good taste of men and women of the calibre of those who will be sought for this job. I need hardly say that such men and women would, as an act of propriety, abstain from voting on any issue directly involving their ordinary affairs.

In conclusion, I thank the House and the honourable members who have spoken for the way in which they have commended this measure. I thank honourable members for the complimentary remarks that have been made in respect of my own efforts in this matter, and give the House the additional assurance that in performance the Australian Tourist Commission will not disappoint any member of the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative
Bill read a second time.
In Committee
Clauses 1 to 5 - by leave - taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 6(1.) The Commission shall consist of five voting members and two non-voting members.
Mr WENTWORTH(Mackellar) [9.5]- I move:
In sub-clause (1.), omit 'two', insert 'four*.

My amendment is designed to allow two members of this Parliament to act as nonvoting members of the Commission. The drafting of my amendment, which has been circulated, has been done by the Parliamentary Draftsman and is in accordance with the general provisions in this regard contained in the National Library Act. I did not intend to move this amendment until 1 heard the debate in this chamber and I realised that the measure was being treated in a non-party manner. I realised also that worthwhile opinions were being expressed by honourable members on both sides of the House. Therefore, I thought it was desirable that members of our Parliament should be associated with this Commission in a non-voting capacity. I take this view partly because I believe that members of this House - as they have shown during the second reading debate, and this has been acknowledged by the Minister - have something to contribute. After all, we are representatives of the people of Australia and the tourists who come to us are also, funnily enough, men and women. Perhaps members of Parliament have something to contribute which the experts may not always appreciate.

I am not proposing that the members of Parliament should be voting members of the Commission; I propose that they be non-voting members. If honourable members look at the National Library Act they will see that we appoint a member of the Senate and a member of the House of Representatives to act on the National Library Committee, which is a similar body to the one we are at present considering. By a convention, which I am sure would be observed, one member would come from the Opposition and one member from the Government. For example, I can recall that only a few days ago we elected the honourable member for Wills (Mr Bryant) who is a member of the Opposition as our representative on the National Library Committee. It would certainly be envisaged that if we were to elect two people as nonvoting members to this Commission, we would elect one from the Opposition and one from the Government just as we have done in the past. This has been done through no legislative necessity to do so but by force of a convention, which I am sure would be honoured, such as with the National Library Committee and the Australian National University. I believe it is inappropriate for members of this House to be represented upon commissions or councils where political issues are involved or are likely to come to the fore, because whatever we may hope or believe to the contrary there is not a really bi-partisan policy on many matters dealt with in the House. However, where there is a bipartisan policy, as with the Australian Tourist Commission, the National Library and the Australian National University - where party politics do not enter into it - I believe very sincerely that this Parliament should be represented. We denigrate ourselves if we do not believe that we have the capacity to fulfil a function such as this. I have been told that this is a matter for experts and that members of this Parliament can have nothing to contribute. This is poisonous nonsense.
Mr Chipp- Who told the honourable member that?
Mr WENTWORTH-I have been told by honourable members of this House, and I believe by other people, too.
Mr Chipp- Do not misrepresent them.

Mr WENTWORTH-I believe that members of this Parliament have something to contribute and have a right to participate in the functions of government where non-party matters are involved. This involves the dignity of this Parliament. If we want to write ourselves off entirely as rubber stamps we will contract out of proposals of this character. However, if we believe in the reality of the parliamentary institution, acknowledging as we must the dictates of party loyalties in matters where party policy is involved, we should see that we participate in the government of this country. We should not be rubber stamps for the Executive. I know there are some people associated with the civil service who think that the Parliament is nothing, that the Government is everything, and that the Government should be the mouthpiece of experts and civil servants. I am not of that opinion. I believe that this Parliament still has some functions, and I believe also that this is one of the cases in which the Opposition can contribute something to the government of this country without involving itself or the Government in party politics. Some members have said that it would be inappropriate to increase the number of members of the Commission from seven to nine. Really, that is nonsense. The two non-voting members would not be able - and I do not think they should be able - to control the votes and decisions of the Commission. I believe that they, as ordinary people, could give the opinions of the man in the street. No man is better qualified to do this than a member of this Parliament. I am confident that the non-voting members would be able to contribute something of value to the work of the Commission. Indeed, since the Commission will be largely dependent on this Parliament for funds to discharge its functions, I believe they would be of assistance in reporting back to this Parliament, thus allowing it to participate as it should in a matter of this character.
I put my submissions from two standpoints. First, I put it that this is one of the proper functions of this Parliament. If we are not prepared to do here what we have done in the case of the National

Library and the Australian National University, then we are running away from our responsibilities as members of Parliament and are denigrating ourselves. Heaven knows, we were very strong a day or two ago against a member of the Parliament who had denigrated us. Do not let us fall into the same sort of trap and denigrate ourselves. Furthermore, I believe that two members of this Parliament, chosen from opposite sides, could and would be able to add something of value to the work of the Commission. The Commission will consist of experts. That is fair enough, but experts, though involved in research, also deal with men and women. In the matter of public relations, no group of people is more skilled than the members of this chamber. At any rate, let us have some idea of our own dignity and worth. Let us not denigrate ourselves, but let us see that there is proper liaison between the Commission in its non-political character and the members of this chamber. Finally, I refer to the tenor of the debate, about which the Minister spoke so generously. Honourable members, speaking off the cuff, had a great deal to contribute to the debate. From the way they spoke, they would make ideal members of the Commission.

Mr UREN(Reid) [9.14]- I support the spirit of the sentiments expressed by the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Wentworth), and in particular the view that members of the Parliament, one from the Senate and one from the House of Representatives, sitting on this Commission would make a worthwhile contribution to its work. The honourable member said that they would be non-voting members. One cannot complain about that. After all, I think they would add strength to the Australian Tourist Commission. I disagree, however, on another aspect. The honourable member for Mackellar seems to have drawn an incorrect inference from the tenor of the debate at the second reading stage and the fact that members on both sides gave some praise to the Minister and the Government for bringing forward this legislation. He said that there had been a bi-partisan approach to the matter of tourism. I cannot accept that proposition in the terms expressed by the honourable member for Mackellar. We on this side want the public sector to have more say in the composition of the Australian Tourist Commission and to play a bigger part generally in tourism than the Government would have it play. We have said that we support this legislation. That is because it is a step in the right direction.

Since 1929 a voluntary or semi-voluntary concern, the Australian National Travel Association, has been supreme in tourist affairs in Australia. Over the years it has received in excess of $Sm in subsidy from the Federal Government. The Commonwealth has contributed 70% of the Association's finances in the past few years. Now, even that body has decided that tourism is getting too big for part time voluntary organisations. It is now necessary for the Government and public institutions to enter the field of tourism. I point out that from 1950 to 1966 Australia has suffered a deficit of $634m on tourist activities. As an example of socialist undertakings I refer to Qantas Empire Airways Ltd, which has received contributions from this Government and has made about $19m profit over the last ten years.
The DEPUTY CHAIRMAN (Hon. W. C. Haworth) - Order! I remind the honourable member that we are discussing clause 6 of the Bill.

Mr UREN- Mr Deputy Chairman, I am aware that we are discussing clause 6. The honourable member for Mackellar put forward the amendment that a member of the House of Representatives and a member of the Senate should be appointed to the Australian Tourist Commission as non-voting members. In support of his amendment he advanced the argument that in regard to tourism there was no difference between the attitude of the Government and that of the Opposition. I point out to the Committee that this is not entirely a non-party affair. We support the Government when it comes forward in a progressive manner, but we say it has taken too long to enter the field of tourism. However, we are grateful for the crumbs that have fallen from the table. We ask that the public sector be given a greater say in the affairs of the Tourist Commission. We have already said that not only in Sydney but also in every capital city and in provincial cities throughout Australia, there should be hotels like the

Wentworth Hotel run by Qantas Empire Airways Ltd. Surely this is not a case of both parties being on common ground. We on this side want to see a growing interest in the public sector. We believe that entry of the public sector into tourism will result in better and more efficient tourist services in Australia. We have pointed out the frustration that has been caused by the Government's holding back the development and establishment of the new Wentworth Hotel in Chifley Square, Sydney. That venture was frustrated by members of the Government. We are not in agreement with the Government on this issue. We criticise the Government for restraining Qantas Empire Airways Ltd.
The DEPUTY CHAIRMAN - Order! 1 hope the honourable member will connect his remarks with the constitution of the Commission.

Mr. UREN- I shall link my remarks with the amendment moved by the honourable member for Mackellar who, in moving the amendment, argued on the premise that we were non-partisan in the matter of tourism. I repeat that we support the Government in the positive and progressive attitude it has adopted in introducing this measure, but I emphasise that we are not in entire agreement in the matter of tourism generally. I believe the Chair was very lenient with the honourable member for Mackellar. I have been called to order twice and have been asked to link my remarks with this clause. But at no time was the honourable member called to order for not speaking to it. I repeat that we believe the tourist industry should expand and that the expansion must come from the initiative of the public sector. We already have Qantas Empire Airways Ltd, which operates overseas, and we need a shipping line that operates overseas. Surely that is not a non-partisan suggestion. Has any honourable member on the Government side suggested that an overseas shipping line be established? We have said before that tourists from overseas have their first experience of Australian hospitality when they board aircraft used by Qantas Empire Airways. If we had an overseas shipping line, passengers boarding its ships overseas would then have their first experience of Australian hospitality. It is in this way that we want the public sector to move further into the tourist industry.

I agree in spirit with the amendment moved by the honourable member for Mackellar. I think honourable members on the Government side of the chamber must agree that we on this side sincerely wish to see the tourist industry in Australia grow. But surely the honourable member for Mackellar will agree that last year, although we received S58m from tourism, we spent $122m overseas, leaving a deficit of §64m. It has taken a long time for the Government to move positively to encourage the tourist industry and surely we on this side of the chamber are entitled to mention this. We believe that tourism cannot be left to the private sector. We as parliamentarians acting in the best interests of Australia want the public sector to be more active in tourism. In many instances the public sector may have to work in co-operation with the private sector if the best' interests of Australia and our tourist industry are to be served, lt may be that a divergence of opinions between parliamentarians who are members of the Australian Tourist Commission, one from the Government and one from the Opposition, may be stimulating. Therefore in spirit I support the amendment. I confine my agreement to agreement in spirit because, after all, I am bound by the decisions of my Party. If a division is called on the amendment I will vote with my Party. The honourable member for Dawson (Dr Patterson), who led for the Opposition in the second reading debate, will decide this matter and we will support him unanimously. Therefore, I support the amendment only in spirit and if a VO It' is taken I may not be able to vote with the honourable member for Mackellar. My Party has decided to support the Government on this issue and I do not think at this late stage we should divide the Committee on it.

Dr PATTERSON(Dawson) [9.24]- I wish to speak briefly to clause 6 of the Bill. The Minister for the Navy (Mr Chipp) has agreed that the five most capable people should be chosen to form the Commission. One of the voting members must be an officer of the Commonwealth Public Service and the Minister has already said that this public servant will come from tha

Department of Trade and Industry. The Opposition has no objection to any of the provisions of clause 6. It could easily be that all five voting members of the Commission will come from the Public Service. Perhaps the Minister will define more precisely what is meant by 'a body or association that is representative of the industries in Australia connected with tourism'. This is an extremely wide wording and could almost embrace everyone from the ranger at Ayers Rock to one of the top representatives of a tourist organisation.

About 90% of the debate on the Bill has been related to Australia's tourist attractions for people overseas. However, it is recognised that no good purpose is served in bringing tourists to Australia unless we can make them happy. As I said, about 90% of the debate related to tourist attractions, principally with the outback and the Great Barrier Reef, and with some of our other attractions thrown in for good measure. There can be no question that the outback and the Great Barrier Reef are two of the finest attractions that we have and two of the finest tourist attractions in the world.
Mr Stokes- Read the amendment.

Dr PATTERSON-I am speaking to clause 6 of the Bill. I hope the Minister, when he is selecting the voting members mentioned in clause 6 (3.), will give some thought to the types of attractions that will be promoted overseas. He said that it is quite possible that the five members will come from Melbourne or from Sydney. I hope that this will not be so and that the members will be selected from all parts of the Commonwealth. I find it hard to believe that no Western Australian or Queenslander would be capable of serving on the Commission. Nevertheless, we respect the Minister's sincerity and believe that he will do all he can to select the five most competent people for this work.

Mr CHIPP(Higinbotham - Minister for the Navy and Minister in Charge of Tourist Activities) [9.28]- If I may, I will first deal with the point raised by the honourable member for Dawson (Dr Patterson). He referred to clause 6 (3.) of the Bill and asked what bodies would be approved to provide representatives of the industries in Australia connected with tourism. I thought I had made this point clear in my second reading speech. Two of the voting members shall be nominated by a body or association that is approved by the Minister as being representative of the industries in Australia connected with tourism. At this stage we regard the Australian National Travel Association as being the body meeting this requirement. I am sure the honourable member will agree that this is the body that should nominate two of the voting members.

The Government does not accept the amendment moved by the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Wentworth). One never expects the honourable member to bring forward a thought that is not provocative, original or stimulating, and he has not let us down tonight. He talked about the denegation of the House if we as members of the Parliament did not stick up for our rights and join in committees like this Commission. This is a most interesting piece of political philosophy, and on this point of political philosophy alone I should like to join issue with him.

I disagree vigorously with him that for members of Parliament to demand membership of bodies such as this is uplifting their status; it is possibly working in the reverse direction in respect of their status and responsibilities. I suggest to the honourable member for Mackellar that this Federal Parliament is the fountainhead of power in the Commonwealth and that each member of this Parliament is a symbol of power insofar as he represents an electorate. After having said that, for us to suggest that each of us should join as members in a position of equality with people that we, as a Parliament, appoint to decide matters on the fringe of fundamental Government policy, does not uplift the status of the member of Parliament but rather lowers it. Apart from that I cannot imagine that members of this Parliament would feel that their status, importance and position of power had been strengthened if members of the Parliament were members of the Australian Broadcasting Commission, the National Capital Development Commission, the Export Payments Insurance Corporation and a dozen or more other statutory corporations that we have.

Let me take this a stage further. I wonder what would happen to the performance, efficiency and objectivity of the Commission if two members of the Parliament sat on it, even as non-voting members. Let us not go into party politics. The honourable member for Mackellar suggests that one member from the House of Representatives and one from the Senate could join the Commission. Let us assume, for the sake of argument that one is a member of the Liberal Party and the other a member of the Labour Party. They will be two Federal members overlooking men whose appointment this Parliament has approved - men who are expert and who are trying to determine in all honesty and objectivity basic matters of tourist policy and tourist promotion policy. Indeed at least one public servant will be on the Commission. Does the honourable member suggest to me that the presence of two members of Parliament on the Commission will not embarrass that public servant? Does he suggest to me that two members of the Federal Parliament, which, as I have said, is the fountainhead of power in this community, as members of the Commission will not embarrass the objectivity of other members of the Commission?
Dr Patterson- The Minister could be on the Commission, and that would embarrass the other members of the Commission.

Mr CHIPP- The honourable member for Dawson makes an excellent point. The Minister could be on the Commission and this would suborn the objectivity and honesty of members of the Commission. If the honourable member for Mackellar is worried about the control that Parliament has over the Commission I remind him quickly of three clauses of the Bill. By clause 21 the moneys appropriated to the Commission are appropriated by Parliament. The Commission, by clause 25, must submit particulars of its proposed expenditure to the Minister. Under clause 29 (1) the Commission must report annually to the Minister on its financial statements and on its operations and the Minister must table these reports in this House within fifteen sitting days of their receipt. This is provided for in clause 29 (3). I believe that this Parliament has more than adequate control over the activities of the Commission. When the reports are tabled every member of the Parliament will have the opportunity to make his contributions, as he has had today. The honourable member for Mackellar would be the first to know that there is access, through ministerial channels, whereby each member of the Parliament can express his point of view about any aspect of the Commission. This Parliament has adequate control over the activities of the Commission, both, financial and otherwise. It would be an error of political judgment and of political philosophy for this Parliament ever to demand for its members the right to sit on statutory corporations appointed by the Government from time to time. For these reasons the Government rejects the amendment.

Mr WENTWORTH(Mackellar) [9.35]- 1 do not want to close the debate on the amendment if anyone else wishes to speak, but since no other honourable member has risen I shall exercise my right to do so. I do think that the Minister spoke a little without consideration a moment ago. He said: 'How terrible it would be for members of the Parliament to sit on a body such as this Commission', but he has forgotten that we elect members of this Parliament to sit on the Australian National University Council and on the National Library Council. If it is wrong to have a member of the Parliament on the Australian Tourist Commission why did we elect the honourable member for Willis (Mr Bryant) a few days ago to sit on the National Library Council? We do these things, and the Minister is talking nonsense when he says that it is a derogation from the dignity of this House.

Secondly, the Minister said that we are adequately protected because we vote money to the Commission and will get reports from it, but this frankly is nonsense. It is a mere matter of form to vote the money, because we cannot refuse the money without throwing the Government out of office, and no member on this side wants to throw the Government out of office. However, we are entitled to know a little bit more about the causes for which we are voting the money. The Minister spoke about the reports being submitted to us. This, as he knows, is entirely a matter of form, and it is deceiving the public and trying to deceive members of this House to pretend that it is anything else.

This House has lost its real authority, and it has lost its real authority because it gives everything to the Executive. I know that there are political matters where we must give to the Executive, and I am not quarrelling with that position. I do not want to weaken the Executive unnecessarily, but I believe that over the last twenty years the Executive has weakened this Parliament unnecessarily and it is time we started to stand up for some of our rights. The Minister referred to the presence of members of Parliament on the Commission.
Mr Turner-What about Qantas, TAA, the Egg Board, the Australian Broadcasting Commission or the National Capital Development Commission?

Mr WENTWORTH-The honourable member for Bradfield has mentioned several bodies. We should be represented on the National Capital Development Commission. I do not see why we are not represented on it, because it does not raise matters of party politics. Party politics are not involved in the National Capital Development Commission. Where party politics are involved I can see good reason for not having members of this Parliament as members of a council, commission or whatever it may be. The Minister claimed that we would embarrass public servants by having members of Parliament on the Australian Tourist Commission. I do not think that this is sense at all. There are public servants who sit on various bodies with Ministers. I instance the River Murray Commission or the Snowy Mountains Hydro-Electric Authority. After all, the Minister again says, we write down ourselves if we put members of this House on a level with people appointed by this House. What damn rot. The Ministers do this time and time again. What the Minister is doing is trying to deceive this House. He is trying to appropriate for the executive government, of which he is now a part, the privileges which should belong in part to this House. He has said things which are not factual. STATES GRANTS (TEACHERS COLLEGES) BILL 1967
Bill presented by Mr Freeth, and read a first time.
Second Reading
Mr FREETH(Forrest- Minister for Shipping and Transport) [9.47] - I move:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to put into effect the Government's promise to make unmatched grants to the States for the construction and equipping of colleges for the training of teachers throughout Australia. The Bill provides for expenditure of up to S24m spread over the three financial years starting in July 1967. Payments will be made to the States in respect of college projects which are selected by the States, to be erected on sites selected by the States and in accordance with plans and standards drawn up by the States and approved by the Minister for Education and Science. A schedule showing their projects is attached to the copy of this second reading speech which is circulated to honourable members.

The offer to the States has been made on two clear understandings. Firstly, the State undertakes not to reduce its own expenditure on teacher training. Secondly, at least 10% of the places made available as a result of the Government's offer are to be available for student teachers not bonded to the State Education Departments. This applies whether the places be new or replacement places and whether they are teaching places or places in residential accommodation. Winners of Commonwealth advanced education scholarships - or of university scholarships - will be able, if they wish, to apply their scholarships to courses at these colleges.

Commonwealth assistance in the construction of teachers colleges is regarded as of the highest priority by the States. This became clear from discussions during 1966 between my colleague, the Minister for Education and Science, and the State Ministers and Directors of Education. As a result, the Government included in its last policy speech the offer of capital grants, and subsequently, at the beginning of 1967, after further discussions, the Minister reached agreement in principle with each State on a programme of work within each State as part of a Commonwealth three-year S24m programme. Honourable members will be pleased to know that, because of the early attention given to these matters both by us and by the State governments, in at least one State tenders have already been called for one large project and in another State planning is almost to the same stage.

At this point 1 draw the attention of the House to the Schedule to the Bill, which gives a preliminary estimate of how the amount of $24m is to be distributed among the various States. I emphasise that, because the amounts estimated for each individual project are only estimates and because the actual annual rate of expenditure in any State is also only an estimate, the Bill gives the Minister power to vary the amounts both between individual projects in a State and between States. This is done to provide the flexibility which is necessary to ensure that individual colleges are built to the proper standards and to ensure that the money provided overall in any one year is used to the best advantage.

Similarly, because some States may take some time to develop their programmes the total amounts required in any one year may not be equal to the amounts required in another year. Therefore the Bill provides, not for $8m each year but for a limit of $8m in the first year, of $16m in the first two years and, of course, of $24m in the three-year period. Honourable members will note that the Bill requires the Minister to table in the Parliament each year a statement showing the amounts he authorised for all projects in the various States in the past year.

I now give the House a brief statement of the projects to be developed with these grants in each State. In New South Wales two new teachers colleges will be built, one at Chatswood and one at Shortland. In addition to providing new places, these colleges will provide up to date facilities to replace existing facilities at Balmain and Newcastle respectively. In the country, the first stage of a new college with residential facilities will be built at Goulburn. In Victoria, projects include a new secondary teachers college, a new technical teachers college and other projects to be selected by the Victorian Government from the list of projects in the schedule which I have circulated to honourable members.

In Queensland, additions will be built at the Kelvin Grove Teachers College, a new college will be built at Mount Gravatt, and $200,000 is available for site development works at the Ross River site in Townsville should it be required. In South Australia, a new Northern Teachers College will be built on a site near Elizabeth, and there are other projects yet to be selected by the South Australian Government. In Western Australia, a secondary teachers college will be built at Nedlands. In Tasmania, a teachers college will be built at Launceston.

We believe that these grants will enable the States to provide new places and to replace out of date places in teachers colleges a good deal earlier than they could ever hope to do from their own resources, and we further believe that the grants will accelerate the introduction of a three year training course for primary school teachers, which is a widely expressed hope among Australian educationists. When this Bill becomes law, capital expenditure during the 1967-69 triennium on universities, colleges of advanced education, and teachers colleges will be at least $68m a year, of which the Commonwealth will provide $41m a year. I commend the Bill to the House.
