HOMES SAVINGS GRANT BILL 1967
Second Reading
Debate resumed from 6 April (vide page 999), on motion by Mr Bury: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Mr CONNOR(Cunningham) [10.18] - The Opposition does not oppose this Bill but will offer certain criticisms in accordance with the forms of the House regarding some very notable omissions, particularly the failure of the Government to continue to recognise savings within a credit union as qualifying for a grant under the legislation and the failure of the Government to curb certain excesses or rectify errors of the Secretary of the Department of Housing in respect of the valuation of homes. The arbitrary assessment of home values has given rise to grievances.

This Bill is designed to bring within the scope of the homes savings grant legislation widows under 36 years of age with at least one dependent child, and to increase from $14,000 to $15,000 the limit of the value of a home that may qualify for a grant. The remedies proposed represent one more stage in the patchwork pattern of legislation resulting from the election promises of the former Prime Minister, Sir Robert Menzies, in 1963, designed to secure the votes of a particular group of home seekers. In fact the legislation could be called 'Operation Cover-Up', being intended to remedy some of the worst bureacratic excesses, which cost this Government the votes of many disgruntled applicants.

The 1965-66 report showed that up to the end of June 1966 only 88% of applications had been approved. The Minister stated that some 74,000 couples had already received grants totalling more than $33m. The average grant since the inception of the scheme has been approximately $450. The problem faced by the former Minister for Housing has undoubtedly been a complex one, namely to extract the maximum political advantage from a sweepingly generalised dragnet and at the same time to supply a justifiable set of definitions that would qualify the most eager applicants, without excessive cost to the Government - and I stress 'without excessive cost'.

In his 1964 speech in this House the then Minister for Housing (Mr Bury) said that housing was vital to the welfare and happiness of individuals and to our future development as a nation. He then went so far as to say that without proper housing the processes of marriage and family formation which are the very essence of Australia's future development would be seriously impared. He qualified his statement by saying that in housing we shall always fall short of the ideal. Having delivered these most laudible sentiments the Minister then lapsed into his Party's inner view of political realities when he said: 'The

Government has become particularly concerned with the difficulties facing home seekers in raising sufficient funds for a deposit large enough to meet the requirements of lending institutions.' I mention these facts because they provide the background to the Bill and the Government's motivation. The Minister continued:

The causes of the situation are complex, but two factors are worthy of particular notice - the rising price of land, especially in the vicinity of our capital cities, and the availability of funds from lending institutions. There is little the Government can do about the price of land, which must bear the cost of development - these are State matters. The availability of funds is also highly critical and is subject to Commonwealth influence. Basically in a fully employed economy additional resources can only be devoted to housing if less are applied elsewhere. Overcoming any housing shortage, therefore, entails some diversion of funds from other uses to housing finance

Then came the Minister's apologia. He said: 1 ask the House for a wide measure of administrative discretion until the scheme settles down. It will be readily recalled by honourable members that the procedures under our social services legislation - those most closely akin to these - have been refined by practical experience of fifty years.

Are we to have as an annual feature of this legislation a stream of empirical amendments? Already the legislation has produced the most complex application form in the history of public administration in this Commonwealth, and our congratulations must surely go to the hardy grantees who have been survivors in the bureaucratic obstacle race. As to the Minister's prognosis of fifty years of remedial legislation, the next Federal election will decide that issue. In the meantime Australian development will continue to be grievously retarded by the absence of a national housing plan. No assessment of Australia's present housing needs has been or could be made by this Government, whose political philosophy has regarded economic planning and long term development as 'non-words', as witness its treatment of the Vernon Committee's Report. Australia was held up to ridicule recently at the conference of the Economic Commission for Asia and the Far East in Tokyo, when the leader of the Australian delegation said that Australia had no formal machinery for national economic planning and that no single administrative body had responsibility for making operational forecasts and long term proposals. There is no industry more important, no issue more basic and no problem more pressing than housing in Australia today. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Whitlam) said in an address delivered recently:

The Australian paradox in housing is that the authority which accepts the greatest responsibility for raising and allocating funds in this field does not accept a parallel responsibility for planning the use of those funds. There has been no thoroughgoing review -of Australia's housing needs and likely trends since 1945, prior to the introduction of the Commonwealth and State Housing Agreement. We have a situation where the Commonwealth is in a position to regulate as much as 90% of housing finance in Australia today, yet it takes no responsibility for the cost of the land and of the house itself. Housing has become an instrument of general economic policy rather than part of a planned and relatively predictable programme. In the absence of a planned programme slum reclamation is retarded and costly ugly suburban sprawl continues unchecked.

To the Minister's credit he did say in August 1965: 'To damp down housing because of undue expansion in other sectors of the economy may distort our ultimate priorities for survival.' In contrast, the present Prime Minister (Mr Harold Holt), in a letter to the President of the Housing Industry Association last October, said:

It still remains our firm view that the task of forecasting housing demand and performance over a period of years is not one for the Government to undertake. In an economy where home building is overwhelmingly the function of private enterprise the Commonwealth, although it may indirectly influence the level of home building, is not in a position to make overall plans to ensure that they will be carried out.

In contrast to this, in the United States the Federal Government shows greater interest and discharges greater responsibilities in housing and urban re-development. The financial relationship between the State and Commonwealth governments has been revolutionised, and the former tax reimbursement formulae and supplementary grants have been replaced by a system of direct grants under section 96 of the Commonwealth Constitution which, as is well known, gives the Commonwealth power to attach such terms and conditions as it thinks fit to any such grants. In this way and through the Commonwealth and State Housing Agreement the Federal Government can lay down a complete pattern of housing development, slum clearance, urban re-development, and reduce and control land prices by direct resumption by the States. Land so acquired can be developed and sold at cost. If profit is to be gained the benefit should accrue to the community through the Government and not to the land speculator. The whole purpose of this legislation, apart from its political motivation, has been to bridge the deposit gap caused by inflated land values due to the speculation boom in the postwar period, which this Government has persisted in refusing to control.

The amendments outlined are in the main ad hoc, and the original Act resembles an old boot which has been patched and clouted so that little of the original leather in the uppers remains. There has been a housing shortage in Australia ever since the first fleet arrived in Port Jackson. The question may fairly be asked whether this legislation has actually helped or whether the Bill before us will help young people and widows to acquire homes in the absence of control over land prices and while building costs continue to soar. Against those who have benefited by the Bill, as claimed by the Minister, may be considered those who have not benefited because of their exclusion. In fact the legislation was carefully designed by the age limit that has been imposed to exclude all World War II exservicemen from any benefits. The Government still adamantly refuses to recognise credit union savings as being acceptable.

It applies the same principles to exclude friendly societies, and discriminates against the lower income groups who are purchasing housing commission homes. Among those who can never hope to benefit from the scheme are the 800,000 hidden people in Australia - the age, invalid and widow pensioners, the recipients of sickness and unemployment benefits, and migrants living in Commonwealth hostels who can never hope to save a downpayment for a home after paying the increased hostel charges from their low wages in heavy industry.

The most grievously injured group of all are the pensioners who, since 1956, have been deprived of any Commonwealth assistance in the construction of low rental housing commission flats following their elimination from the terms of the agreement. Add to these the 200,000 married men who receive less than $40 a week taxable income - men whom the building societies will not accept even if they could, by their sacrifices, save $500 a year for the three years required under the legislation. Apart from the grievances of those people who can never hope to save, how far have the young savers themselves been hurt? A report of the Directorof the War Service Homes Division is most interesting. His report for the year ended 30th June 1966 contains a statement that in the two years since the introduction of the legislation the average cost of a dwelling house and home has increased by the following amounts: New South Wales $1,026; Victoria $515; Queensland $542; South Australia $1,738, and Tasmania, $1,437. That was in a period of two years, and the average increase per home throughout Australia from 1963-64 to 1965-66 has been $741 - almost $300 more than the average grant.
Mr Stokes- That was mostly labour costs.

Mr CONNOR-We shall come to that in a moment. I thought the honourable member would fall into the booby trap. Over $100m have been paid in price rises, and only S33m for grants. The Australian Capital Territory has been an exception, with a reduction associated probably with the reduced price paid at leasehold auctions. The aggregate increase in the cost of all dwelling houses and land in Australia from May 1964 to now has been over $!00m. The much vaunted grant of $33m under the terms of this scheme is paltry and pitiful by comparison. I shall quote from a report on the development of Australia by the world famous Stanford University Research Institute - 'Think Tank' as I believe the Americans term it. This was circulated to all members in 1964, and at page 235 states:

One important factor that limits both the capacity and the incentive for many people, particularly young married people, to save is the extraordinarily high cost of housing construction and purchasing. Interest rates running up to 8% on first mortgage and more on second mortgage represent a serious deterrent to home ownership. There is in Australia no institution comparable to the State Advances Corporation in New Zealand, and housing finance is poorly organised. There is constant complaint that State housing programmes are inadequate. Private construction is expensive and often not safeguarded against inexperienced contractors. It is difficult to raise the funds necessary to build except by incurring a liability to the building contractor. Those who might become substantial and regular savers through the amortisation of payments on their own home are often discouraged and led to dissipate their own incomes in consumption expenditure.

When this Government assumed office in 1949 the Commonwealth Savings Bank was making housing loans at 31%; its current lending rate is 5% - an increase of Building societies are largely dependent on the savings banks for their funds and the maximum loan receivable is $7,000. Repayment of such a loan over a period of thirty years represents an additional payment for interest of about $1,250.

The borrower from one of the savings banks subsidiary to the general trading banks would pay, as the current 'Statistical Bulletin' of the Bureau of Census and Statistics shows, up to 5i% interest. Borrowings on this basis for a similar loan, with a period of repayment of thirty years, would result in an additional payment of about $2,000 for interest. In the 'Sydney Morning Herald' of 8th April is a reported cut by the United States Central Bank of its discount rate from 4i% to 4% on borrowings by banks, members of the Federal Reserve System. The Bank of Canada has announced a reduction of its bank rate from 5% to 4i%. Interest rates must be restored to those operating in 1949. Interest rates on housing loans and bank loans in Australia are much higher than they are overseas. The Government must accept full responsibility by its failure to modernise the Australian banking system with its rigid, inflexible, and archaic approach to the requirements of a modern age. Of the stability of the Australian banking system there cannot be the slightest doubt; the same applies to its inflexibility and lack of imagination. In 1953 the hire purchase companies successfully challenged the system of banking controls.

When denied further advances from the trading banks in discounting hire purchase agreements and associated negotiable paper, they decided to appeal directly to the investing public, and offered higher interest rates than those payable by the trading banks' on fixed deposits. From this has resulted a complete distortion of the Australian interest rate structure which the Government has not been prepared to control. The latest statistics disclose that total outstanding balances on hire purchase contracts in Australia are SI, 932m, and cheque paying bank total advances are $3,253m. There has now developed an alternative, or 'black market', banking system in Australia which remains completely outside the control of existing banking legislation despite the Commonwealth's clear constitutional powers of regulation and control. Institutions soliciting deposits at fixed rates of interest for fixed terms, and in certain cases allowing withdrawal on notice, are clearly carrying on the business of banking when they lend such deposits. Hire purchase companies have now progressed far beyond the financing of contracts of hiring of retail goods with an associated option of purchase. They are now, at exorbitant interest rates, moving over into first and second mortgage finance of housing and commercial and industrial construction, factoring, the provision of bridging finance, and the financing of contracts for the purchasing of land, in addition to assisting land sub-dividers.

Acting on the principle that if you cannot beat them then join them, the major private trading banks of this country at present either fully own or have a major controlling interests in hire purchase companies, now euphemistically terming themselves 'finance companies'. In many cases the profits from such companies are forming the major part of the associated banking companies' profits. Having failed almost completely to establish their own hire purchase divisions within their normal banking functions, most of our trading banks until very recently almost completely shunned personal loans. Their evaluation of requests for assistance have been dominated by the concept of freehold security and related improvements, and they have largely ignored cash flows as alternative security in propositions relating to the development of Australia's mineral and other associated resources.

The structure of Australian interest rates is, at the present time, geared to and dominated by those offered by hire purchase company borrowings. The obvious solution is for a separate classification to be created, under the Commonwealth banking legislation, licensing such organisations and subjecting them to the full discipline of Reserve Bank controls. There is a close association between the benevolence of the Government to the hire purchase racketeers, and their antagonism to credit unions and friendly societies. Until recently an honest man of good character and with a steady job applying to certain of the trading banks for a personal loan would be steered to its hire purchase subsidiary where greater interest could be extorted. The obvious threats to excessive interest charges and inflated retail mark-ups on consumer durable goods by a working man walking into a retail store with cash in his pocket provided by a credit union and demanding a cash discount are horrifying to this Government. The excesses of hire purchase finance obviously bred the popularity of the credit unions as a counter to them, and it is for this reason, not the availability of housing finance through credit unions, which has influenced the Government in its rigid policy. The recent Reserve Bank policy statement on personal loans is obviously intended as a counter to credit union activities. The growth of credit unions is alarming this Government. In the Commonwealth Bank there is a credit union with more than 9,000 officers participating. The general trading bank officers are in the process of forming one also. In the Australian Broadcasting Commission there are six credit unions with a total membership of 6,000. In the Taxation Branch of most States there are credit unions. In my own constituency, the Port Kembla steelworks has a credit union with 7,000 members and $1,400,000 in deposits.

I come to perhaps the most significant fact of all. Deposits in credit unions rose from $12m in 1962 and now total $80m, $40m of which is held by New South Wales credit unions. It is significant that they are strongest in New South Wales, where their growth was first stimulated and encouraged by a Labor Administration. The Government's arguments as to the percentage of credit union funds available for housing are merely specious humbug. Instalments paid on contracts for the purchase of land have been properly recognised as acceptable savings since the inception of this legislation. Are we to believe that instalments paid to land speculators in this way are readily available through accumulation in savings banks and building societies for relending to intending home builders? The discrimination against credit unions is outrageous when land purchase contracts are acceptable. Total current Commonwealth Savings Bank loans for home building represent 24.1% of total deposits held. I obtained those figures a fortnight ago. Under present policy, the maximum which can be advanced by the Bank for home building purposes is 35% of total deposits. At the present time 30% of all credit union funds are lent for housing purposes, such as the discharge of second mortgages, part purchase of land, alterations and extensions to existing home accommodation, bridging finance, deposit assistance to migrants and also first mortgage finance up to a sevenyear limit.

Credit unions function in New South Wales under the same Act of Parliament as do co-operative building societies, namely, the Co-operation Community Settlement and Credit Act of 1923. There is no legal distinction between these two types of organisations. They come under the control of the same Registrar, have their accounts subjected to the same audit and general supervision, and their rules are approved and registered in the same manner. The Government obviously views credit unions in the same way as Conservative Administrations throughout the world have opposed and crushed any attempt by wage and salary earners to enter into the business of banking and credit. Credit unions in fact represent the little people's banks. Behind the scenes the Government wishes to channel every dollar into the control of the people who are its political supporters and whose pressures are applied shrewdly and persistently. In no country in the English speaking world are higher interest rates being paid for public credit than in Australia. The entire credit system and interest charges are a disgrace to this Government. The average family in Australia today is paying S2.50 per week in retail profits and interest charges on money borrowed to purchase such essentials to modern living as refrigerators, washing machines, television sets and the whole range of electric household appliances. In addition there are the excess interest payments on home mortgages to which I have already referred. This Government will naturally do its utmost to destroy any move to help the wage and salary earner to rise above the level at which he can be exploited by the Government's associates and supporters.
Credit unions have expanded almost miraculously in size and speed in North

America. In the United States credit unions are accepted by the Housing and Homes Finance Agency. If given the opportunity for legitimate development and growth, credit unions will grow into a formidable alternative to the less desirable sectors of our present credit structure, and the case for their recognition is unanswerable. The total number of members investing and borrowing in credit unions in Australia today is over 200,000, of whom 100,000 are in New South Wales, and it is to these people that the Government will answer for ils arrogance and hostility. It is interesting to note that of the total number of 2,838 co-operative building societies in .1963-64 more than 1,951 were registered in New South Wales. This is further evidence of the foresight of a Labor Administration. At no stage in the former Prime Minister's policy speech was reference made to the question of mobilising savings of applicants in institutions of the Government's choice. This has been the gravamen of repeated rejections by Ministers for Housing of representations from credit unions for recognition.

The valuable role of permanent building societies has been largely ignored by the Government. In the United Kingdom they are one of the major credit sources for home construction at relatively low interest rates. A similar development in the United States has been the growth of housing banks. The limitations imposed by the trading banks and co-operative building societies in financing the purchase of older homes has also seriously prejudiced young home seekers, many of whom have been forced to purchase a new home at a higher price in an outer suburb when their real preference would have been for the purchase of a sound but less pretentious home at a much lower price in an inner area more accessible to public transport and employment. Permanent building societies can discharge a valuable function in this field.

The former Minister for Housing, who is now the Minister for Labour and National Service, was not able to achieve a most valuable suggestion made by him to reduce housing costs. Over three years ago he said that the complex building regulations in Australia added $500 to the cost of each new house. With over 900 local government authorities in Australia, the range and variety of building codes is amazing. The proper initiative is obviously to call together the various State Ministers for Housing and Local Government to achieve a rational modern building code with due allowance for the varying climatic zones of this continent.

Housing costs have been further inflated by the utter failure of the Government to deal with the problems of urban redevelopment. The inner heart of our capital cities, and even of major provincial cities, is being deserted by former residents. Increased land values and associated council rate rises have been a major contributing factor. The obvious answer is high density inner urban development. In the heart of each Australian city is a completely adequate system of sewerage, water supply, drainage, electricity, telephone and public transport. With the exodus of lower income groups to the supposedly cheaper land of the outer suburban areas, costly public utilities are being left unused and public transport problems intensified. Metropolitan Sydney is only 70% sewered, although sewerage main capacity exists for 3£m people in a city of lim. The unregulated urban sprawl provides a further demand for public utilities. It has been estimated that the cost of providing these is $3,200 for the average outer suburban block. A survey by the Cumberland County Council in the area of Sydney some years ago showed that the average time spent daily travelling to and from work from the outer suburbs of Sydney was from 2i to 3 hours

If any supporter of the Government - I say this to the honourable member for Maribyrnong (Mr Stokes) who, I understand, will follow me - rushes to its defence and claims that increased wages for building workers have been a major factor in increasing costs, the complete answer is contained in statistics of unimproved land values in Sydney and other Australian capital cities. In 1954 the unimproved capital value of the Sydney metropolis and the associated City of the Blue Mountains was $952m. By 1959 the value had increased by 120% to $l,920m. The trend has continued and the latest unimproved capital value for 1966 is $4,38 lm, an increase of 360%. In the same period the average wage and salary earnings in New South Wales rose from $33 to $58.60, an increase of 75%. The price of suburban land, in contradistinction, increased by four and a half times as much as wages. The wholesale prices of building materials in the comparative period increased by only some 30%.

Today we have a government faced with capital investment curbs imposed by both the United States of America and the United Kingdom. We have the Minister for Trade and Industry (Mr McEwen) hotfooting it overseas now to see what he can save from the Kennedy Round proposals. What is the position in Australia? How underpopulated is Sydney? Greater London has an area of 693 square miles and a population of more than 8 million. New York, with 299 square miles, or less than half the area of Greater London, has a population of 11.3 million. Sydney has an area of 500 square miles and a population of 2.3 million. In other words, the density of population in Sydney is out of all proportion to the area. The national advantage in terms of the capital cost of servicing public utilities that will be saved by a swing to higher density housing will be substantial, the public transport system better patronised and the peak hour rush to outer suburbs reduced. More than half the lives of the average married couple, is spent either with no children or after their families have been reared. A more logical pattern of housing would be for the outer suburbs with the larger homes and living areas to be made available to meet the needs of young couples for the rearing of their families and for the middle-aged and childless couples to move into the higher density residential areas of redevelopment in major cities.

Let me summarise in this way: The homes savings grant is a completely ineffective method of coping with inflated land values. In pre-war home finance, land value represented only 10% to 12% of the total cost of the house and site. As a result of the speculative boom, it has now risen to 30%. lust as the present Government has continued to increase its contribution to medical benefit funds without controlling doctors' fees so it is prepared to pay an ineffective subsidy towards inflation of land costs. Recently a conference of Commonwealth and State Ministers for Housing was held

In Perth. This highlighted the present limitations on Australian housing development. Despite the assurances of the present Commonwealth Minister for Housing, with special reference to the homes savings grant, the State Ministers for Housing resolved unanimously that additional money from the Commonwealth was urgently needed to build permanent homes for migrants, in addition to the moneys available under normal agreements. The Premier of Western Australia, Mr Brand, said that unless substantial help came from the Federal Government Australia would be faced with grave social problems as a result of the lack of housing, despite the claims of record home completions.

The conference dealt with housing of low income groups, including widows, deserted wives and the aged, the needs of migration, the problem of the second mortgage and the maintenance of an adequate flow of finance. The Victorian Minister for Housing said that housing for the aged and the clearing of slums were projects towards which the Commonwealth now gave nothing but should give specific help. Mr Brand went further and said that with a falling off of war service home applications the Federal Government should provide additional finance for housing to equal the flow of war service homes finance at its peak. All States had felt the pressure of demand for lower rental homes and criticised the stop-go methods of financing housing. Regular consultation between the States and the Commonwealth to plan future demand and promote stability in the industry were also specifically requested.

A major defect in the present legislation is the unfettered discretionary power conferred on the Secretary of the Department. He has the power to reject applications for grants which in his opinion are for homes exceeding in value the limits contained in the Act. This is one of the most blatant escape hatches in the legislation and, in operation, can be used to relieve the Commonwealth of any obligation to pay grants in respect of all homes which can be said to be in excess of the statutory limit. I have had many complaints from bitterly disappointed and irate applicants on this issue. The injustice is felt most keenly by industrious persons who have, to reduce expense, done part of the construction work on their own homes. In such cases they have been deliberately penalised for their industry and thrift. Provision of arbitral machinery in cases of disputed valuation has been carefully debated. In most States the statutory valuing authority should be called in to adjudicate on the basis of the statute prevailing in the State.

May I say this in conclusion. In Australia today young people who marry and have a family not merely give hostages to fortune but face the near certainty that they have by their decision almost destroyed the possibility of home ownership. In simple terms they face the choice of either having a family or a home; they cannot have both. Whilst the immigration scheme must continue, the best of all immigrants is still the child born to parents in an Australian home. The average young couple today who consciously decide to limit their family and delay the birth of their first child do so mainly so that both can take employment and can amass the necessary savings to qualify under this legislation. They still face the near certainty that annually increased costs of houses and land will be equal to their annual savings. They are the poorer in the lack of a family and its joys, and Australia is the poorer for the retarding of its population growth.

Mr STOKES(Maribyrnong) [10.58]- We have just listened to the diatribe of a dedicated Socialist, the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr Connor). He has led for the Opposition in the debate on this Bill, which amends the Homes Savings Grant Act, and in doing so he has roamed over the whole field of housing and banking. He has demanded controls, licences and the discipline of banking and the building industry, with rigid, long term planning in the true Socialist manner. I can understand why he claimed that the home savings grant scheme was nothing more than an election gimmick. This grant, which was introduced by the Government, has always stuck in the craw of Opposition members. They did their very best when the promise of the grant was made during an election campaign to prevent its introduction. They said: This is unconstitutional. You cannot do this.' But when they examined it they discovered on a very good authority that marriage loans and loans of this sort were quite within the terms of the Constitution. Who was that eminent authority? None other than a former Leader of the Opposition, their own Dr Evatt. They have been chagrined ever since that this measure was brought in by the Government, and they have sought constantly to throw muck at it.

The honourable member spoke about credit unions. He knows that despite the size of some credit unions the bulk of their business is directed to activities related to the purchase of consumer goods except that in the housing field assistance is given by way of part deposit for the purchase of land, in providing small second mortgages, and in enabling an additional room to be built or an extension or a garage to be added to a property. This cannot be considered as true home ownership moneys invested for that purpose, and the honourable member knows that full well. He spoke also about nothing being done for people who could not buy their homes, namely, widows and pensioners. He even mentioned Second War people. The War Service Homes Division exists to help exservicemen, and for those who do not want to purchase homes but who seek low rental accommodation funds are made available to the States under the Commonwealth and State Housing Agreement to build this type of accommodation.

I do not intend to cover the whole field of housing. The Bill before us amends the Homes Savings Grant Act, and I want particularly to speak to it. This measure, as the Minister for Labour and National Service (Mr Bury) said, gives effect to promises made by the Prime Minister (Mr Harold Holt) prior to the last election. However, as the Minister said, these amendments go far beyond the original promises, because the Government, in a commonsense way, has decided to adjust a new and unique piece of legislation as experience has indicated the necessity to do so. When the original Act was being discussed some of my colleagues and I voiced the opinion that lack of discretion would cause difficulties in borderline cases, but at that time the Government was not disposed to widen a strict interpretation of the legislation. It is now pleasing to note that a provision in this Bill proposes that the head of the

Department of Housing ls to be given new discretionary powers which will operate retrospectively from the date of commencement of the scheme - from 2nd December 1963. This discretion is vested in the departmental head, but the Minister is responsible for the direction of his administration and therefore the Minister also is able to exercise these powers.

The Government and the Minister are to be commended, too, for the announcement that after the passage of this legislation it is intended to distribute a new brochure which will clearly set out the operations of the Act as finally amended. Some matters are rather contentious and complex, and I want to try to clarify some points before the brochure is issued. It is proposed to increase the value of the home to be purchased from $14,000 to $15,000. This needs no further comment. However, I wish particularly to refer to the extension of the grant to either widowed spouse aged less than thirty-six years with one or more dependent children. Under the legislation this provision will apply on or after 28th November 1966 provided the widowed person has saved for at least three years immediately preceding the prescribed date, which is the date of the contract to purchase. It is important here to stress that not only will the savings of the deceased spouse that were held in an acceptable form prior to death be taken into account in establishing the widowed person's eligibility, but also any other moneys or interest that may be bequeathed to the other will be accepted if it is placed in an acceptable form or converted into acceptable savings on or before 31st December 1967 or a date on which the applicant contracts to buy or build a home, whichever date is the earlier.

Another matter of concern is that difficulties were experienced where the effective date of the contract to purchase had been misconstrued as the actual date appearing in the contract, which was the date on which the purchaser signed the contract. Actually the legal effective date of the contract to purchase is the date on which the two parts, one signed by the vendor and one signed by the purchaser, are exchanged, irrespective of the fact that it may be dated with the date the purchaser signed it a week or two earlier; and of course this date is a very important date. This is the date which acts as the cut off; it cuts off the savings period and it also originates the period within which an application must be lodged

Under the amendment no change is intended in the way in which the prescribed date will be fixed. It will continue to be fixed as at present, and the general eligibility requirements regarding age and residence will need to be fulfilled at the prescribed date. The purpose of this amendment, which is clause 14 (d) of the Bill, is to enable the Department to accept certificates from the banks or from the building societies if they are made out for a period of three years up to a prescribed date, lt does not have to be the exact date as settled by the contract. There will be a period of grace of fourteen days before or after the prescribed date so that there will not be the inconvenience of sending back to the banks and building societies requests for fresh certificates to be issued every time there is a disparity between the finishing date of the certificate as to savings and the actual prescribed date under the contract.

As I have said, another matter originates from this particular amendment, and that concerns the time limit for the lodgment of an application. As we know, this period is being extended by the amendment before us to twelve months, and after that a discretion is given to the departmental head in very unusual circumstances. For the benefit of those who may wish to know something more about this, Mr Deputy Speaker, I should like to stress that they should not take this twelve months period as giving them a right to sit down and forget about it for twelve months, because if they run over the period they may well find that their case is not one of unusual circumstances and that they will miss the boat. Therefore, 1 can only stress to all applicants that they should lodge their applications as soon as possible after their contract is signed and so not run the risk of being left out because their particular case is not one for discretion.

It is also very well worth while considering in this regard that the Government has undertaken to reconsider all applications previously rejected because they were lodged later than the permissible time, and that these cases will now be processed by the Department without the need for the lodging of any further application. However, I must stress again that there are some people who did not submit applications because somebody at the counter in the Department, their banker, or somebody else said to them: 'Look, you are out of time; you are wasting your time putting it in'. These people must be alerted to the fact that they may lodge a fresh application which will be treated as having effect from the commencement of the scheme on 2nd December 1963.

One requirement for eligibility in the original scheme was that neither of the couple may have owned another dwelling during their marriage, whether or not they had occupied it or regarded it as their matrimonial home. As a result of this condition of eligibility some people have been disqualified from obtaining the grant. 1 refer to people who, perhaps, have bought a home for their aged parents or who have been left a property by parents or some other relative. Although the premises may have been unsuitable for their purpose or subject to a long standing tenancy agreement, they were regarded as owning the premises. The amending Bill will empower the Department to disregard ownership of another dwelling house where it would be unreasonable to regard that house as the matrimonial home. I believe that this is quite a step forward. if we bear in mind the proposal to disregard a house which is unsuitable as a matrimonial home and consider also the amendment which extends eligibility to a widowed spouse, raised in our minds is the question of what happens to divorced persons. This is a point which has not been discussed, but it is one on which 1 should like to dwell for a moment. 1 sought advice from the Minister on this point and was told that if either or both of the couple, prior to their divorce, had been made a grant in respect of the home owned during the first marriage, both would be ineligible for a second grant in respect of the later marriage. However, the new spouse of each of the divorced persons may be eligible if the divorced spouse has not retained ownership of the previous home and another home is acquired during the second marriage, provided of course that the new spouse meets all requirements of the schemIf neither of the couple, prior to the divorce, had been made a grant in respect of the first home and that home had been sold after the divorce, both could be eligible persons if they were to re-marry and another home was acquired during their second marriage.

Ownership of another dwelling house precludes payment of a grant only if that dwelling house has been owned by one or both of the couple during the marriage in respect of which the person is applying for a grant, but if one of the couple, after the divorce, retains ownership of the matrimonial home of that couple and then remarries, no grant would be payable in respect of that home during the second marriage. The scheme is intended to assist young couples to acquire a home and in this case the couple would already have a home. Nor would a grant be payable in respect of a second home acquired by the new couple if the divorced member of the couple retained ownership of the first home until after he or she remarried.

A further amendment which is proposed will allow the acceptance of savings in either name, where both parties to the marriage are under thirty-six years of age at the prescribed date and are eligible in all other respects. An exception is when one or both of them have not saved individually for the minimum period of three years immediately preceding the prescribed date. In these circumstances the savings of both members of the couple will be taken into consideration in determining the amount of grant payable, provided that together they have saved for three years or more. For example, the wife may have saved for up to eighteen months or two years before the prescribed date and then may have started to spend her money on items for her glory box and so would not be saving so much. On the other hand, the husband, having become engaged, may have decided to save and perhaps saved for the eighteen months or the two years immediately preceding the prescribed date. So, there are two sets of savings in individual names, but they aggregate over three years and will therefore be counted as eligible savings.

Mr Devine- They have to be in special accounts. :. Mr STOKES - They have to be in a home savings or similar account. Further, where both parties have saved in individual accounts for a total of three years, those two accounts will now be aggregated so that a larger grant will be attracted than at present. The provisions that cover the matters I have just raised are to operate on and after 1st May 1967.

It is pleasing to note that the original requirement in respect of the certificates issued by banks and building societies covering seven years of prior saving is to be discontinued and that it is intended that this detailed information will be restricted to the three years before the prescribed date. When the original legislation was introduced many of us wondered why the seven-year period was included. We are now very pleased that this commonsense amendment has been introduced, as it will greatly simplify application forms and save a great deal of work for banks and building societies.

Another amendment to the legislation is the introduction of a minimum limit to the grant. This may seem a trifle incongruous, particularly as the minimum limit has been set at SIO, but applications have been made for a home savings grant where the payment has amounted to only 60c or so. Another amendment introduced by this Bill relates to a break in the savings period: It provides that any break not exceeding thirty days in the savings period will be disregarded should there be good and sufficient reasons for the break, such as the transfer of savings from one place or institution to another. The expressed intention is that, where a savings date falls within such a break, the amount of savings acceptable at that date will be the amount held immediately before or after the break, whichever is the lesser. Although usually when people transfer an account from one place or institution to another through the normal banking channels the same amount is deposited as was drawn, some people like to draw the money from the first institution in cash or by a cheque which they can cash. Sometimes they spend some of the money and deposit a smaller amount when opening a new account at a bank or when paying money into another society. Others may have a win at the races and within thirty days be able to pay into the account they are opening at the second institution a greater amount than was withdrawn from the first. The amendment provides that in either case the amount to bc taken into consideration will be the lesser amount.

There are a number of other amendments that will possibly be covered by colleagues who will follow me in this debate. I commend the Government and the Minister for their willingness to introduce this measure and the speed with which it was introduced to deal with matters that were found to be contrary to the original expressed intention of the scheme. Despite what the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr Connor) has said about a miserly $33m, it is interesting to note that since the commencement of operations by the Department under this scheme, from 20th July 1964 until 7th April 1967 only 7,584 applications were rejected out of a total of 87,411. Many of these will come within the scope of this new legislation. Already S33.685m has been paid out in respect of 75,061 applications. To the beginning of last month the Department had in hand over 4.000 applications in process or in query.

I should like to refer also to another minor amendment. It relates to the admission of savings held in banks in the Territory of Nauru. The addition of the Territory of Nauru completes the list of external territories which were covered originally by section 4(5.) of the principal Act. The Government thus illustrates that it is prepared to accept savings with banks in all our external territories.

This brings me to a proposal I should like to advance. I should like the scheme to be extended to intending migrants, provided they can fulfil all the other conditions laid down as to age, the period of saving and the form of savings, together with the provision that savings, when transferred to this country, are transferred to an acceptable account and are accompanied by a certificate from the overseas bank as to the period of saving. There could even be a provision that, say the last twelve months of the saving period must be spent in this country. There is no doubt in my mind that this not only would provide a great fillip to our immigration programme, which 1 think is sorely needed, but would also assist migrants to purchase their own homes earlier than would otherwise be possible, thus reducing the time families would spend in hostels.

It may be argued - 1 take it the Minister would so argue - that this cuts across one of the purposes of the original legislation, namely, the creation of special savings in the hands of approved institutions which would increase the funds they would be able to lend in the housing field. As against that, 1 would say that the savings transferred from overseas, having been saved there for a couple of years, would be greater than savings held by people just starting an account. What is more, they would be available to the approved institutions, banks, etc.. for at least twelve months for lending out. 1 believe that many intending migrants would not bother to save before coming to Australia unless they were given the incentive to do so and were told that if they had saved for a couple of years before migrating they would be able to obtain the Government's grant after a further period of twelve months. I believe this is a worthwhile incentive to offer. I know it would be necessary to vary some of the present conditions, such as the condition relating to the three year residential period and in some cases the required period of three years as an Australian citizen. I do not think these difficulties are insurmountable, particularly as in recent times more than 50% of migrants have come from the United Kingdom.

I ask the Minister for Labour and National Service to have a look at this question in collaboration with his colleagues, the Minister for Immigration (Mr Snedden) and the Minister for Housing (Senator Dame Annabelle Rankin) and determine whether such a scheme is feasible and whether it can be introduced at some time in the future. I can speak with a great deal of pride and sense of satisfaction of the Government's actions in improving this very worthwhile piece of legislation, the Homes Savings Grant Act. I strongly commend this amending Bill to honourable members.
Mr HANSEN(Wide Bay) [11.25]- The Bill before the House represents the second series of amendments to the Homes Savings

Grant Act which was introduced in 1964 by the Minister for Labour and National Service (Mr Bury) who was then Minister for Housing. When introducing the first of the amending Bills in March 1965 the Minister said that during the time the Act had been in operation the Government had studied the method of operation of this legislation and the means by which people saved for their first home. He said at that time that the amendments would do much to make more persons eligible for grants under this legislation and would result in freer implementation of the Act

The honourable member for Maribyrnong (Mr Stokes) would remember that on that occasion a number of members from this side of the House proposed that widowed persons should also be eligible for homes savings grants. If my memory is correct, when the former honourable member for Hughes, Mr Johnson, was speaking during that debate, the honourable member for Maribyrnong said that widows were a bad financial risk for the sale of homes. I am pleased to see a change in this respect, particularly with regard to widows rather than widowers. A widow, following the loss of the breadwinner, is usually more in need of a home and if she qualifies in other respects I believe she should not be denied this opportunity. I do know of cases where this has happened. Some of the amendments contained in this Bill will date back to the original date of operation of Che Act, which was immediately following the 1963 general election. But the particular amendment I am referring to, relating to eligibility, is not retrospective to that date, so these people to whom I have referred do not qualify in this instance. Still it is pleasing to know that money will now be made available to them.

Quite a number of amendments are being made in this Bill. One of them will increase the limit of acceptable savings for each year from $500 to $600. Honourable members know that money is losing its purchasing value. Perhaps there has been some increase in the earning capacity of some people. Whilst it may be commendable, this Bill will most assist those people who are in the least need of assistance to purchase their first home. There are people who find it easy to save $500 in a year. But there are other people, such as a person in his first year as a qualified tradesman who, at the age of 20, becomes engaged. Statistics concerning marriage show that couples marry at a younger age each year. So if that young tradesman follows Che usual pattern he will have very little time in which to save for a home from the time at which he first receives tradesmen's wages to the date of his marriage. He will be very fortunate if he and his fiancee can save $500 a year.

The purchase of a home involves much more than just the purchase of a piece of land and a dwelling on it. Furniture, kitchen utensils and many other items have to be bought. This cost has to be met from savings. In the operation of this legislation a great deal depends on the prescribed date. If a person draws money out of his account before the prescribed date he finds that his eligible savings are reduced. I have warned young couples to watch how their bank accounts go before they sign a contract. If someone who is building his own home makes a large withdrawal to meet the cost of building materials and the prescribed date is the date on which the foundations went down, he finds that his eligible savings have been reduced. It is quite a complicated matter. I do not blame anyone who has been misled. I think the Minister for Housing (Senator Dame Annabelle Rankin) has acknowledged that some people have been misled in making their applications and eventually have found themselves outside the previous period of three months. That period has now been extended. People will be able to make fresh applications. That is an indication of the problems that arise.

The honourable member for Maribyrnong mentioned the encouragement given to migrants to save for the purchase of a home and the need to recognise the savings that they make. This is quite commendable in itself. But it does not follow the line of thinking of the Minister for Labour and National Service. He does not consider that any savings should be eligible unless while they were in the bank they were being used for the purpose of home construction. I do not believe that enough of the money that is in the savings banks is made available for the building of homes. If we follow the line of thinking introduced by the honourable member for Maribyrnong, why should we give migrants a privilege that we are prepared to deny to Australians whose savings in credit unions are not recognised?

The honourable member for Cunningham (Mr Connor) dealt fully with the credit union movement in Australia. It has grown considerably and at a very fast rate. I believe that its growth has most of the previously recognised banking authorities worried. There may be something in the suggestion that the banking authorities do not want savings in credit unions to be recognised as eligible savings. The latest report that I have received on the credit union movement shows that Australia has 500 credit unions with approximately 200,000 subscribers and savings of more than $80m. One of the largest credit unions is the Commonwealth Bank officers credit union. Police unions, electricity commissions and the Australian Broadcasting Commission have credit unions. They all make available for the purchase of homes and items to go into homes and for extensions of homes, cheap money which would not be available from other sources. Instead of the young couple being forced to pay hire purchase interest rates of 8% or 10% flat on refrigerators and other essential items for their home they can obtain the money for these items at lower rates of interest from credit unions. The credit unions are doing a good job in helping young people to set up their own homes.

A home is something more than just a dwelling. The credit unions have helped young couples to bridge the deposit gap by providing second mortgage money. Formerly such money was available only for short terms at high rates of interest. In 1964 the Minister for Labour and National Service, who was then Minister for Housing, said that credit unions were excluded from the legislation because the maximum amount available at the time from a credit union by way of loan was only £1,000, which had to be repaid within five years. Many young couples trying to purchase their first home would be glad of a loan of $2,000 repayable over the five years to help bridge the deposit gap. Some credit unions have taken notice of what the Minister said in 1964. At least two of them - the Electricity Commission Employees Credit Union Ltd of New South Wales and the Irrigation Commission
Credit Union Co-operative of New South Wales - have amended their constitutions in order to increase the amount of loan available to $4,000.

Credit unions do encourage savings. The Minister for Labour and National Service and the present Minister for Housing both have stressed that the homes savings grant was introduced to encourage people to save. Because of their closeness to the people cred t unions do encourage savings. They encourage people to budget and to live within their wage, meagre as it may be. Credit unions encourage people to save for the various commitments which must be met throughout the year, such as rates. The credit union movement is growing. It has been suggested that a scheme be devised to grant concessions to migrants. This would be a worthy undertaking, but having regard to the Minister's attitude to credit unions qualifying under the legislation, I cannot see how such a scheme in respect of migrants could qualify.

The honourable member for Cunningham pointed out to the House that credit unions make money available for the purchase of items for the home and for bridging the deposit gap. While credit unions cannot make available all the funds required to purchase a home, they do something towards helping prospective home owners. For these reasons we believe that credit unions should be recognised for the purposes of this legislation.

The Bill proposes to increase the limit on annual savings from $500 to $600. Another amendment provides that savings need not be confined to those made during the three years immediately prior to the prescribed date. They may be for a three year period extending further back than the three years immediately prior to the prescribed date. This is a notable amendment because many young couples have drawn on their savings in order to place a deposit on land. Since 1965 money so spent has been recognised as savings. It could be that money saved in the last three years has been used to buy things for the glory box or to purchase necessities for the home, leaving little or no savings.

Reference was made to the eligibility of divorced persons compared with widowed persons. I remember the former honourable member for Eden-Monaro, Mr Allan Fraser, citing the case of Tommy Manville Mr Fraser pointed out that if Tommy Manville continued to marry women under thirty-six years of age, those women would qualify for the giant of $500. Tommy Manville had thirteen wives, I think, unless I am confusing him with someone else. If he lived in Australia, as long as he made sure they were young enough and he remained married to them long enough each would have been able to qualify for a home savings grant of $500. 1 believe that there are reasons why divorced persons should be assisted to finance the purchase or construction of a house. Close attention should bc given to this aspect of the scheme. lt is proposed also that savings in the Territory of Nauru will be included in the scheme. Can the Minister for Labour and National Service tell me what banks operate in the Territory? Must they of necessity bs of the same type as the banks that operate in Australia? lt is very difficult to get information about the form that savings would take in Nauru. 1 do not know what banks operate there. My information is that the Territory is very small. The Minister for Territories (Mr Barnes) may know how many Australians who are working there might qualify under this scheme and he may even be able to tell me what banks operate there. Are they Australian, English or New Zealand banks? If they are Australian banks would savings deposited in them qualify under the scheme? 1 hope to hear from the Minister for Labour and National Service about this.

A further proposal is that the minimum giant payable shall be $10. I suppose that this is a reasonable limit. 1 doubt whether many people would bother to make inquiries if, after going to all the trouble of making out their applications, they would not receive at least $10.

The Minister for Labour and National Service has promised that immediately this measure becomes law, and the principal Act is amended as provided for, a new information booklet will be printed and made available to the public. I suppose that there are many people who would like an opportunity to discuss these matters and inquire into them. When the original legis lation was before this House, the Minister who ,was then Minister for Housing, was very patient with members of my party and, I suppose, of his own party, in explaining the various provisions. Any ordinary person who picks up the existing explanatory booklet becomes further confused immediately he begins to read it, I believe. This applies not only to interested young couples but also to many bank managers. It is recognised that many people have been given misleading information about the homes savings grant scheme. I am sure that they have not been misinformed by members of this House, however. Any honourable member who is interested in the matter knows where to go to get the required information, even if he was not present to hear the debate on the original legislation. Honourable members recognise that some people have been misinformed about whether they are eligible. For this reason, I am pleased to see that persons who, since the origin of the scheme, lodged applications outside the permissible time limit or who failed to lodge applications because they had been wrongly informed that they were not eligible, are now to be treated as eligible.

This Bill will also empower the Department of Housing to disregard the ownership of a dwelling house in certain circumstances. We all recall that Mr Johnson, the former member for Hughes, brought this matter to to the attention of the Minister. He pointed out that because of a shortage of funds some people do not wish to borrow too great a sum or have difficulty in raising sufficient to go ahead with the construction of a home. Sometimes a person purchases land on which is situated an old house, the purchase being made not to occupy the old house but to acquire the land so that a new house may be built on it. The old dwelling on the land may have been condemned. In some instances, such purchases of old houses were made before the prescribed date immediately after the 1963 general election. The land with the condemned house on it having been purchased before the specified date, the people concerned have been reckoned ineligible for the grant. Even though the house had been condemned it was regarded as being a dwelling. The people were living there only temporarily while arranging for permits and contracts to have their permanent home built, and I suggest it would be unreasonable to regard the temporary dwelling house as being the matrimonial home or as being suitable for that purpose.

There is another suggestion that I should make to the Minister and I hope he will bear it in mind in preparing the new booklet. I refer to the single person who is contemplating marriage and who commences to build a home before his marriage. There is some doubt as to when such a person should apply for a grant. I have been asked whether the application should be made before the marriage takes place, and I have given the advice that a person is not eligible until he is married. I think other honourable members have had experience of cases of this kind and I think the new booklet should make clear the point of time at which an application should be made in these circumstances.

Another amendment included in this Bill is to increase the maximum value of a home in respect of which an application for a grant may be made from $14,000 to $15,000. There may be quite good reasons for this. I think one reason is the increase in the cost of homes, and another particular reason is the increase in the cost of land. I have a copy of the 'War Service Homes Report 1965-66' which shows that in New South Wales the cost of a dwelling increased by $87 and in Victoria by $287. In New South Wales the cost of a building block increased by $599, so that the total increase would exceed the amount of the grant.

When the original Bill was being discussed in this House the opinion was expressed by some honourable members that the grant would simply be another hand-out to real estate investors and land developers. As I have said, in New South Wales the cost of land increased by $599 in twelve months while the cost of the average home increased by $87. These are figures contained in the annual report of the Director of War Service Homes. We know that war service homes are not palatial homes by any means. They are ordinary family homes. In fact families of any size frequently find it necessary to build extensions on to these war service homes.

In Victoria, as I have said, the cost of a dwelling increased by $287 but the cost of land decreased by $41. In Queensland there was a decrease of $128 in the cost of a dwelling. I feel sure that this is a reflection of the condition of the building industry in that State. There is a shortage of work in the industry and contractors are undercutting one another. I am sure that the former Minister for Housing (Mr Bury) in his new capacity as Minister for Labour and National Service is well .aware of the extent of unemployment, especially among skilled tradesmen, in the building industry in Queensland. At the same time as there was a decrease in the cost of a dwelling in that State there was an increase of $650 in the cost of land. In South Australia there was an increase of $703 in the cost of a dwelling and a decrease of $13 in the cost of land. In Western Australia, the position was fairly static, the increase in the cost of a dwelling being only $14 while there was a decrease of $324 in the cost of land. Values must have reached their peak there at that period. In Tasmania there was an increase of $1,101 in the cost of a dwelling and of $422 in the cost of land. No figures have been given for the cost of land in the Australian Capital Territory, but the increase in the cost of a dwelling was $1,474. The average cost of a war service home in the Australian Capital Territory is $12,436.

The question has arisen as to how the value of these homes is to be assessed. I note from the Minister's second reading speech that the Housing Ministry will be given new discretionary powers in this matter. Hitherto, decisions on this point rested with the Director and he was allowed no discretion. I am pleased to see this provision included. I do not think it will be abused. I should like to mention the case of the person who is building his own home and who has been able to show that he has kept costs down to a certain figure. In most cases people in this group are connected with the building industry. Because they are able to buy materials cheaper than can the ordinary person, they can build a house for about $14,000 or $15,000. They can buy building materials such as hardware, gravel and bricks at concessional rates which help them to keep down the cost of the home. I do not disagree with the proposal in the Bill, but I believe that where people can show that they have been able to build for a comparatively low figure the fact that they have been able to buy their materials cheaper should be given due recognition. 1 suggest that experienced valuers employed by the various government departments be employed in assessing the value of homes. I point out that valuers employed by the Taxation Branch value properties for the Department of Social Services for the purpose of assessing a person's eligibility for social service benefits under the means test applicable to those benefits. The services of these officers could well be used to assess values under this legislation.

We welcome the proposed amendments even though we think that they are a little overdue. We are pleased to note that the Government is paying heed to what is being suggested by honourable members on this side of the chamber. Honourable members such as the former honourable member for Hughes who took part with me in a similar debate some time ago will be pleased to note that the suggestions which they put forward and which were included in the Government's policy speech at the last election are now being implemented. I have much pleasure in supporting the Bill.

Land Tenure in the Northern Territory - Dairying Industry Bill Debate
Motion (by Mr Bury) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

Mr CALDER(Northern Territory) [11.55] - Northern Territory land tenure proposals appear to be a genuine attempt by the Government to encourage economic development in the Northern Territory, with special reference to top end properties where soil and rainfall are suitable for improved pasture and agriculture. In the centre there are also some regions where soil and water of suitable quality and quantity may be found. Open range grazing as used in the north, with few exceptions, since the first settlers is not in the best interests of rapid development. Professor Elcock of the University of Montana in the United States of America, while visiting the Northern Territory property on which I was working, told us in 1950 that northern Australian grazing methods were seventy years behind the times. By this he was referring to open range grazing, bronchoing calves, cutting out on an open face with thousands of cattle on the camp, fire branding, ear marking with pliers and even knives, castrating with knives, dehorning with horn saws and even solid wooden sticks and droving cattle many hundreds of miles on the hoof. This was nearly twenty years ago. Some properties have progressed considerably since then, but many have not been in a position to effect improvements. Today, in the high rainfall areas especially, with the great developments in improved pastures, holdings can be smaller and station improvements much more sophisticated. Agriculture and farming becomes an economic possibility, but this sort of development requires big money. Whence does it come?

In the past Australians have been noticeably hesitant to take a gamble on this sort of investment. They will gamble on the horses, football and two-up, but they will not do so on important matters such as the original development of the Holden car, oil exploration in the real outback and land development in distant areas. I have experienced this reticence myself, especially in the last two cases I have mentioned, for I have lived in this country for many years and have seen the lack of faith in outback Australia, not entirely by the Government, as suggested by the headline-seeking honourable member for Dawson, but by the general public of Australia who live outside the northern areas.

Dealing with pastoral proposals specifically, in relatively short-term leases there has usually been a period of no development, or bare holding of the improvements, during the latter part of the lease. This is only natural if the owner senses that the property is to be reclaimed. To combat this it is proposed to introduce a system similar to the one now used in Western Australia whereby, when the lease has run for between twenty and forty years and the lessees have completed their original covenanted improvements, and wish to continue the lease and have worked out a new development programme, they may apply to convert to a new fifty-year lease. The area and new rentals would then be considered and the new lease worked out by the land board - not by the Minister or by the Administrator in Council but by three of six picked and impartial highly-experienced men.

The lessee must convert under this scheme to preserve the priority right to a new lease. This is fair enough, for by this time the lessee would have normally done a great deal of expensive improvements and be justified in expecting to hold his land against would be applicants with less original foresight, finance or experience than he had had twenty or forty years earlier. But it also means that lessees will really have to improve their properties or be faced with the grave danger of losing them. In many cases they will be able to raise additional finance for this by splitting their leases, and in some cases converting parts of them to agricultural leases of up to 200,000 acres, of which they themselves may own half. But these agricultural leases must be improved to such a standard that successful agricultural operations could be conducted on the subdivided blocks. Here the land board which had previously determined the size, rent and tenure of pastoral leases should once again be the determining body in the case of agricultural leases converted to freehold. If not, it could be done by the Administrator in Council before the final consent is given. Otherwise we may have agricultural land passing into foreign hands for lease in perpetuity at the rate of 200,000 acres at a time.

It is agreed that the financing of this part of the scheme may have to be carried by companies, both local and overseas owned. I am sure this will happen but, although we must expect these companies to receive a fair return for their initial outlay and the risk involved, we cannot afford to allow them to hold great tracts of this arable land in perpetuity. Either the size of the holdings must be diminished as the years go by, or it is limited at the outset, or the length of tenure with regard to companies both overseas and Australian must be limited or come up for review at regular intervals.

Increasing the Land Board to six members under these circumstances would be a good move for these members will not only have greater powers but also far more work to do. The honourable member for Dawson rushed to press to condemn these proposals, possibly only for political headlines, for he had apparently not really considered them from the practical landholder's point of view. Does the honourable member realise that these proposals, in part at least, emanated from the Committee of the Centralian Pastoralist Association long before Sir William Gunn had ownership of pastoral land in the Northern Territory, and that this Association is almost entirely comprised of private owners who run the properties themselves.

The honourable member stated that these proposals were made specifically to suit Sir William and his holdings in the Northern Territory, especially Tipperary. This is certainly not so. But if they or any other large company, either foreign or local, wish to get control of large areas of arable land in the Northern Territory, they should certainly have to convince the Land Board on which will sit six men of outstanding knowledge, experience and integrity and/or the Administrator in Council. Also, the land must be improved to a standard where successful agricultural operations could be conducted on subdivided blocks. The cost of this, judging by the pilot farm experiment, could be so great as to preclude almost every private farmer and may result in over capitalisation by big company landholders.

The pastoral land in the State of Texas in the United States of America was almost entirely owned by British interests in 1880. Who owns this land today? It is owned by the Texans. They used foreign capital for land development. We need the assistance of large scale investors in this part of the country. But they must expect some reward for their services. With these constructive suggestions that the Land Board of six or the Administrator in Council determine the subdivisional plan regarding agricultural freehold land, I support the proposals and see them as a genuine effort on behalf of the Government to get greater development for the Northern Territory pastoral industry including closer settlement, pasture improvement, agriculture and farming.
